FIGREF15.text: Introduction: The transcription factor nuclear factor of activated T cells c1 (NFATc1) is a member of a family of transcription factors which are activated upon T-cell receptor activation followed by intra-cytoplasmatic calcium influx. The NFAT family of transcription factors coordinates different aspects of T cell development and activation. NFATc1 is highly regulated in T cells where it contributes to the effector function and cell homeostasis. Furthermore, NFATc1 influences various other cells of the immune system like B cells and mast cells.

FIGREF16.text: ity, TRX is attracted attention as an endogenous peptide with antiinflammatory effects and reported to attenuate the development of allergic inflammatory diseases such as asthma and allergic rhinitis through the suppression of eosinophil functions, including migration and activation. Although histamine H 1 receptor antagonists (antihistamines) are used for the treatment of allergic diseases with remarkably success, the influence of the agents on the production of TRX is not well defined. Objectives: The influence of antihistamines, fexofenadine hydrochloride (FEX), cetirizine (CT), and levocetirizine (LCT) on TRX production from macrophages in response to H 2 O 2 stimulation was examined through the choice of in vitro cell culture technique. We also examined the influence of FEX and LCT on the appearance of TRX in nasal secretions obtained from patients with Japanese cedar pollinosis who were treated with these agents during the pollen season. Results: Addition of FEX, CT or LCT into cell cultures increased the ability of cells to produce TRX in dose-dependent manner. The minimum concentration of the agents that caused significant increase was 0.3 mM for FEX, 0.4 mM for CT and 0.4 mM for LCT, which was similar to therapeutic blood levels. Administration of FEX or LCT into the pollinosis patients also caused increase in TRX levels in nasal secretions.Conclusions: These results may suggest that antihistamines increase the ability of inflammatory cells, especially macrophages to produce TRX, and results in favorable modification of clinical status of allergic inflammatory diseases such as pollinosis.

FIGREF17.text: Objectives: Outbred CRV (CD-1) and female inbred Balb/c mice were studied, each line divided into 2 groups (8 control and 8 experimental). The control group received a standard AIN-93 diet. Experimental mice groups received over 4 months a semi-synthetic diet with high fructose concentration (30% of fructose in water). Cytokines, chemokines and growth factors (Eotaxin, G-CSF, GM-CSF, IFNc, IL-1a, IL-1b, IL-2, IL-3, IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL -9, IL-10, IL-12 (p40), IL-12 (p70), IL-13, IL-17A, KC, MCP-1, MIP-1a, MIP-1b, RANTES, TNFa) were assayed using multiplex Luminex 200 (Luminex Corporation, USA) methods with commercial kits (Bio-Plex Pro Mouse Cytokine Grp I Panel 23-Plex, Bio-Rad Laboratories, Inc. USA). Results: Excess fructose in the diet caused a significant increase in the level of IL-12P in the female Balb/c line compared to controls (median 0.409: min 0.214 -max 0.712 pg/mL vs median 0.147: min 0.125 -max 0.285 pg / ml, respectively) being more than 3-fold increased (P<.05). In line CD-1, the excess fructose diet caused significant decrease in serum chemokine MIP-1a (median 0.012: 0.002 min -max 0.030 pg/cm 3 vs median of 0.068: 0.023 min -max 0.102 pg / cm 3, respectively; P<.05) and trends to decreased IL-17A. The levels of other studied factors were significantly different after this diet from control mice. Conclusions: Experimental diet having an excesses of fructose caused increased levels of IL-12P in Balb/c mice and significant decreased levels of chemokine MIP-1a in CD-1 mice. The absence of an impact of this high carbohydrate diet on the synthesis of other pro-and anti-inflammatory factors may be a result of adaptation of the immune system and adipose tissues to this high The skin is an important immunological organ with an outer protective layer, the stratum corneum, forming a barrier between the skin-associated lymphoid tissue and the environment. The efficiency of topically applied active ingredients in cosmetics is limited by their penetration through this layer. The majority of the population in the Western world daily use some kind of topically applied cosmetics. Oleic acid (OA) is a lipid fluidiser often used as a skin penetration enhancer. The effect of OA in the skin or onimmune responses, however, is to our knowledge not known. We hypothesize that the enhanced permeability caused by OA may aggravate immune responses to cosmetic chemicals.

FIGREF18.text: Conclusions: The increased epidermal thickness and neutrophil influx in the ear, combined with the tendency of increased secretion of IL-2 in the lymph nodes, indicate that OA can aggravate local immune responses towards the allergen HCA, and thus possibly chemicals in topically applied cosmetics. Hypertonic saline sprays are frequently used as adjunct agents providing symptomatic relief and/or reducing the need for prescribed medication in allergic rhinitis patients. Recently, extracts from Undaria pinnatifida (brown algae) and Spirulina platensis (blue/green algae), rich in active ingredients fucoidans and phycocyanin, respectively, have been linked with anti-inflammatory and/or anti-allergic properties in various cellular and animal systems. To further characterize the effects of these ingredients in combination with hypertonic seawater, we have performed a series of mechanism-of-action studies in airway epithelial cells. Objectives: To assess the ability of a Hypertonic Seawater Solution (2.3% NaCl; HSS) comprising Undaria pinnatifida and Spirulina platensis algae extracts (HSS-algae solution) to reduce inflammation triggered by a respiratory allergen (ammonium hexachloroplatinate IV; HCPt) or a bacterial antigen (lipopolysaccharide; LPS) in airway epithelial cells. Results: Using 3-dimensional (3D), fully differentiated cultures of airway epithelial cells isolated from allergic human donors treated with HCPt, we have shown that the allergen induced strong IL-8 and IL-6 secretion in the supernatant of allergic cells. Moreover, HCPttreatment led to a reduction of the Cilia Beating Frequencies (CBF) of the nasal epithelium at day 3 post allergen challenge (measured by digital high-speed video imaging). Importantly, HSS-algae solutions blocked HCPt-induced cytokine increase and prevented reduction of CBF. In the same cells, HSS-algae solutions increased Mucociliary Clearance (MCC) in the absence of HCPt further supporting the positive effect of these solutions in nasal cell function. Similarly to the results obtained in allergic 3D cultures, HSS-algae solutions blocked IL-8, IL-6 and IL-1b secretion induced by LPS-challenge and increased CBF in normal epithelial 3D cultures. Conclusions: Hypertonic seawater solutions (2.3% NaCl) comprising Undaria pinnatifida and Spirulina platensis algae extracts exert direct anti-inflammatory effects and improve nasal cell function in physiological 3D cultures of epithelial cells isolated from allergic and normal donors. These results support potential use of hypertonic seawater solutions comprising natural algae ingredients in the management of allergic disease.

FIGREF19.text: Immunology, Hospital Cl ınico San Carlos, Madrid, Spain; 2 Inmunotek, S.L., Madrid, Spain; 3 Department of Hematology, Hospital Cl ınico San Carlos, Madrid, Spain Introduction: Lymphoproliferative syndromes (LPS) are a diverse group of hematological diseases where both the disease and the use of new therapies contribute to secondary immunodeficiency. Infectious complications in LPS patients are the major cause of morbiditymortality. Objectives: To assess the clinical benefit of personalized polybacterial sublingual vaccines in an observational study of LPS patients with recurrent infections. Results: A cohort of LPS patients with recurrent respiratory tract infections (RRTI) (≥3 episodes of upper RTI or at least 1 pneumonia/ year) and recurrent urinary tract infections (RUTI) (≥3 UTIs/year) treated with polybacterial sublingual vaccines was carried out. All patients underwent immunization with sublingual polyvalent preparation (MV140, INMUNOTEK S.L. Madrid, Spain) for RRTI (Staphylococcus spp., S. pneumoniae, K. pneumoniae, M. catarrhalis, H. influenzae) or RUTI (MV130: K. pneumoniae, E. coli, E. faecalis, P. vulgaris) for 3 months and followed-up at 6-months and 1-year. Baseline immunological evaluation included: serum Igs, IgG subclasses, specific antibodies' production, and B and T cell subsets counts. Baseline information included number of GP visits per year and hospitalization. Patients were classified based on their global improvement: clear improvement (>60% reduction of the number of new infections), partial improvement (25-60%) and no improvement (≤25%).

FIGREF20.text: Introduction: Recurrent respiratory tract infections (RRTIs) in children are a major healthcare problem associated with significant morbidity and mortality. The majority of these infections are due to viral infections and can induce asthma symptoms in lower airways (wheezing, bronchospasm etc). The available therapy with inhaled corticosteroids has a limited efficacy in the prevention of these viralinduced symptoms.Immunostimulation with selected bacterial strains through the sublingual route has demonstrated to induce clinical benefit in patients with RRTIs.

FIGREF21.text: Both SpyCatcher-VLP and Der p 2-SpyTag migrated as single band onto SDS-PAGE. Mixing of SpyCatcher-VLP with Der p 2-SpyTag resulted in an efficient covalent coupling of the spy-tagged allergen to the surface of SpyCatcher-VLPs. Specifically, densitometric analysis of SDS-PAGE gels indicated 66% coupling efficiency, corresponding to 118 rDer p 2 molecules displayed per SpyCatcher-VLP. In addition, DLS analysis shows that VLP-Der p 2 complexes appear as non-aggregated particles with an average diameter of 40 nm. Indirect ELISA assay, using sera from HDM allergic patients sensitized to Der p 2, displayed similar IgE reactivity to VLP-Der p 2, rDer p 2-SpyTag and rDer p 2 produced in P. pastoris. Remarkably, whereas Der p 2-SpyTag and rDer p 2 Pichia can activate the degranulation of basophils preloaded with Der p 2-specific IgE positive sera, VLP-Der p 2 hardly triggered basophil activation. Neither of the two soluble forms of rDer p 2 nor VLP-Der p 2 induced basophil degranulation using serum from non-allergic individuals.

FIGREF22.text: Eastern Finland, Joensuu, Finland; 2 VTT Technical Research Centre of Finland Ltd., Espoo, Finland; 3 Desentum Oy, Espoo, Finland Introduction: The detailed molecular characterization of natural or recombinant allergens and their mutants is essential in studying molecular features characteristic for allergenicity or production of (hypo)allergens for specific immunotherapy. We have developed a mass spectrometry (MS) based platform for the measurement of allergens in their native, folded state. Native MS allows stoichiometrical, topological and dynamical characterizations of proteins and their complexes. Objectives: Native MS is extremely powerful when performed with high-resolution techniques such as a Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance (FT-ICR). FT-ICR allows very precise mass measurements of large proteins and their complexes as well as analyses from complex mixtures. Our FT-ICR instrumentation consists of a Bruker solariX XR FT-ICR mass spectrometer equipped with a 12tesla superconducting magnet. High-field FT-ICR allows mass measurements from very small amounts of protein material. High mass accuracy and resolution provided by FT-ICR allows direct sequence verification through comparison of experimental and theoretical protein masses. All possible covalent modifications can also be detected. Native MS is used to study folding of allergens as well as quaternary structure and complex formation with other proteins or ligands. The method also allows studying weak or transient interactions, whose dissociation constants are up to the low millimolar level. Results: We have characterized a number of different natural and recombinant allergen proteins or their mutants by using our native FT-ICR MS platform. These include food allergens (bovine milk), animal dander allergens (dog, horse), tree allergens (birch) and grass pollen allergens (timothy). The results show a large spectrum of different forms of heterogeneity in the allergen samples and a frequent tendency of many allergens to form transient oligomers in solution.Conclusions: The utilization of native FT-ICR MS is a very versatile tool for exact molecular analysis of allergen proteins. It is very powerful method for monitoring homogeneity of protein materials which can be utilized in the quality control of (hypo)allergens intended for clinical use. Native MS is also a new tool in the analysis of allergen protein folding and in detecting even weak protein-protein and protein-ligand interactions, which may have important implications for their biological function. Specifically designed recombinant allergens with reduced IgE reactivity are promising candidates for a more defined, effective, and safe specific immunotherapy (SIT). The aim of this work was to characterize a hybrid recombinant hypoallergen (QM1S) of the major allergens Der p 1 and Der p 2 in order to obtain a vaccine prototype for SIT against house dust mite (HDM) allergy.

FIGREF23.text: Dermatophagoides pteronyssinus and D. farinae house dust mites are a prominent cause of perennial allergy worldwide. These two mite species exhibit particularly broad and complex allergen spectra with up to 35 different allergen groups registered by the International Union of Immunological Societies (IUIS) as of today, with some IgE reactivities still unassigned. The objective of our study was to further characterize the proteomes and allergomes of D. pteronyssinus and D. farinae and identify novel allergens. The identification of such new allergenic components is however notably hindered by the lack of comprehensive house dust mite sequence datasets. Objectives: We conducted a comprehensive analysis of D. farinae and D. pteronyssinus transcriptomes by deep RNA sequencing. Transcriptomic data were used to tailor protein sequence databases suitable with mass spectrometry (MS)-based identification of proteins. We then performed a proteome and allergome analysis based on two-dimensional electrophoresis and IgE reactivity profiling. Recombinant molecules were produced in both E. coli and P. pastoris to confirm IgE binding. Results: Transcripts from D. pteronyssinus and D. farinae were assembled de novo after deep RNA sequencing. Databases encompassing 143 369 and 37 585 entries, respectively, were thus populated after CDS detection and translation, and used to inform proteomic analyses. Extensive characterization of proteomes by bottom-up MS analysis combined to IgE reactivity profiling after two dimensional electrophoresis of HDM aqueous extracts to the identification of novel HDM allergen candidates. We notably confirmed IgE reactivity of a protein representing a new allergen group in both species using non glycosylated recombinant molecules.Conclusions: We performed a detailed characterization of D.pteronyssinus and D. farinae proteomes and identified a novel allergen group present in those two mite species. Those allergens have been submitted for official registration by the IUIS Allergen Nomen-The objective of the present study is to formulate and evaluate SLIT containing two incompatible allergens-purified extracts of Cockroach and Parthenium. Incompatible and interactive allergens are not permitted to mix together and dispense due to their interaction and degradation of the proteins by endogenous proteases. This novel bilayer tablets approach not only overcomes the incompatibility but also makes the ailing patient a convenient way of taking both the allergens at the same time from the bilayer tablet.

FIGREF24.text: Stability studies were carried out every month as per ICH guidelines. Further stability studies of the formulations and characterization of the allergen by SDS page are in progress. Conclusions: The physical characteristics, stability and in-vitro release results of bilayer tablets were found satisfactory and appreciable when compared with the tablets containing mix allergen in single layer Tablet. The Sublingual drops formulation containing mixture of both the allergens showed steep fall in potency as the allergens in combination tend to interact and degrade in liquid formulations when compared with the Single allergen SLIT drops.

FIGREF25.text: Objectives: To examine the faculty of a MED171-encoding DNA vaccine as an immunotherapeutic modulator in a mouse model of shrimp hypersensitivity and to investigate the modulatory role of the induced Foxp3 + regulatory T (Treg) cells. Results: DNA vaccine was constructed by expressing the hypoallergen MED171 in the plasmid pCI-Neo. Balb/c mice in the treatment group were intradermally injected with the DNA vaccine after Met e 1 sensitization and challenge. Non-sensitized mice and sensitized mice receiving PBS or mock plasmid as sham treatment were included as negative and positive controls. Blood, spleen and small intestine were collected for antibody, cytokine, flow cytometric, gene expression, histological and immunohistological analyses to evaluate the efficacy of the vaccine. It was found that DNA vaccination pronouncedly reduced the level of specific IgE and Th2 cytokines, as well as local inflammatory responses in the treated mice comparing to the positive controls. In addition to the induction of Th1 responses, DNA vaccination doubled the frequency of Foxp3 + Treg cells in the spleen of treated mice, in parallel with the up-regulation of FOXP3 expression and accumulation of Foxp3 + cells in the small intestine. In some experiments, BALB/c mice from the treatment or PBS control groups were dosed with anti-CD25 antibody to assess the modulatory role of Treg cells. Such depletion of Treg cells in the vaccine-treated mice restored the infiltration of mast cells and eosinophils in the small intestine as in the sham and was significantly more intense than in the non-depleted treated mice. Conclusions: MED171-encoding DNA vaccine effectively ameliorates shrimp allergy in mice and acts through a Treg-mediated mechanism. [This work was fully supported by the Health and Medical Research Fund (02130206), Hong Kong Special Administration Region, China]

FIGREF26.text: Introduction: We aimed to determine the prevalence and severity of the reactions in children during subcutaneous venom immunotherapy and we tried to find the possible risk factors for large local and systemic reactions.

FIGREF27.text: and in 81 children immunotherapy for vespula species; and in one children apis mellifera + vespula immunotherapy were given. During the immunotherapy doses 40 (37.4%) patients had local, 5 (4.7%) of patients had large local and 7 (6.5%) patients had systemic reactions. A total of 5671 injections were given and local, large local and systemic reaction rates were 1.60%, 0.14% and 0.17% respectively. Multiple logistic regression analysis revealed the presence of asthma (OR:4,1, 95% CI 1.3-12.7, P=.016) as a significant risk factor for the development of large local and systemic reactions. A total of 33/68 (48.5%) patients declared a bee sting during the venom immunotherapy. The median time for bee sting after the beginning of immunotherapy was 34 months (inter-quartile range 24-46 moths). In 24 (72.7%) out of 33 patients developed a reaction (19 local, 1 large local and 4 systemic). Systemic reactions were Muller grade 1 and 2. Conclusions: In children, the reactions seen during venom immunotherapy are mostly local. Presence of asthma is a significant risk factor for the development of large local and systemic reactions during venom immunotherapy. Bee sting during immunotherapy frequently causes reactions. However most of these reactions are local or mild systemic.

FIGREF28.text: expression of hypoxia-inducible factor-2a (HIF-2a) in the nasal mucosa of patients with nasal polyps (NP), and to investigate if HIF-2a plays an important role in the pathogenesis of NP. Results: NP tissues were obtained from 40 patients; biopsies of inferior turbinate mucosa from 20 healthy subjects were used as controls. Quantitative PCR and immunohistochemistry were performed to determine the expression levels of HIF-2a. HIF-2a mRNA expression is significantly lower (2.27-fold) in tissues from NP patients when compared to controls, HIF-2a staining immunoreactivity is significantly weaker in NP patients than that of controls. HIF-2a mRNA level has a significant positive correlation with vascular endothelial cadherin (VE-cadherin). The staining immunoreactivity of VE-cadherin is also significantly weaker in NP patients than that of controls. Conclusions: Down-regulation of HIF-2a is associated with aberrant endothelial intercellular junctions in NP, and it could contribute to the edema and infiltration of inflammatory cells in the pathogenesis of NP.

FIGREF29.text: , the Second Hospital of Shandong University, Shandong University, Ji Nan, China; 2 Department of Otolaryngology, the Central Hospital of Zibo, China, Zi Bo, China Introduction: Nasal polyps (NPs) are a manifestation of certain types of chronic rhinosinusitis with histological characterization of chronic mucosal inflammation and abnormal epithelial remodeling. Abnormal expression of T-helper 17(Th17) and inflammatory cells may contribute to the pathogenesis of nasal polyps. Objectives: This study assessed the expression of Th17 cells, eosinophil cells, neutrophil cells, macrophage and related cytokines in patients with nasal polyps (NPs) and tested for correlation between Th17 cells and inflammatory cells. Results: The positive number of Th17 cells in-GC NP group were significantly higher 16.22 (10.19-22.25) as compared to controls ABSTRACTS | 205

FIGREF30.text: 17A mRNA and eosinophil cells number (r=À.5923, P<.05) and macrophage cells number (r=.5875, P<.05). There were positive correlation between Th17 + cells and the mRNA level of IL-5Ra, GATA, IL-10 (r value was 0.5595、0.6023,0.7667, all P<.05) in-GC NP patients. Conclusions: There were closely association between Th17 cells and Th2 cell immune response in NP patients, especially the eosinophil cells, which may provide new insights into the pathogenesis of CRSwNP. 0226 | Are there any specific signs of allergic fungal rhinosinusitis visible by computed tomography scan? Infectious and Tropic Diseases Clinical Centre of Serbia, Belgrade, Serbia; 2 Leibniz Institute for Natural Product Research and Infection Biology -Hans Kn€ oll Institute (HKI), Jena, Germany; 3 Center for Radiological Diagnostics, School of Dentistry, University of Belgrade, Belgrade, Serbia; 4 Clinic for Infectious and Tropic Diseases, Clinical Centre of Serbia, Belgrade, Serbia; 5 Clinic for Allergology and Clinical Immunology Clinical Centre of Serbia, Belgrade, Serbia Introduction: Radiological features along with clinical presentation are critical for early diagnosis, prognosis and appropriate treatment of chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS). It is still unknown if there are some parameters of the computed tomography (CT) image that are clearly distinguishable for the cases of CRS with fungal involvement -allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS). In addition, possible signs of fungal involvement in CRS, that might be seen on the CT image before the formation of the allergic mucin clusters (hyper-attenuated zones), and the complete radiological picture of AFRS, have not been established yet.

FIGREF31.text: We suppose that development of AFRS is host-, environment-and time-dependent, as there are worse results of CT finding in patients with longer duration of CRS. AFRS produces a more non-homogenous opacity that is slightly hyperdense on CT as compared to other forms of CRS, what could be helpful in distinguishing AFRS from other CRS forms. The demonstration of focal or diffuse areas of increased attenuation in paranasal sinus soft-tissue masses on unenhanced CT scans, strongly suggests fungal involvement and should be considered as official AFRS diagnostic criteria. 0227 | Expression profiles of regulatory and helper T-cell-associated genes in antrochoanal polyp Hospital of Shandong University, Jinan, China; 2 National University of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore Introduction: Antrochoanal polyp (ACP) is a neutrophil-dominated inflammation, but it is unclear what role regulatory T (T-reg) cells and helper T (Th) cells play in the pathology of ACP. Objectives: We investigated the expression profiles of T-reg and T-helper-cell-associated genes in Chinese patients with ACP in this study. Biopsies were obtained from 21 ACP patients for comparison with 34 inferior turbinates collected from healthy controls. The expression levels of mRNA for inflammatory cell and T-cell related markers were determined by quantitative PCR. Cellular infiltrates were assessed by histo-and immunohistochemistry.

FIGREF32.text: Conclusions: Up-regulation of T-reg transcription factor FOXP3 and down-regulation of Th1/Th2/Th17 transcription factor T-bet, GATA3 and RORc in ACP indicate a regulatory response occurring at a site of persistent mucosal inflammation. However, immune regulation fails to control the underlying tissue pathology. FXOP3 may play important role in the pathogenesis of ACP. 0228 | Olfactory change pattern after endoscopic sinus surgery in chronic rhinosinusitis with olfactory dysfunction Zi X; Shi L; Zhi L; Jin P; Zhao L; Tu Y; Li A; Li T Department of Otolaryngology, The Second Affiliated Hospital Of Shandong University, China, Jinan, China Introduction: Olfactory dysfunction is a common complaint among chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) patients, with a prevalence of 30-60% across CRS with or without nasal polyps (CRSwNP or CRSsNP), and it is one of the four signs and symptoms to diagnose CRS according to EPOS 2012. ESS for patient with CRS is considered a well-established surgical method in case where medical therapy fails, Months after operation are the key period for olfactory recovery, However, the olfactory change pattern after ESS in short-term and its relationship with CT scores and QOL remains understudied.

FIGREF33.text: 0229 | The effect of HGF, TGF-ß1, and PGE2 in allergic rhinitis mouse model Mo J; Kim J; Bae J; Kim E Dankook University College of Medicine, Cheonan, South Korea Introduction: In our previous study, we reported the anti-allergic effect of tonsil derived mesenchymal stem cell and its culture supernatant in allergic rhinitis mouse model and identified increment of HGF, TGF-b1 and PGE 2 in the culture supernatant of tonsil derived mesenchymal stem cell.

FIGREF34.text: Conjunctival fibroblasts and mast cells are thought to contribute to conjunctival wound healing. It was reported that the number of mast cells in the conjunctiva increased in individuals who had undergone glaucoma surgery. Mast cells may therefore contribute to the scarring observed after trabeculectomy surgery. We have now investigated the potential role of mast cell-fibroblast interactions in conjunctival wound healing with the use of threedimensional cultures of mouse cells in a collagen gel. Objectives: We examined the effect of bone marrow-derived mast cells on the contractility of conjunctival fibroblasts in a threedimensional collagen lattice system. Fibroblast contraction results in shrinkage of the collagen gel, which is quantitated as a decrease in gel diameter. The release of matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-2 and MMP-9 into culture supernatants was evaluated by gelatin zymography. Results: Collagen gels containing mast cells alone did not manifest contraction during culture for 5 days, whereas those containing conjunctival fibroblasts alone shrank in size in a time-dependent manner. The addition of mast cells to cultures of conjunctival fibroblasts resulted in a further decrease of gel diameter dependent on added mast cell numbers. Gelatin zymography revealed that addition of mast cells increased the amounts of proMMP-9 as well as of active forms of MMP-2 in the culture supernatants. A synthetic MMP inhibitor attenuated the stimulatory effect of mast cells on collagen gel contraction mediated by conjunctival fibroblasts. Conclusions: Our results suggest that mast cells increase the release and activation of MMPs and therefore, promote collagen gel contraction mediated by conjunctival fibroblasts. Interaction between conjunctival fibroblasts and mast cells may thus contribute to conjunctival scarring after glaucoma surgery. 0231 | Role of interleukin-10 in immunoglobulin e-mediated immediate hypersensitivity in the conjunctiva of mice Ishida W; Fukuda K; Harada Y; Taguchi O; Fukushima A Department of Ophthalmology, Kochi Medical School, Nankoku-Shi, Japan

FIGREF35.text: Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is a chronic allergic eye disease that mainly affects children and young adults. Chronic eye rubbing might lead to keratoconus, a disease characterized by thinning and steepening in the cornea causing irregular astigmatism and subsequent decrease in visual acuity. Corneal cross-linking (CCL) is a new treatment, which uses riboflavin in combination with UV-A to induce chemical bonds between collagen fibrils in the corneal stroma and prevents the progression of the disease.

FIGREF36.text: 0233 | Systemic associations in VKC affected children: analysis and considerations of last 7 years clinical records in our tertiary referral center.Ciurlo C; Allegri P Lavagna Genoa Hospital, Lavagna Genoa, Italy Introduction: Some recent literature reports show that among VKC patients, about one half of them showed associated systemic allergic diseases, but until now, there is no evidence of auto-immune or other systemic associations. Objectives: Following the observation that in last years we assist to an exponential increasing of other systemic diseases associated with VKC we retrospectively reviewed the clinical data of 315 children (62.8% males, 37.2% females) followed in the last 6 years (from Jan 2011 to Dec 2016) in our Lavagna Hospital North-Western referral center for allergic conjunctivitis. Our purpose was to register all the cases suffering from not allergic systemic diseases associated with VKC and their ocular and clinical characteristics.

FIGREF37.text: Genova) Hospital -Pediatric Dep., Genova, Italy; 3 Lavagna Hospital -Pediatric Dep., Genova, Italy Introduction: Specific immunotherapy (SIT) for allergic diseases is a quite recently recognized treatment and it is currently applied also in allergic rhinitis and rhino-conjunctivitis. No publication, until now, is available, at our knowledge, on the efficacy of SIT in rare ocular allergic diseases like vernal kerato-conjunctivitis (VKC).

FIGREF38.text: To collect fatal anaphylaxis cases in children (<19 years) in France from 1979 to 2011 and to determine pediatric anaphylaxis mortality rate (PAMR), time trends and specificities according to triggers, sex and geographical regions. Data were obtained from databases of 1) the French Mortality Center (CEPIDC) to collect fatal anaphylaxis cases 2) the National Institute for Statistics and Economics and (INSEE) to define the referent populations.

FIGREF39.text: Fatal anaphylaxis is a rare event in childhood, around 10 times lower than in adulthood in France. Trigger often remains unknown. The PAMR might be underestimated. Implementation of guidelines and new International Classification of Diseases (ICD 11) might improve accuracy and completeness of the coding for anaphylaxis and exhaustivity of anaphylaxis-related deaths databases. Paediatrics and Adolescent Medicine, Queen Mary Hospital, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR Introduction: Anaphylaxis, a potentially life-threatening allergic reaction, has increased in many developed countries in recent decades. However, there is limited data on anaphylaxis epidemiology in Asian regions. In this study, we examine the time trends of anaphylaxis incidence in Hong Kong during a 14 year-period, and explore anaphylaxis triggers and gender differences in anaphylaxis incidence. Objectives: We obtained anaphylaxis emergency visits and hospital admissions data from the Hong Kong Clinical Data Analysis and Reporting System from July 1, 2001 to June 30, 2015. Anaphylaxis was defined according to the International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision (995.0, 995.60 to 995.69). Anaphylaxis patients were divided into groups (food, drug, other) according to the trigger recorded on the diagnosis description. Incidence rates of anaphylaxis were calculated by using population estimates from Centre for Health Protection, Department of Health, Hong Kong.

FIGREF40.text: Allergy and Clinical Immunology, Kangwon National University School of Medicine, Chuncheon, South Korea Introduction: The incidence of anaphylaxis is often underreported and there have been few epidemiologic studies. To prevent anaphylaxis and related mortality, patient education is important and prescription of epinephrine self-injector is needed in some cases. Objectives: We investigated the prevalence of anaphylaxis and prescription rates of epinephrine self-injector in Korea We used data from the 2010-2014 Health Insurance Review and Assessment database, which covers the claims of 97.0% of the South Korean population. Anaphylaxis was identified on physician-certified diagnoses using the ICD-10 codes (T782). Data upon prescription of epinephrine self-injector were collected from the Korea Orphan Drug Center, which is the only pharmacy exclusively dealing with epinephrine self-injector in Korea.

FIGREF41.text: Introduction: Anaphylaxis and mediator-related symptoms belong to the most prevalent and dangerous symptoms observed in mastocytosis patients. The ECNM database gives a unique opportunity to analyze factors responsible for the severity and clinical impact of allergies reactions, their local variations, and their relation to the variant of the disease in patients with mastocytosis.

FIGREF42.text: Coskun R; Demir S; € Unal D; Olgac M; Gelincik A; Çolakoglu B; B€ uy€ uk€ ozt€ urk S Istanbul Faculty of Medicine, Department of Internal Medicine, Division of Allergy, Istanbul, Turkey Introduction: Anaphylaxis is a serious allergic reaction that can be lethal. A number of risk factors and co-factors have been described for anaphylaxis. We aimed to investigate the clinical characteristics of anaphylaxis and also the factors affecting its severity. Objectives: A total of 404 cases with anaphylaxis history (99 male, 305 female) were included. Demographic and clinical characteristics of the patients were questioned via questionnaire who applied between 2014 and 2016. Results: Half of the patients (47.5%)(m:54, f:138) had more than 1 and 14.9% (m:22, f:38) had at least 4 anaphylaxis attacks. The most common causes of anaphylaxis were drugs (n=295, 73.1%), venom (n=55, 13.6%) and foods (n=32, 7.9%); 36.4% of the patients had a concomitant infection and 20.3% were regularly using NSAI. In 15 patients (3.7%) had late anaphylaxis and only 1 patient had biphasic reaction. Half of the patients (48.8%) had no comorbidities. Most of the patients (n=391) applied to emergency units due to anaphylaxis;

FIGREF43.text: Center-Charit e, Department of Dermatology and Allergy, Charit e-Universit€ atsmedizin Berlin, Berlin, Germany; 2 Proteome Factory AG, Berlin, Germany Introduction: Anaphylaxis is a mast cell dependent potentially lifethreatening hypersensitivity reaction. Upon mast cell degranulation preformed and de novo synthesized mediators are released. Up to now there is no reliable marker to support the clinical diagnosis of anaphylaxis or to determine the severity of the reaction.

FIGREF44.text: Boer D; Nieuwhof C; Menheere P; Bons J Maastricht University Medical Centre, Maastricht, The Netherlands Introduction: Knowledge in respect with the biological variation (BV) is important to interpret fluctuations in tryptase concentrations of allergy in general and of drug and food allergy in particular. Because chronic diseases are considered to be models of "physiological" BV around an adapted homeostatic set-point, mastocytosis and chronic urticaria can be studied as models of interest for BV of tryptase.

FIGREF45.text: Basal serum tryptase levels were higher in PS-allergic patients compared to control donors (12.47AE5.67 vs 10.4AE3.13 ng/ mL). Basophils showed increased degranulation (CD63+:2.33AE0.9 vs 1.31AE0.63; P=.009), and T cells from PS-allergic patients showed increased activation after contact with PS membranes (CD4+CD69+ T cells: 8.3AE4.6 vs 3.7AE1.8%; P=.048) when low volumes of priming fluid were used. No activation was detected in control samples. Acute samples from two PS-allergic patients showed an elevation of serum tryptase, as well as a decrease in complement levels (C3 and C4). Conclusions: Basophil degranulation in PS-allergic patients and elevated serum tryptase levels during acute reactions support the activation of mast cells and basophils during hypersensitivity reactions to PS membranes. Complement activation may also participate in this activation. A leachable component of the membranes may be responsible of T cells and basophils activation in some patients. Cofactors, such as alcohol, acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) and especially exercise, are known to induce reactions in wheat allergic patients below their threshold at wheat dosages normally considered safe. Only few studies have sought to investigate the effects of co-factors on other type-1 food allergies. The experimental 'passive cutaneous anaphylaxis' model (modified Prausnitz-K€ ustner) allows in a patient-safe manner to study the time and size of an allergic reaction using sera from allergic patients in healthy subjects, who can be orally challenged with or without inclusion of co-factors.

FIGREF46.text: Both alcohol and ASA affected reaction time and size of reactions elicited after egg ingestion in this passive cutaneous anaphylaxis model. This could indicate that patients with egg allergy could have faster and more severe reactions after ingestion of egg in combination with co-factors, and that co-factors should be considered in relation to other food allergies than wheat.

FIGREF47.text: of physicians were aware the recommendations from the French Society for Anaesthesia and Resuscitation. The European or American recommendations were less known. 47.7% (21) of physicians used the classification of Ring and Messmer, and 11.2% (5) classification of Muller to evaluate the severity of anaphylaxis. The recognition of symptoms is good in our studies even for the abdominal symptoms. Indeed, abdominal pains or vomiting were reported as anaphylactic symptoms by respectively 79.5% (35) and 63.8% (28). However, the way the question was asked placed the respondent in context of anaphylaxis. Regarding the first-line treatment, cutaneous-mucosal symptoms were treated by oral antihistamines by 95.3% (42) of physicians, by intravenous antihistamines or by corticotherapy in 2.3%

FIGREF48.text: Pediatrics, Faculty of Medicine Ramathibodi Hospital, Mahidol University, Bangkok, Thailand; 2 Department of Radiology, Faculty of Medicine Ramathibodi Hospital, Mahidol University, Bangkok, Thailand Introduction: Intramuscular epinephrine is the first line drug in the treatment of anaphylaxis. Epinephrine prefilled syringe is an alternative prescription instead of epinephrine auto-injector.

FIGREF49.text: One inch needle length may not be appropriated for epinephrine prefilled syringe in all children. Vila Nova de Gaia/Espinho, EPE, Vila Nova De Gaia, Portugal Introduction: Multiple drug hypersensitivity (MDH) syndrome consists in allergies to two or more chemically different drugs. Most cases described are associated with antibiotics, although other drugs can be involved. Antihistamines (AH) and corticosteroids (CCT) are not common culprits, making the suspicion of hypersensitivity reactions (HR) to these drugs less likely. More importantly, the treatment of most allergy diseases becomes quite difficult if the patient presents a MDH syndrome to these drugs.

FIGREF50.text: School of Medicine, Department of Chest Diseases, Division of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, Ankara, Turkey Introduction: Oral iron preparations are well-tolerated drugs which frequently are used for iron deficiency anemia. Hypersensitivity reactions due to oral iron salts are rare. Although management of intravenous iron hypersensitivity is well-defined in literature, there is little known about oral iron hypersensitivity.

FIGREF51.text: Medical resources: assessment of potential medication needed in case of reaction Reception of patients: assessment of no health problems in the previous 24h Premedication: assessment of correct intake of the premedication prescribed by the allergist Assessment of a secure vascular: Drug administration: verification of the correct reception of the drug-doses prescribed and that these correspond to the patient, monitoring of vital signs and assessment of a correct administration in the order programmed Results: With this nursing protocol we accomplish an exhaustive vigilance of the patients which conduce to a rapid detection of a possible reaction. Furthermore, in case of reaction, with the fast intervention of the nursing and the medical material prepared, we achieved a decrease in the severity of the reactions and a faster resolution of them.

FIGREF52.text: Garcia JF; Aun MV; Motta AA; Kalil J; Giavina-Bianchi P University of São Paulo, São Paulo, Brazil Introduction: Allergy to penicillin is a major cause of drug anaphylaxis worldwide and may preclude the only effective treatment of pregnant women with syphilis. Rapid Drug Desensitization (RDD) is an alternative approach and has become a cornerstone in the management of anaphylaxis to drugs, and biomarkers to predict breakthrough reactions during the procedure are needed. The study assessed the safety and efficacy of risk stratification for guiding penicillin re-introduction in pregnant women with syphilis and past history of allergy to penicillin.

FIGREF53.text: 29-year old woman who with the second dose of BV experienced a severe HSR with itching in the hands and feet 5 minutes into the infusion and dyspnea at the end of administration. Patient 2: A 48-year-old man developed dyspnea, chest tightness and syncope, at 5 minutes of infusion of the second dose of BV. Results: The results of intradermal skin tests with BV were positive in both patients. However, the prick skin test was only positive in patient 2. Also, results of BAT with BV were positive in both patients.

FIGREF54.text: Desensitization protocols for chemotherapy agents have been extensively performed and in patients with immediate hypersensitivity reactions (IHSRs) have proven to be effective. All standardized protocols that have been published have been performed with premedication. However, premedication can cover up the symptoms of the reaction. The aimed of our study was to assess the safety and effectively of a desensitization protocol without premedication.

FIGREF55.text: Biologicals (B) that inhibits tumor necrosis factor alpha-infliximab (I) and adalimumab (A) are used for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) however hypersensitivity reactions preclude their use in sensitized patients. The rapid desensitization (RD) could help to return B to the IBD treatment. Objectives: Our aim was to evaluate the RD safety and efficiency in IBD patients on I and A treatment. We examined 50 IBD patients from September 2012 to December 2016 by prospective manner. 45 (90%) patients suffered from M. Crohn, 4 (8%) patients from ulcerative colitis and 1 (2%) patient from IBD undifferentiated form. The mean age was 40 years (17-64 years). The group consisted of 40 women (80%). Adverse reactions to I occurred in 19 patients (38%), adverse reactions to A in 16 patients (32%) and to both drugs in 15 patients (30%). According to the classification of adverse reactions to B by Pichler et al., the type alpha occurred in 7 (14%), type beta in 27 (54%), type gamma in 14 (28%), type delta in 0 patient and type epsilon in 2 (4%) patients. Methods: Skin tests (ST) were positive in 5 (10%) and basophile activation test (BAT) was positive in 7 (17%) patients. IgG antibodies to infliximab were not detected. IgG antibodies to adalimumab could have been examined only in December 2016 in only 7 patients with negative result. RD was indicated when skin test and/or TAB were positive in 12 (60%) subjects and based on clinical course of an adverse reaction in additional 8 (16%) persons.Overall, the desensitizations were performed in 20 (40%) patients, with infliximab in 8 (40%) and with adalimumab in 12 (60%) patients.Montelukast, anti H1 and H2 blockers and systemic steroids were used for the pretreatment which could be later withdrawn in 5 (10%) persons. All procedures (skin and blood tests, desensitization) were carried out with the informed consent of the patients.Results: Successful RD was performed in 16 (80%) patients. In 4 (20%) patients desensitization had to be stopped early for the adverse reactions (dyspnoea and exanthema in 2, decrease of C3 and C4 complement proteins in one and flu-like syndrome in one Around 15% of inpatients report a history of penicillin allergy, but very few are truly allergic. Clinicians rarely question a history of penicillin allergy and unnecessarily withhold penicillin in a large number of mislabelled patients. A label of penicillin allergy also creates hesitancy in using other beta-lactams.

FIGREF56.text: Experimental design: In November 2016, we sent via email a 20item online survey developed using SurveyMonkey.com to 1511 medical and non-medical prescribers at Central Manchester University Hospitals.The survey investigated prescribers' knowledge of penicillin allergy diagnosis and management, their views about the barriers to correct management and the improvement interventions that we are planning to implement in the Trust.

FIGREF57.text: Introduction: Microcrystalline Tyrosine (MCT) represents a patented depot adjuvant formulation and currently features in licensed modified allergen (allergoid) vaccines and various other preclinical and clinical developments. The mechanism of MCT adjuvants is sought and the objective of the current study was to analyse innate and adaptive immunogenicity of MCT-based vaccines in murine models in vivo and in vitro, compared to those of aluminiumbased vaccines. Objectives: BALB/c or C57BL/6 mice were immunised by subcutaneous injections with ovalbumin (OVA) combined with MCT or aluminium hydroxide (alum). OVA-specific antibody responses were tested in blood, while OVA-specific CD4 and CD8 T-cell responses were tested in cultures of spleen cells restimulated in vitro with OVA. For T-cell response, C57BL/6 mice were adoptively transferred with lymphocytes from transgenic T-cell receptor OT-I (CD8) and OT-II (CD4) mice. Antibody responses in serum were measured by ELISA, while cytokine secretion were measured both in culture supernatants by ELISA or by intracellular staining and flow cytometry of spleen cells. Results: The onset and the peak of the antibody IgG1 and IgG2 responses in mice immunised with aluminium were typically faster than with MCT, but no significant difference in the endpoint titres were observed between the two groups of immunised mice. A significant secretion of the T-helper type 1 cytokine IFN-y from spleen cells was observed both in MCT-and alum-immunised mice measured. In the C57BL/6 model, MCT but not alum mediated IFN-y secretion. In the OT-I/OT-II cell transfer model, Th1 cytokine secretion with OVA-MCT was comparable or even higher than cells with OVA-alum. This confirmed in flow cytometry after staining of spleen cells with fluorescent antibodies against CD4, CD8, activation molecules and intracellular cytokines. Conclusions: Results from these pre-clinical immunogenicity studies in mice have demonstrated the comparative potential of MCT and aluminium-based adjuvants with regards to their potential for stimulation antibody responses and T-cell responses. The favourable Th1-like immune responses produced by MCT together with the previously demonstrated favourable safety profile of MCT-based vaccines, suggest that MCT may meet the requirement for a wide range of future vaccines and immunotherapies.

FIGREF58.text: of Immunology FMBA, Moscow, Russia Case Report: Background: The study is based on the assumption that short synthetic peptides that mimic the dominant B and T cell epitopes attached to biodegradable polymeric nanoparticles can be delivered intradermally or sublingually to induce sustained immunological tolerance and/or stimulate the activation of Th1 cells. Methods: Synthetic fragments of Bet v 1, major allergen of birch pollen, with sequences of amino acids 120-132 (KO-1), 104-116 (NC-817), 42-57 (NC-815) and 141-156 (NC-818) were synthesized. To detect the IgE/IgG binding activity of peptides sera samples were collected from BALB/c mice after immunization with recombinant Bet v1 together with Al(OH) 3 or Freund's adjuvant. Allergenicity of peptides was detected by whole blood histamine release assay (HPLC with tandem mass-spectrometry) using blood from patients with sensitivity to birch pollen and by ELISA (IgE binding) with mouse polyclonal antibodies specific to Bet v1. The peptides (Pep) were conjugated with nature polymer chitosan (CS) via maleimidopropionic acid (Mal) linker. This conjugate having positive charge was adsorbed onto nanoparticles, poly(lactic-co-glycolic acid)/PLGA (75/25) having negative charge. The final structure of conjugate PLGA/CS/Mal/Pep was proved by amino acid analysis, infrared spectrometry and dynamic light scattering. Results: Peptides with sequences of KO-1, NC-817, NC-815 and to a lesser extent NC-818 showed noticeable binding activity with anti-Bet v1 IgE, but at a much lower than whole birch extract (T3). At the same time we did not observed marked anti-Bet v1 IgG-binding activity of these peptides, except for fragment NC-817. Al peptides demonstrated low histamine release activity in comparison to histamine release induced by T3. We have prepared PLGA-based nanoparticles that contain four Bet v1-specific fragments with a size of about 100-150 nm bearing a positive charge. Conclusion: The data obtained indicate the possibility that even short peptides may exhibit allergenic activity. In the case of Bet 1 this fact has not previously been demonstrated. In future work, we plan to assessment the allergenicity of conjugates Sublingual polybacterial immunostimulation is successfully used in the clinical practice for the prophylaxis of recurrent bacterial infections. Sublingual immunostimulation of inactivated Candida albicans is being currently prescribed with success in the prophylaxis of Recurrent Vulvovaginal Candidiasis (RVVC). Objectives: To assess the systemic response of the sublingual immunostimulation with Candida albicans in mice, evaluating the in vitro proliferative capacity of splenocytes and the production of cytokines to specific and unspecific stimuli. Results: 32 Balb/C mice, divided in 4 groups of 8 animals each (4 females and 4 males per group), were immunized sublingually with 3 different concentrations of a selected strain (V132) of Candida albicans (group 1: 10 10 organisms/mL, group 2: 10 9 organisms/mL and group 3: 10 8 organisms/mL) or with sham. As schedule of immunization, anesthetized mice received weekly 10 lL of each dose or sham for a period of 1 month and afterwards were sacrificed. The splenocytes were isolated and cultured with a positive control (phytohemagglutinin), V132, sham and culture medium. The proliferation of the splenocytes was measured with Carboxy Fluorescein Succinimidyl Ester (CFSE) after 6 days. Cytokine levels (IFN-c, IL-17 and IL-10) in supernatants were quantified after 48 hours using the Cytometric Bead Array. The proliferative response was higher in mice immunized with the concentration of 10 9 organisms/mL. This proliferation was significantly higher than the one induced by the sham group in response to the specific V132 stimulus (P<.05). The production of IFN-c, IL-17 and IL-10 was dose dependent. Levels of IFN-c, IL-17 and IL-10 were significantly higher in the supernatants from group 1 splenocytes in response to V132 (P<.05) than in the control group. Levels of IFN-c, IL-17 and IL-10 were higher in group 2 splenocytes than in the control group but only reached statistical significance for IFN-c (P<.05). The in vitro response of splenocytes to proliferation and secretion of cytokines was specific to the stimulation with V132. Conclusions: In vivo sublingual immunization of mice, using this schedule of immunization with V132, elicits a systemic dose-response with proliferation of splenocytes in response to specific stimuli with a Th1/Th17 lymphocytes polarization and high levels of IL-10. Mast cells play an integral part in the pathology of allergies. Activation of mast cells is dependent on binding of allergen-specific IgE to its high affinity IgE receptor (FceRI). Crosslinking of IgE by allergen results in mast cell activation and release of preformed and newly synthesized mediators. Traditional medicines have shown to inhibit mast cell activation and reduce adverse allergic effects in patients. Traditional medicines are produced from herbs and plants, which contain numerous bioactive components. For example, essential oil components pulegone, eugenol and methyl eugenol have previously been shown to inhibit IgE-mediated degranulation in vitro and/or in vivo. Objectives: This study aimed to compare the efficacy of pulegone, eugenol and methyl eugenol in inhibition of mast cell degranulation and to understand the mechanism of action. Methods: Rat basophilic leukemia (RBL-2H3) cells, primary bone marrow-derived murine mast cells (BMMC) and primary stem cellderived human mast cells (SCHMC) were primed overnight with IgE and incubated with different concentrations of the bioactive essential oil compounds ranging from 0.05 to 1000 lmol/L. The cells were activated with DNP-HSA in case of RBL-2H3 and BMMC or with anti-IgE in SCHMC. Degranulation was determined by beta-hexosaminidase release and western blot analysis was performed to study MAPK/ERK signaling and FceRI localization. Results: Eugenol most effectively reduced mast cell degranulation compared to pulegone and methyl eugenol. Degranulation was inhibited by 42.1AE2.1% (P<.0001) in RBL-2H3 cells, 58.6AE3.2% (P<.0001) in BMMC and 51.4AE1.5% in SCHMC (at 500 lmol/L). Preliminary results show eugenol to inhibit the phosphorylation of several signaling molecules downstream of the FceRI. Furthermore, in IgE-DNP-HSA-activated RBL-2H3 cells, eugenol (1000 lmol/L) preserved the ratio of membrane-localized vs internalized FceRI (0.35AE0.05) compared to medium exposed activated controls (0.56AE0.09) (P<.05), bringing it back to the level of non-activated controls (0.26AE0.05). Conclusions: Eugenol was shown a very effective inhibitor of mast cell degranulation. Eugenol reduced internalization of the FceRI. Eugenol may stabilize the phospholipid membrane of mast cells and hereby reduce FceRI cross-linking. Eugenol may be an interesting component to further study as an oral or topical application to reduce mast cell degranulation in order to alleviate allergic symp-We have previously demonstrated that exposure of mast cells to aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR; a cellular chemical sensor) ligands resulted in reactive oxygen species (ROS)-and calcium (Ca 2+ )-dependent activation of mast cells in vitro and in vivo via, in part, the induction of ER stress response. Sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) is a bioactive lipid mediator that regulates a diverse range of cellular responses, including mast cells. However, whether AhR also controls sphingolipid (SL) homeostasis in mast cells and the underlying mechanisms remain unknown.

FIGREF59.text: Otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, Hangzhou First People's Hospital, Nanjing Medical University, Hangzhou, China Introduction: Allergic rhinitis (AR) is a multiple gene-regulated disease involved in many immune cells such as mast cells and eosinophils, and various inflammatory mediators, and miRNA probably plays a critical regulatory role in its pathogenesis. Therefore, studies on the functions of critical miRNA and its regulatory mechanisms in activated mast cells will lay an important theoretical foundation for our understanding of AR pathogenesis and the development of ther-MiR-125a-3p mimics significantly suppressed b-hexosaminidase release from mast cells treated by anti-DNP IgE and DNP-HAS (P<.05), and inhibited the expression of TNF-a mRNA and IL-13 mRNA determined by qRT-PCR in activated mast cells and secretion of TNF-a and IL-13 determined by ELISA in the supernatant of activated mast cells (P<.05). Conclusions: Upregulation of miR-125a-3p can inhibit IgEmediated degranulation, synthesis and release of inflammatory mediators in activated mast cells. UniLaSalle, Nutrition and Health Department, EGEAL Unit, Beauvais, France; 2 Universit e de Picardie Jules Verne, PERITOX Unit, Amiens, France Introduction: In developed countries, food allergy incidence is increasing. Environmental factors such as transformed food might be incriminated. Infants are more susceptible to these factors because of the immaturity of their immune system. Advanced glycation endproducts (AGE), generated from Maillard reaction which takes place during food processing, are found in the diets of infants. The impact of these contaminants on the development of allergies remains poorly understood. Objectives: In this context, the purpose of this study is to determine if the effect of the Ne-carboxymethyllysine (CML), an AGE present at significant concentration in infant formulas, can alter the CD4+T helper cells (Th) differentiation in vitro. Human naive CD4+CD45RA+ T cells isolated from PBMC were cultured in the presence of activating beads (anti-CD3/CD28) in the absence (negative control Th0) or presence of interleukin-4 (IL-4) (Positive control) and under same conditions in the presence of 10-30-100-300 or 550 lmol/L of CML. Phenotypic analysis of Th2 cells was performed by flow cytometry using specific extracellular (CD4+CD25+) and intracellular markers (IL4+) and by RT-qPCR through the analysis of specific Th cell subsets transcription factors. The expression of RAGE, the receptor of AGE, was also investigated by RT-qPCR. Results: Th cells stimulated or not by IL-4 and cultured in the presence of 300 and 550 lmol/L CML have a two fold greater proliferation than the control condition. The highest dose of CML induces an increase in the production of IL-4 and an overexpression of GATA3 (transcription factor specific for Th2 cells) and RAGE in Th cells activated by IL-4 compared to the controls. Transforming growth factor-b1 (TGF-b1) and interleukin-10 (IL-10) are cytokines defined by their ability to suppress pathological immune responses in the settings of allergy and inflammatory diseases. The regulatory activity of these cytokines is achieved by effects on the cell differentiation state and by the inhibition of cytokines involved in inflammation and allergy, thus playing an important role against the development of immunological disorders. Hence, peptides that mimic the active core of TGF-b1 or IL-10 cytokines could be highly promising candidates for immune modulation.Objectives: In the present study, TGF-b1-and IL-10-like peptides were selected and evaluated for their in vitro and in vivo capabilities of modulating the immune response under inflammatory and allergic conditions.

FIGREF61.text: Introduction: In allergic asthma, a CD4+ T helper 2 (Th2) cell signature dominates the inflammatory response and is amplified in selfenforcing loops. This leaves the host unable to terminate the immune reaction. The cellular and molecular mechanisms stabilizing the Th2 population in the lung are not well understood and raise the need for deeper analysis. Objectives: We aimed to decipher and understand Th2 cell intrinsic post-transcriptional signatures maintaining the allergic inflammatory response in the lung. Results: Murine Th2 cells were isolated from allergic inflamed lung tissue (ovalbumin-induced) via FACS-sorting and subsequently microarray analyses were conducted (mRNA and microRNA). Na€ ıve T cells from sham immunized and treated mice were used as control. Microarray results revealed the differential expression of 137 miR-NAs in ex vivo Th2 chronic cells compared to na€ ıve CD4+ T cells, with the majority of miRNA being downregulated in Th cells. A multi-omics approach was developed, integrating mouse gene and microRNA information and inferring the protein information from the human interactome. In this setting, we considered miRNA targets to have a central role in the network and further ranked the activity of miRNA. The identified top ranked miRNAs were validated in 3 0 -UTR-luciferase assays in HEK293T cells analyzing wild-type and mutated 3 0 -UTR-sequences in vitro. The importance of these miR-NAs in Th2 cell function was proven by introducing inhibitors and/ or mimics which resulted in an alleviated phenotype in mouse Th2 cells in vitro. Conclusions: A new systems immunology tool for the identification and ranking of miRNAs in multi-omics data sets was established and validated. With this approach a miRNA network stabilizing Th2 cells in chronic allergic airway inflammation was identified. Thus, this result may open the opportunity for novel approaches of

Its clinical presentation encompasses non-immediate severe vomiting

FIGREF65.text: 0279 | Cows milk allergy in children: Natural course and factors predicting the prognosis Esenboga S; G€ ur çetinkaya P; Uysal Soyer € O; Sekerel BE; Sahiner ÜM Hacettepe University School of Medicine, Pediatric Allergy Department, Ankara, Turkey Introduction: Cow's milk allergy (CMA) is one of the most frequent food allergies in children. Even though many of the children with CMA begin to tolerate milk by the age of 6 years, in some children CMA may persist throughout the whole life. In this study we aimed to search the prognosis of CMA and the factors that predict the persistence of the disease. Objectives: Children with IgE-mediated CMA who have been followed up at the Pediatric Allergy Clinic of Hacettepe University School of Medicine, between 2002 and 2016 participated in this study. Children were diagnosed as having IgE-mediated CMA when they fulfilled all of the following criteria: Titers of CM sIgE of 0.35 kU/L or higher AND a positive skin prick test result to CM, defined as a wheal 3 mm or larger compared with the negative control AND a consistent and clear-cut history of an early reaction that was unequivocally related to the ingestion of CM. Most of the patients also had an open challenge during diagnosis. All the patients were evaluated with either an open challenge or a double blind placebo controlled challenge for the tolerance of the CM. ABSTRACTS | 233

FIGREF66.text: Food allergy may impair health-related quality of life (HRQL). Predictors of HRQL have been found in greater extent in adults than in children. There are no data on HRQL of children and teenagers with food allergies in Slovenia. Objectives: The aims of the study were to identify HRQL of food allergic children and teenagers and to examine clinical usefulness of exploring HRQL and food allergy independent measure (FAIM). 69 children were examined (21 girls, 48 boys, mean age 8.4 with SD 3.85 years). Eight adolescents completed Food Allergy Quality of Life Questionnaire (FAQLQ)-Teenager Form, 20 children FAQLQ-Child Form and 42 parents Parent Form of FAQLQ. A questionnaire assessing HRQL of a child/teenager in kindergarten/school (9 items)was also developed and applied. The FAQLQ and FAIM scores were the sum of item scores divided by the number of completed items (ranging from 1-minimal impairment to 7-maximal impairment).

FIGREF68.text: Studies suggest that skin symptoms are an important health problem in hospital employees.

FIGREF69.text: As a part of more comprehensive project, this cross-sectional study included 180 workers (40 surgeons, 40 surgery nurses, 30 physicians non-surgeons, 30 non-surgery nurses, and 40 office workers) employed in surgery clinic (mean age 43.3AE9.7 years, mean hospital tenure 185.2AE128.1 months). Evaluation of examined subjects included completion of a questionnaire on current health problems (including skin symptoms in the last 12 months), Maslach Burnout Inventory, and latex-specific IgE determination.

FIGREF70.text: In the past decade the American College of Occupational and Environmental Medicine (ACOEM) recognized the central role of spirometry in workplace and since this statement was published, ACOEM and the American Thoracic Society (ATS) issued a series of important changes on standardization of lung function testing in occupational settings. Longitudinal evaluations of periodic spirometry testing may detect excessive lung function loss due to an exposure or underlying condition earlier than using a single spirometry test. Workplace exposures associated with accelerated decline in lung function include mineral dusts, silica, metals, but also organic materials and butter flavorings which may act with an immune mediated mechanism.

Multivariable linear and logistic regression was used to estimate the effect of fish production work on lung function and prevalence of respiratory symptoms.

Differentiation between these 2 types of WRA may be difficult, they can coexist too. Inhalant occupational exposure to various agents may modify the clinical course of asthma among workers.Objectives: To characterise airways reaction in WRA after specific inhalation challenge (SIC) carried out in clinical conditions with high (HMW-A) and low molecular weight agents (LMW-A).

Concurrent handling of different enzymes could pose an additive or a synergistic risk of sensitization depending on immunogenic or additional adjuvant properties.Objectives: An opportunity to study this is provided by occupational health sensitization data in subpopulations of employees working with different enzyme combinations under different levels of exposure, ie various departments and work operations and pro-

FIGREF75.text: A group of 98 children aged from 3 months to 3 years with AD were evaluated for evidence of IgE-mediated sensitization by skin prick tests (SPT) and/or measurement of serum specific IgE antibodies. The inclusion criteria to the investigated group was a clinical diagnosis of AD by the Hanifin and Rajka criteria and the positive results of SPT (wheal>3mm) and/or the presence of serum specific IgE antibodies to two and more allergens (sIgE>0.7 IU/mL). The control group consisted of children with symptoms of AD and monovalent IgE-sensitization. The severity of AD was measured by SCORAD scale. The value of peripheral blood eosinophilia and prevalence of other than skin symptoms were compared between groups. Polyvalent IgE-mediated allergy was confirmed in 46.3% of children. Statistically significant differences were found with regard to the prevalence of allergic symptoms from gastrointestinal and respiratory tract (14.29% vs 8.33%; P<.001) and the value of SCORAD (62.95AE16.71 vs 56.62AE18.31; P<.001) and peripheral blood eosinophilia (7.6AE3.81 vs 5.46AE3.05; P=.044) between the study and control group.

FIGREF76.text: Korean institute of Drug Safety and Risk Management (KIDS) detect and evaluate signals from cumulated data and generate and provide drug safety information. The Korea Adverse Events Reporting System (KAERS) is a Korean drug monitoring system which is compatible with the international standards WHO-Uppsala Monitoring Centre.Objectives: The purpose of this study was to characterize a case series of ADR in Korean children by using the KAERS in KIDS. We retrospectively reviewed all ADRs in KAERS database from Jan 2012 to Dec 2013 considering children under 18 years of age. The cases that were assessed as 'unlikely', 'unclassified' or 'unassessable' were excluded.
