Age under 1 year of age were in the highest proportion of reported ADRs and this can be considered that most of national vaccination program takes place during the first year of age. Further studies and yearly analyses are needed to better characterize the pediatric ADRs. 0308 | Assessment of the results of the drug provocation tests in children with history of multiple drug allergies 's Hematology Oncology Training and Research Hospital, Department of Pediatric Allergy and Immunology, Ankara, Turkey; 2 Mugla Sitki Kocman University, Faculty of Medicine, Department of Pediatric Allergy and Immunology, Mugla, Turkey

FIGREF78.text: Introduction: Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID) is a primary antibody defect characterized by high susceptibility to sino-pulmonary infections, requiring a long-life immunoglobulin(IG)    replacement therapy to reduce infective manifestations. Despite IG therapy CVID patients frequently develop chronic damage, autoimmunity, granulomatous inflammation, lymphoproliferative disorders, and malignancies, that affect Health Related Quality of Life (HRQoL).Generic instrument to asses HRQoL has been used to compare general population or chronic diseases to CVID. Recently, the first CVID-specific tool, the CVID_QoL questionnaire, has been validated with the purpose to catch the detailed impact of the disease onHRQoL. The instrument includes three dimensions: Emotional Functioning (EF), Relational Functioning (RF) and Gastrointestinal and Skin Symptoms (GSS).Objectives: Here we use the CVID_QoL questionnaire to quantify the impact of clinical manifestations, immunological characteristics and therapy schedule on HRQoL in a large cohort of CVID adults.Results: One hundred fifty-four CVID from Referral Center for Primary Immunodeficiency of Rome completed the CVID_QoL.Immunoglobulin route of administration, therapy setting, clinical and immunological data were collected from medical files. CVID_QoL, EF and RF scales correlated with age. The duration of disease did not influence HRQoL. No difference were observed between patients receiving SCIG and IVIG; no correlation was found between IgG trough level or Ig serum level at diagnosis and CVID_QoL scores. Being female, underweight, admitted in hospital, having a previous diagnosis of cancer or chronic comorbidities, taking polymedication and having an unexplained persistent enteropathy proved to be major risk factors associated with a poor health status. In particular, females had severe scores in the emotional dimension, while relational and symptoms dimension scores were similar in men and women. The number of infection correlated with a poorer HRQoL status. The experience of pneumonia, relapsing episodes of diarrhea (>4 for year), sinusitis and bronchitis (>2 for year) was associate to more severe CVID_QoL scores.Conclusions:The study provides the impact of immunological, clinical and therapy-related factors assessed by CVID_QoL on the burden of disease in adults patient with CVID. Primary antibody deficiency (PAD) are characterized by increased susceptibility to infections. Early diagnosis and treatment reduce morbidity and mortality. The replacement therapy with immunoglobulin reduces the risk of acute respiratory infections, but has low efficacy to reduce chronic lung complications that represent the principal morbidity factor. Patients with primary immunodeficiencies who have respiratory infections and develop lung damage may take advantage of a more aggressive therapeutic strategy: antibiotic prophylaxis of infectious episodes and cycles of respiratory rehabilitation. At now, data on antibiotic prophylaxis are uncertain. Objectives: We conducted a multi-center (7 adult and paediatric centers) randomized placebo-controlled double-blind trial on 89 patients (age 12-74) with PAD (X-linked agammaglobulinemia or Common variable Immunodeficiency) and COPD with recurrent exacerbations. All patients had COPD confirmed by spirometry. Written informed consent was obtained. The aim of the study was to evaluate efficacy and safety of low-dose of azithromycin (250 mg 3 times for week for 3 consecutive days) for 24 months vs placebo. In patients under azithromycin prophylaxis we expect a decrease of acute COPD exacerbations (reduction of dyspnea, cough, sputum volume and purulence), no use of additional antibiotics, an increase of respiratory volumes (FEV1), an improvement of the Health Related Quality of Life measures. Results: The study started on June 2014 and has been lasted 30 months (24 months of therapy, 6 months of follow-up). Monthly we evaluate: lung function by FEV1 and St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire, sputum sample for microbiological assessment, routine and immunological blood test, diary card for use of additional antibioticsTo our knowledge our study is the first one on antibiotic prophylaxis in patients affected by primary antibody deficiencies. 0311 | IgM and IgA anti-pneumococcal capsular polysaccharides as prognostic tool for common variable immunodeficiency: A longitudinal study Pulvirenti F; Cavaliere MF; Milito C; Carello R; Pesce AM; Quinti I Department of Molecular Medicine, Sapienza University, Rome, Italy Introduction: The clinical spectrum of CVID ranges from a poorly symptomatic form to severe phenotypes characterized by high susceptibility to infections, autoimmunity, granulomatous inflammation, lymphoproliferative disorders, and malignancies. Due to high prognosis heterogeneity, prognostic factors are required. Objectives: With the aim to identify additional prognostic factors, we evaluated the anti-polysaccharide IgA and IgM responses by Elisa assay in 75 CVID in a longitudinal study over a 6-year period. Patients were immunized at baseline with the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (Pneumovax ® ). Twenty healthy donors (HD) were also included. Results: As expected, CVID patient had lower IgM/IgA response than HD. For CVID, four immunological phenotypes were identified by post-vaccination IgM and IgA levels: IgM/IgA responders (16%), IgM-only responders (21%) and non-responders (63%). During the follow up, concomitant CVID-related conditions, immunoglobulin serum levels, respiratory infections and outcome were recorded by medical files. CVID non-responders and IgM-only responders developed more frequently respiratory infections, gastro enteric symp-

FIGREF79.text: In conclusion, even if patients could not raise the protective humoral level, in CVID the anti-polysaccharide IgA and IgM responses could represent a prognostic factor, individuating groups of patients with less immunological impairment, lower risk of comorbidities and better survival. 0312 | Subcutaneous ig replacement therapy in primary and secondary hypogammaglobulinemia: A retrospective single centre study of 203 patients Cinetto F; Scarpa R; Neri R; Rizzo F; Compagno N; Agostini C Department of Medicine-DIMED, University of Padova, Padova, Italy Introduction: Intravenous (IVIg) or subcutaneous (SCIg) immunoglobulin (Ig) replacement therapy represents the standard of care for primary Ig deficiencies (PID). IVIg are widely used in hypogammaglobulinemia secondary to B-CLL and Multiple Myeloma (MM). SCIg represent an effective, safe and well-tolerated treatment approach in PID, but no extensive data are available on their use in secondary hypogammaglobulinemia (SID). In particular, limited data are available on their use in hypogammaglobulinemia occurring after anti-CD20 treatment in Non-Hodgkin Lymphomas (NHL), as well as in immune-mediated disorders. Objectives: In this retrospective, single center study we evaluated efficacy and safety of SCIg treatment (>6 months) in a cohort of 203 patients with PID and SID. Serum IgG trough levels, SCIg dosage and infusion schedule, adverse events and infection rate were compared between PID and SID. A subgroup analysis on health-related QoL parameters was performed, by using TSQM and SF-36 questionnaires. Different SCIg formulations (16%, 16.5%, 20%, 10% facilitated) were used. Results: PID patients (n=79) presented CVID (69), Agammaglobulinemia (2) and IgG subclass deficiency (8). SID patients included 38 NHL, 55 B-CLL, 19 MM and 12 patients with immune-mediated disorders. Mean age was 48.2AE11.6 for PID and 69AE11.5 for SID. Mean duration of SCIg treatment was 33.5AE19.5 months (range 7-120 months; 44.1AE23.5 in PID, 26.7AE12.3 in SID). In both groups, SCIg appeared to be effective in replacing Ig deficiency and reducing the infection rate; similar IgG trough levels and QoL results were achieved. A low number of adverse events, mainly local, was registered, with no serious adverse events. Of note, SCIg monthly dosage was significantly lower in SID (315AE64.7 mg/Kg) than in PID (358AE105 mg/Kg) (P<.01). Moreover, SID patients used longer

FIGREF80.text: University, Pediatric Clinic, University Hospital Alexandrovska, Sofia, Bulgaria; 2 Medical University, Laboratory of Clinical Immunology, University Hospital Alexandrovska, Sofia, Bulgaria Introduction: Damage to the lungs in immune deficiency is common and may be the first manifestation, referring to the diagnosis. In addition to general patterns of pulmonary manifestations in immunodeficiencies (due to acute or chronic pulmonary infections), there are differences in the clinical course depending on the type of immune defect. For example, in selective Ig A deficiency (SIgAD) occur normally manifestations of bronchial obstruction, as well as in patients with Bruton's disease or common variable immunodeficiency (CVID). Objectives: A cross-sectional study evaluating immunology status in 22 children referred to the clinic due to difficult to treat asthma and their follow up for a period of 1 year. For all patients detailed asthma history, treatment regimen, clinical indices, pulmonary function tests (PFT), bronhodilator response were performed. We drew blood for evaluating humoral and cellular immunity. Results: The results of our study revealed 8 children with CVID, 3 children with (SIgAD), 5 children with deficiency in IgG subclasses. In the rest 7 children no immunological problems were identified; however there were therapy compliance mistakes. We modified the therapy in all children with favorable results one year after establishing the diagnosis/problem. Conclusions: In children with difficult to treat asthma a possible primary immunodeficiency (PID) should be looked for and if diagnosed treated. With improved diagnostic methods and therapeutic options the length and quality of life in patients with PID is considerably extended. Mastery of pulmonary manifestations is essential for their prognosis.

FIGREF81.text: Primary antibody deficiencies (PADs) are genetic diseases characterized by impaired antibodies production, such as common variable immunodeficiency (CVID), immunoglobulin A deficiency, and IgG subclass deficiency. Rarely PADs are associated with complex autoimmune disorders, such as neurological diseases.Objectives: We describe three cases of women with PADs and concurrent myelopathy. The first patient (71 years old) came to our attention for sensory ataxia, paraparesis and dysesthesia of the lower limbs, weakness of the right hand and neurogenic bladder. The second one (57 years old) presented with atasso-spastic gait, tetra-hyperre-flexia and difficulty in emptying the bladder. A laboratory evaluation showed in both cases decreased serum levels of all immunoglobulin isotypes and low specific antibody responses. In their past history both patients reported recurrent infections, thus allowing the diagnosis of CVID. The last patient (43 years old) had a history of post-traumatic panniculitis since 2010 with lymphedema and elephantiasis of forearm. She developed frequent infections of subcutaneous tissue, often followed by systemic complications and need of hospitalization. An acute respiratory failure supported by H. influenzae type B infection was followed by a post-infectious acute myelitis with residual paraparesis and neurogenic bladder. The presence of severe recurrent infections in a subject with no others obvious causes led us to undertake an immunological research which detected an isolated deficit with decreased serum levels of IgG3 (170 mg/ l). Results: All patients received high dose of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) 2 g/Kg/month. After three months the first and third patient, were switched to 20% subcutaneous immunoglobulin (20% SCIg); the second patient maintains IVIg therapy at dose of 30g/month. At three years follow-up, the response to treatment was good and no relapses occurred. Conclusions: There have been few reports on neurological autoimmune disorders associated with PADs of the adult. The use of immunoglobulin as replacement therapy of the PAD seems also to be effective in protecting the recurrence of such manifestations. , Hospital de Santa Maria (HSM), Centro Hospitalar Lisboa Norte EPE, Immunoallergology Unit, Hospital Dr. N elio Mendonça, SESARAM, EPE, Funchal, Lisbon, Portugal; 2 Immunoallergology Department, Hospital de Santa Maria (HSM), Centro Hospitalar Lisboa Norte EPE, Primary Immunodeficiencies Center, Lisbon (HSM/FMUL/IMM), Lisbon, Portugal; 3 Immunoallergology Department, Hospital de Santa Maria (HSM), Centro Hospitalar Lisboa Norte EPE, Lisbon, Portugal; 4 Immunoallergology Department, Hospital de Santa Maria (HSM), Centro Hospitalar Lisboa Norte EPE, University Clinic of Immunoallergology, Faculty of Medicine of University of Lisbon (FMUL), Lisbon, Portugal Case Report: Introduction: X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA) is a primary immunodeficiency caused by mutations in Bruton Tyrosine Kinase (BTK). XLA-patients present with recurrent bacterial infections, mainly affecting respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts; although cellulitis, arthritis, meningitis and sepsis have also been reported. The authors describe the association of cellulitis, with bacteremia by Campylobacter jejuni and recurrent identification of Campylobacter in stool cultures, in a young adult with XLA.Case report: 22-year-old male with XLA diagnosis since 16 months-old, under subcutaneous IgG replacement therapy. In August 2016, the patient noticed a copper-erythematous area on the anterior surface of the right leg, with increased heat, pain and edema, but no skin erosion. Ultrasound-doppler revealed increased thickness and echogenicity of the subcutaneous lipomatous tissue, suggestive of phlebitis, negative for deep vein thrombosis. Laboratory workup revealed high C-reactive protein (7.45mg/dL) and serum IgG 756 mg/dL. Blood cultures were negative. He was treated with oral flucloxacillin (1g 6/6h). Increase of inflammatory signs in the limb was noticed, and maintained despite increase in flucloxacillin (1.5g 6/6h).

FIGREF82.text: Allergy and Clinical Immunology, Rasoul-e-Akram Hospital, Iran University of Medical Sciences, Tehran, Iran; 5 Vali-e-Asr Hospital, Tehran University of Medical Sciences, Tehran, Iran Introduction: Hyper IgM Syndrome (HIGM) is a rare primary immunodeficiency in which impairment of immunoglobulin class switching leads to normal or increased levels of serum IgM and lowto-undetectable levels of all other immunoglobulin isotypes. So far five genes, CD40L, AID, CD40, UNG and NEMO, have been identified to be involved in HIGM. The aim of this study is to report genetic results of five HIGM patients, confirmed by genetic studies. Objectives: Ten patients (7 males and 3 females) with presumed HIGM, who referred to Immunology, Asthma and Allergy Research Institute (IAARI) between 2006 to 2016, were entered the study based on two criteria; clinical features such as recurrent and severe infections in different organs besides the immunoglobulin profile including normal or elevated levels of serum IgM and low levels of IgG, IgA and IgE. The patients were examined for the presence of mutations in CD40L, AID and CD40 genes respectively. After genomic DNA was extracted from whole blood samples, PCR test was done and followed by direct sequencing of the products. Sequencing results were analyzed by Finch TV.Results: From ten patients who entered the study, genetic defects of five patients were; three reported mutations in CD40L including a missense mutation (p.G198R), two frameshift deletions (p.F31fsX5 and p.D62fsX18) both resulting in early stop codon several bases downstream, and a reported nonsense mutation (p.E122X) in AID.Also a mutation in UTR (c. À1T>C) of CD40 which results in decreased expression of CD40 protein.

FIGREF83.text: UNC13D gene checked out. Primers were designed for exon and exonintron regions of UNC13D gene. Having extracted genomic DNA from parents' whole blood samples and chorionic villus samples (CVS) in the 12 th week pregnancy, PCR technique was done and followed by direct sequencing of the products. Finally sequencing results were analyzed. Results: Genetic analysis of UNC13D gene in the parents revealed a delins mutation (c.1444_1457ACCCATGGTGCAdelinsTGGTGC) in heterozygous status in exon 16 of UNC13D gene, leading to deletion of 5 amino acids (Gln, Pro, Met, Val and Gln) and insertion of 3 amino acids (His, Gln and Ala) in the protein. The mutation was also detected in the fetus as homozygous.

FIGREF85.text: College London, London, United Kingdom; 2 University College Cork, Cork, Ireland Introduction: Health-related quality of life (HRQL) is significantly impaired in food allergy, in both patients and their parents. The experience of an in-hospital food challenge (FC), whether positive or negative, can improve HRQL. However, FC may result in anaphylaxis, requiring treatment with injected adrenaline which might impact negatively upon HRQL. Objectives: We compared HRQL measures before and after FC in children who experienced anaphylaxis (treated with self-administered adrenaline), and matched controls who experienced less severe reactions. Double-blind, placebo-controlled FC to peanut were conducted in children enrolling in an oral immunotherapy trial (BOPI study, Clini-calTrials.gov Identifier: NCT02149719). Validated questionnaires (FAQLQ, FAIM, Self-Efficacy) were completed prior to FC and approximately one month later, by both the young person themselves and the parent. Local ethical and regulatory approval was granted, and informed consent was obtained.Results: Twenty-eight children (age range: 8-15 years, 64% males) undergoing FC were included in the analysis: 14 had anaphylaxis (respiratory symptoms) during FC and self-administered adrenaline; these individuals were matched for age/sex with 14 children who had mild reactions only.Across the cohort, children reported improved HRQL and self-efficacy (P<.05) following FC, with no statistically significant differences between the group where the child self-administered adrenaline, and those having mild reactions only. Likewise, parental assessment of HRQL in their child, and their assessment of their child's ability to self-manage their food allergy, also improved (P<.05), with no adverse impact of anaphylaxis.Interestingly, parents reported improved HRQL in themselves significantly greater than that perceived by them in their child (P<.01), or reported by the child themselves (P<.05).

FIGREF86.text: Barni S; Mori F; Sarti L; Pucci N; Belli F; Novembre E Anna Meyer Children Hospital, Florence, Italy Introduction: Food protein-induced enterocolitis syndrome (FPIES) is a non-IgE-mediated food hypersensitivity that is characterized Children with suspected CM-FPIES underwent oral provocation test (OPT) according to Leonard SA protocol in a hospital setting with emergency facilities available. Prick by Prick (PbP) with CM, SM, casein-based extensively hydrolyzed formula (eHF), DM and goat's milk (GM) were performed according to the European Academy of Allergy and Clinical Immunology (EAACI) recommendations. Tolerance towards DM, SM and eHF was also checked. Results: CM-FPIES was made in ten out of ten patients and all children tolerated DM. PbP with CM, SM and eHF were negative except one child with positive SPT to CM (atypical FPIES). Most of the children also tolerated soy milk (SM) and eHF was a safe, but not palatable, alternative. Conclusions: Among mammalian milk products, we showed that donkey's milk is a safe and well-tolerated alternative in ten children with cow's milk FPIES. Our results should be confirmed in a higher number of CM-FPIES. 0323 | Donkey's milk tolerability and palatability in cow's milk allergic children Barni S; Sarti L; Mori F; Pucci N; Belli F; Novembre E Anna Meyer Children Hospital, Florence, Italy Introduction: Cow's milk allergy (CMA) is the most common food allergy affecting 2-3% of children. The alternative formulations proposed by international guidelines often have low palatability, resulting untasteful. Donkey's milk (DM) is well-tolerated milk and thanks to its palatability is well accepted. We assess the tolerability and palatability of DM in children with CMA. Objectives: From January 2015 to January 2016, 51 children with clinical history of CMA and positive skin prick test (SPT) and/or serum specific IgE (s-IgE) to CM were studied. SPT and s-IgE to CM, casein, a-lactalbumin, b-lactoglobulin and DM were performed. DM tolerance was tested by oral provocation test (OPT). In children≥3 years of age, DM palatability was assessed through a liking scale. We used the Wong-Baker modified pain scale [6 faces with different expression (from smiling to crying face) corresponding to different degrees of taste (delicious, good, normal, not good, bad taste, disgusting)].

FIGREF87.text: The systematic literature search was made from the international Medline-Ovid database and the Finnish Medic-database. From the medline-database the search was made in two parts. The search term in MeSH search was milk hypersensitivity/dh (diet therapy) or (milk hypersensitivity and diet) or (milk hypersensitivity and (child nutritional physiological phenomena or malnutrition)). The search term in the keyword search was milk hypersensitivity or milk allerg* and the search was limited to years 2014-2015. The search was verified 11.4.2016 by doing the MeSH and the keyword search again limiting the result to years 2015-2016.

FIGREF88.text: Cow's milk proteins allergy (CMPA) is the most common food allergy in childhood with a significant impact on daily routine of children and their caregivers. In children with CMPA, successful oral immunotherapy (OIT) protocols have been described. However, the underneath immunological mechanisms allowing tolerance remains unclear. Regulatory T cells (Treg) are known for mediating tolerance and immune suppression, and their dysfunction has been already related to CMPA. Objectives: We aim to evaluate the immune profile of children after OIT, and compare it to healthy controls.Methods: 28 children with CMPA after successful milk-OIT and healthy controls have been recruited. Immune profile was evaluated

FIGREF89.text: A total of 234 patients have been diagnosed of drug allergy from 2009 to 2016 in our outpatients clinic. Out of them, 69 have been confirmed as having hypersensitivity to NSAIDs. 49 women and 20 men with a mean age of 52 y.o. 33 patients were allergic to pyrazolones, 27 patients were diagnosed of hypersensitivity to Aspirin; 8 aril-propionic allergic patients, 2 aril-acetic allergic patients and 1 COX-2 inhibitor allergic patient. 15.7% had hyperuricemia and of them only 2 have been diagnosed of AERD. Out of the 10 patients with hypersensitivity to NSAIDs and hyperuricemia: 3 suffered anaphylaxis, 5 urticaria and angioedema, 3 urticaria due to NSAIDs. Besides 3 patients with hyperuricemia showed aeroallergen sensitization (out of 18 who showed any sensitization). Only 2 patients had a confirmed diagnosis of nasal polyps and none of them showed hyperuricemia. 9 patients have been diagnosed of bronchial asthma, but only one showed an increase in uricemia. 15 patients had suffered and anaphylactic reaction after NSAIDs intake, showing a mean uricemia of 4.76 and the mean uricemia of the whole NSAIDs allergic population was 4.85.

FIGREF90.text: In Ukraine during 2015-2016 a government endorsed methodology for assessment of patients with drug hypersensitivity based on international guidelines (EAACI, WAO) was adopted standardizing a national unified clinical protocol for "Drug Allergy and Hypersensitivity". As the first step the prevalence and the management of drug hypersensitivity reactions to local anesthetics in Ukraine was assessed by survey. Objectives: 272 physicians who provided local anesthesia were selected as responders from West, Central and East parts of Ukraine. The number of local anesthetic procedures performed per week were: up to 5 in 38.23%, 5-10 in 10.29%, 10-15 in 16.54%, 15-20 in 14.7%, 20-25 in 17.64%, 25-30 in 10.66% and more than 30 in 9.55%. Results: Physicians used regional (85.66%), infiltrative (85.29%), spinal (74.63%), surface (68.38%) and epidural/peridural (49.26%) anesthesias. The most used preparations were articaine (229 responders), lidocaine (195), procaine (146), bupivacaine (141), mepivacaine (132), proparacaine (112), and bimecaine (101

FIGREF91.text: Multiple NSAID-induced skin manifestations are entities well differentiated from aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), although no detailed phenotype analysis has yet been performed. Objectives: Was to evaluate the characteristics of NSAID allergy with cutaneous manifestations by analyzing the response to nasal lysine-aspirin (L-ASA) challenge and measurement of nasal inflammation compared with AERD subjects and controls. The study included 67 subjects with confirmed hypersensitivity to NSAID. Five groups were formed: acute urticaria (NSAID-AU n14), chronic urticaria (NSAID-CU n14), palpebral angioedema and dust mites allergy (NSAID-PA n14), respiratory manifestations (AERD n14), and healthy controls (HC n11). Nasal measurement at 0, 15, 30, 60, 90 and 120 minutes after L-ASA challenge were analyzed for clinical manifestation with acoustic rhinometer, symptoms scores and visual analogue score (VAS). The challenge test was considered positive when nasal permeability decreases >25% from basal values. Results: Through the measurement of nasal permeability L-ASA challenge was positive in 38.5% of the cases. Of them 37.5% of the NSAID-PA and 37.5% of AERD were positive, while only 12.5% in NSAID-AU and NSAID-UC. In all HC were negative. The mean values for decreased nasal permeability in the different clinical phenotypes shows significant differences between: NSAID-CU (16.9%) and NSAID-PA (28%)/ AERD (36.1%) (P=.043 and P=.004 respectively), also between NSAID-AU (18.5%) and AERD (36.1%) (P=.01), finally between NSAID-PA and AERD / HC (11.7%) (P=.003 and P=.000). A look at the total scores of symptoms during the nasal challenge from baseline to 120 minutes in the groups, showed differences al 30 minutes, between: NSAID-CU and AERD (5.5mm) (P=.004), NSAID-AU (1.79mm) and NSAID-PA (3.43mm) (P=.02), finally NSAID-AU and AERD (P=.002).

FIGREF93.text: were early-type, and the suspected drugs in history were pain killers in 20%, antibiotics in 75%, and both in 5%.OPT  resulted positive in 8 patients whom all complained about respiratory symptoms in previous drug reactions. Patients of asthma was well controlled before the test (OPT positive: n=7, negative: n=5). OPT positive group had higher post-test symptom scores, and lower PEF values than OPT negatives. In group comparison, although FeNO values of OPT positives were higher than negatives in all steps (all P<.05), nNO values were similar between them. In pre and post test comparison, the only change in FeNO was a decrease in OPT positives, and an increase in negative group after 1 st hour of OPT (both P>.0.5). On the other hand, there was an insignificant decrease in nNO levels of OPT positive group, and increase in OPT negative group which both returned to basal values after 24 th hour. Decrease in nNO was significant at 4 th hour of OPT in OPT positive group (P=.004).

FIGREF94.text: A total of 898 patients were included: 126 (14.03%) NERD, 511 (56.9%) NIUA and 261 (29.06%) blended reactions. The percentage of patients having underlying rhinitis (P<.0001), asthma (P<.0001) and polyposis (P=.006) were higher in NERD compared to blended and NIUA and, although no significant, the percentage of atopy was higher in blended and NIUA compared to NERD. The onset of the reaction after NSAID intake was 45 minutes (IR: 20-120), being this interval shorter in blended and NERD compared to NIUA (P=.005213). A total of 100 (79.36%) NERD patients and 201 blended (76.42%) were confirmed by NPT-LASA. Conclusions: Patients developing blended reactions to NSAIDs showed an overlap of clinical characteristics of NERD and NIUA. Due to the high rate of positive response to NPT-LASA, patients with blended reactions should be evaluated firstly using NPT-LASA, being safer than oral DPT.

FIGREF95.text: Blanca-López N; P erez-Alzate D; Somoza ML; Ruano FJ; Haroun E; Vazquez De La Torre M; Garcimartin MI; Blanca M; Canto G Infanta Leonor University Hospital, Madrid, Spain Introduction: Although hypersensitivity reactions to NSAIDs are the most common cause of hypersensitivity drug reactions, no studies have been carried out focusing on populations stratified by age.Previous studies indicate that certain manifestations like facial angioedema are more frequently observed in children with asthma induced by NSAIDs being rather infrequent. Our aim was to compare a group of children with confirmed NSAIDs hypersensitivity vs a group of adolescents.

FIGREF96.text: of pediatric adverse drug reactions (ADRs) in Korea: Using big data of 48.1 million South Korean health-care records and KAERS (Korea adverse event reporting systemThe prevalence of adverse drug reactions (ADRs) has been increasing worldwide for the past few decades. ADRs is a important in pediatric patients. However, studies on the prevalence of ADRs in children are rare. The aim of this study was to estimate the prevalence of ADRs in Korea. Objectives: To investigate the prevalence of ADRs, we analyzed the nationwide database (National Health Insurance Corporation Records and KAERS database) which included the health-care records of 48.1 million individuals and nationwide ADR reporting systems between January 1, 2009, and December 31, 2015. Results: There was a tendency of increasing prevalence of ADRs in Korea: 0.19% (2009), 0.20% (2010), 0.21% (2011), 0.26% (2012), 0.28% (2013), 0.29% (2014), and 0.32% (2015). Moreover, there has been a pattern of increasing number of pediatric ADRs in Korea; 9094 (2009), 9791 (2010), 10 399 (2011), 13 002 (2012), 13 839 (2013), 14 633 (2014), and 16 000 (2015). In 2015, there were 6036 male and 9964 female pediatric patients of which; 7998 were under 2 years old, 4985 were aged 3~6, 638 were aged 7~12, 2397 were aged 13~19 years old. Antibiotics were the most common causative drugs followed by anti-inflammatory agents (NSAIDs).

FIGREF97.text: The development of toxoallergic reactions to different medicines still remain a very important clinical problem. Objectives: To present the results of a one year retrospective study of toxoallergic reactions, caused by medicines in patients admitted to Toxicology Clinic /adults / of Emergency University Hospital "N.I. Pirogov", Sofia, Bulgaria. The records of Toxicology Clinic were reviewed retrospectively for all hospitalized patients due to toxoallergic reactions, caused by medicines, during a one year period-from January 1, 2016 to December 31, 2016. The methods used were: clinical observation and examination and laboratory investigation including the determination of specific IgG and IgE antibodies to different antibiotics. in 46 patients / 25.00%/. Penicillins were the antibiotics mostcommonly caused toxoallergic reactions in 37 patients/ 42.04%/, followed by lincosamides/ clindamycin/-in 30/ 34.09%/, cephalosporins-in 11/9.68%/quinolones-in 7/7.95%/, others-3/3.40%/. An anaphylactic shock have been observed in 11.41% of the patients/21 cases/. An angioedema-swelling on the face and neck, eyelids, lips, tongue or throat-was seen in 53/ 28.80%/ persons. All of the patients had cutaneous/mucus membrane symptoms.Conclusions: Our data show that the antibiotics are the most common cause of severe toxoallergic reactions in adults. Affected patients should not resort to the use of drugs without prescription by a specialist. The study stress the importance of continuous medi-It is widely known that several arachidonic acid metabolites play important roles in airway inflammation in asthma.Major arachidonic acid metabolites related with asthma pathogenesisin 5-lipoxygenase (LO) and 15-LO pathways are leukotrienes (LTs), 15-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid (HETE), and eoxins. However, there are few studies investigating genetic effects on production of these arachidonic acid metabolites.Objectives: To investigate the genetic effects on production of arachidonic acid metabolites related with asthma pathogenesis.Results: A total of 95 aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) and 94 aspirin tolerant asthma (ATA) patients were enrolled.Serum samples were collected from all of the study subjects whereas urine samples were collected from 45 AERD and 44 ATA patients when the asthma was stable. Serum and urine samples were also collected after the lysine-aspirin bronchoprovocation test (Lys-ASA BPT). The metabolites of LTE 4, 15-HETE and eoxin C 4 were analyzed using the UHPLC/Q-ToF MS system. HLA-DPB1 high-resolution genotyping was obtained from direct sequencing method and polymorphisms of CysLTR1 À634C>T, LTC4S À444A>C, ALOX15 À272C>A and ALOX15 À427 G>A were genotyped using SNaP shot ddNTP primer extension kit. The levels of urine LTE 4 were significantly higher in patients carrying HLA-DPB1*0301 (P=.041), while no differences were found in serum LTE 4 . The asthmatic patients with the TT genotype at CYSLTR1 À634C>T had significantly higher levels of urine LTE 4 (P=.015), but no differences were found in serum LTE 4 levels. The levels of urine and serum 15-HETE were not significantly different according to the genotype of ALOX15 polymorphisms. The levels of urine/ serum LTE 4 and eoxin C 4 were not significantly different according to the genotype of LTC4S polymorphisms. The levels of serum eoxin C 4 in AERD patients with the AA genotype at LTC4S À444A>C were significantly increased after Lys-ASA BPT, while the AERD patients with AC/CC genotype showed no significant changes. The interaction between the TT genotype at CYSLTR1 À634C>T and urine LTE 4 levels had a significant effect on the % fall of FEV 1 after Lys-ASA BPT (P<.001, OR=1.756) analyzed by generalized linear model adjusted with age and gender. Conclusions: HLA-DPB1*0301 and genetic polymorphisms of CysLTR1 À634C>T affect LTE 4 overproduction which can contribute to promote the airway inflammation in AERD. 0355 | The lncRNAs involved in murine airway allergic inflammation following induced pluripotent stem cell-mesenchymal stem cell treatment Wang S; Fan X; Yu Q; Deng M; Sun Y; Gao W; Li C; Si J; Fu Q Otorhinolaryngology Hospital, The First Affiliated Hospital, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, China Introduction: We previously reported that induced pluripotent stem cell-mesenchymal stem cells (iPSC-MSCs) alleviated asthma inflammation in mice. Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) were recently reported as being involved in the immune response. However, whether lncRNAs are associated with iPSC-MSC immunomodulation in allergic inflammation is still unclear. Objectives: We hypothesized that lncRNAs also had important biological functions in airway allergic inflammation and iPSC-MSCmediated immunomodulation. This study aimed to identify aberrantly expressed lncRNA profiles after asthma induction and iPSC-MSC treatment.Results: In vivo study mice were induced into an asthmatic state and received treatment consisting of iPSC-MSCs. In vitro study Memory T cells isolated from sensitized mice were challenged and co-cultured with iPSC-MSCs. iPSC-MSCs significantly prevented asthma inflammation in vivo and decreased the Th2 cytokine levels in vitro. Over 1300 lncRNAs were differentially expressed after the induction of asthma, and 846 or 4176 lncRNAs were differentially expressed with iPSC-MSC treatment in mice or in vitro, respectively. After overlapping the differentially expressed lncRNAs produced in a similar manner in mice and in vitro, 23 lncRNAs and 96 mRNAs were selected, in which 58 protein-coding genes were predicted to be potential targets of the 23 lncRNAs. Furthermore, using a series of bioinformatics technologies, 9 lncRNAs co-expressed with the most differentially expressed mRNAs, which were enriched in terms of the immune response, were screened out via Pearson's correlation coefficient with mRNAs that were involved with inflammatory cytokines and receptors. lncRNAs-MM9LINCRNAEXON12105+ and AK089315 were finally emphasized via qRT-PCR validation.Conclusions: Our results suggested that aberrant lncRNA profiles were present after asthma induction and iPSC-MSC treatment, Allergic rhinitis with asthma is a common allergic reactions and related diseases, with the incidence in the normal population generally higher. In recent years, more and more evidence suggests that the incidence of allergic rhinitis with asthma involves regulations of multiple genes. In this research, through exploring the gene expression profiles of allergic rhinitis with asthma by RNAseq technology, the differences of gene expression profiles was analyzed, providing a research basis on the mechanism of allergic rhinitis with asthma.Objectives: To construct related gene expression profile of allergic rhinitis with asthma and screen the pathogenic genes.Results: Compared AR with asthma group to the control group, there 89 related genes were found and 16 genes were up-regulated, 73 genes were down-regulated. Furthermore, there 17 genes(ADAM33, BCL6, IFNGR2, IL12A, IL12B, IL13RA1, IL17A, IL31, IL4R, IL5, KIT, LTB4R, MS4A2, RORC, STAT5A, STAT6, TBX21) differentially expressed. Compared AR with asthma group to the AR group, there also 89 related genes were found and 1 gene differentially expressed.Conclusions: Using Allergy & Asthma PCR Array, we preliminarily constructed the aberrant gene expression profile of AR with asthma and ADAM33, BCL6, IFNGR2, IL12A, IL12B, IL13RA1, IL17A, IL31, IL4R, IL5, KIT, LTB4R, MS4A2, RORC, STAT5A, STAT6, TBX21 are the possible pathogenic genes of AR with asthma. RORC may be the specific marker gene in asthma induced by allergic rhinitis.

Two outcome measures were studied: hospitalization/emergency room (ER) visits (available in 12 studies, n=4151 patients) and oral corticosteroid (OCS) use (available in 9 studies, n=3512 patients) in the last 6 or 12 months of the study or first year of the trial. Meta-analyses with random effects were performed using an additive genetic model adjusted for age, gender and adjusted British Thoracic Society (BTS) treatment steps. Overall, 1433 patients reported hospitalizations/ER visits and 1274 patients reported OCS use. The SNP was statistically significantly associated with an increased risk of OCS use (OR per increase in variant allele=1.19, 95%CI: 1.02-1.39, P=.03, I 2 =40.78%). Regarding the hospitalization / ER visits, the summary effect estimate pointed in the same direction (OR per increase in variant allele=1.17, 95%CI: 0.96-1.42, P=.1, I 2 =59.44%). Conclusions: Variation in the 17q21 locus contributes to an increased risk of exacerbations despite the use of ICS in children and young adults. Cardiovascular and Diabetes Medicine, University of Dundee, Ninewells Hospital and Medical School, Dundee, United Kingdom; 3 Child Health, University of Aberdeen, Aberdeen, United Kingdom; 4 The Asthma and Allergy Research Group, University of Dundee, Dundee, United Kingdom; 5 Department of Primary Care and Public Health, Brighton & Sussex Medical School, Brighton, United Kingdom Introduction: Asthma is a chronic respiratory disease, characterised by relapse and remission of symptoms. FIGREF99.text: and Fife, Scotland. Through collaboration with the Health Informatics Centre in Dundee, BREATHE was linked to several databases including Accident & Emergency, community prescribing and Scottish Morbidity Records (hospital admissions). This linkage allows exploration of associations between genetic variation and prescribing. Data between 2005 and 2013 were analysed using random effects generalised linear models.Results: The analysis was performed on 1008 individuals (mean age of 10 in 2005). At the end of the 9-year period, 505 individuals had been prescribed ≥1 course of prednisolone, 388 had been prescribed ≥1 long-acting b 2 -agonist combined with corticosteroids and 304 had been prescribed ≥1 anti-leukotriene antagonists. Over the 9-year period, a significant association was found between individuals homozygous for the Arg16 variant and the prescribing of prednisolone (Gly/Arg vs Arg/Arg-Incidence Rate Ratio (IRR): 1.54, 95% CI: 1.06-2.25; Gly/Gly vs Arg/Arg-IRR: 1.64, 95% CI: 1.12-2.42). A significant association was also found between the Arg16 variant and prescribing of anti-leukotriene antagonists (Gly/Gly vs Arg/Arg -IRR: 2.33, 95% CI: 1.06-5.13) and a combination of long-acting b 2agonist and corticosteroids (Gly/Arg vs Arg/Arg-IRR: 2.80, 95% CI:1.35-5.81; Gly/Gly vs Arg/Arg-IRR: 3.15, 95% CI: 1.50-6.63). No statistical difference was found in the risk of asthma-related hospital admissions.

Considering the wild variant CTCT as value 1, the CCCC showed 1.40AE0.08) (P=.02). We compared the cytokine production of A549 transfected cells among the different PTGDR haplotypic variant CTCT, CCCC and control cells. Culture supernatant levels of IL-4, IL-6, IL-7, IL-8, and TNF-a in A549 transfected cells were significantly higher compared with control cells (P<.05). Conclusions: We detect an increase of the Th2 cytokine IL-4, the pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-6, IL-8 and TNF-a and the B-cell maturation factor IL-7, in both CTCT-and CCCC-PTGDR transfected cells supporting the role of PTGDR in the cytokine response of cells. 0360 | C-159t polymorphism of the CD14 gene in adult patients with fixed and reversible airflow obstructive asthma in Crimea, Ukraine Medical University, Kyiv, Ukraine; 2 The University of Auckland, Auckland, New Zealand; 3 Immunology Research Institute of New England, George Washington University School of Medicine, Gardner, United States Introduction: The CD14 gene is located on chromosome 5q31-32, which is a critical region for asthma. The association of the CD14 C-159T SNP and sputum levels of sCD14 in fixed/reversible airflow obstructive asthma patients has not been characterized. Objectives: The C-159T polymorphism of CD14 receptor gene was studied in 151 patients with fixed and 180 reversible asthma. The degree of obstruction was determined by the post-bronchodilator ratio of FEV1 / FVC. The fixed obstruction phenotype had a ratio of FEV1 / FVC<0.7 (70%) whereas reversible was >0.7. The control group included 285 non-atopic volunteers. In the control group, the frequency distribution of genotypes (CC-97, CT-146, TT-42) was not significantly different from asthma with fixed (CC-52, CT-77, TT-22, v 2 =0.01, P=.99) and reversible airflow obstruction (CC-53, CT-92, TT-35, v 2 =2.19, P=.33). The sputum level of sCD14 in patients with fixed (CC-Me=9.3, Q1=6.1, Q3=11.9 ng/mL; CT-Me=8.0, Q1=5.2, Q3=10.4 ng/mL; TT-Me=14.7, Q1=6.3, Q3=23.2 ng/mL) and reversible (CC-Me=9.8, Q1=6.1, Q3=15.3 ng/mL; CT-Me=7.9, Q1=5.4, Q3=10.9 ng/mL; TT-Me=17.7, Q1=13.7, Q3=21.6 ng/mL) airflow obstructive asthma phenotypes was significantly higher (P<.01) compared to the control group (Me=6.7, Q1=4.3, Q3=9.3 ng/mL). In fixed and reversible airflow obstructive asthma the sputum level of sCD14 in patients with the TT genotype was significantly higher (P<.01) compared to the CC and CT genotypes. Conclusions: The C-159T polymorphism is not associated with fixed and reversible airflow obstruction asthma phenotypes in the Crimean population of Ukraine. The highest level of sCD14 in induced sputum of asthma patients is associated with TT genotypes of the CD14-C159T polymorphism. 0361 | Association of CD14 C159t promoter polymorphism with regulatory cytokine response in Indian children with atopic asthma Agarwal A; Singh M Postgraduate Institute of Medical Education and Research, Chandigarh, India

FIGREF101.text: of Children's Health, Moscow, Russia Introduction: Bronchial asthma (BA) is one of the most common respiratory system diseases. The role of innate immunity components in the pathogenesis of bronchial asthma is studied widely, with particular focus on the TLRs and cytokines. The most important is the study of TLR2 and TLR4, because these receptors recognize a broad range of ligands and activate cytokines production. The aim of this work is the study of gene expression of TLR2, TLR4 and cytokines in children with bronchial asthma.

FIGREF102.text: The 5-year GAP trial showed that a grass SLIT-tablet (75 000) prevented the development of asthma symptoms and use of asthma medication in children (5-12 years) with grass pollen allergic rhinoconjunctivitis (ARC) (Valovirta, EAACI 2016). The trial comprised 3 years treatment with a standardized grass SLIT-tablet and 2 years blinded follow-up off treatment. Objectives: To further substantiate the effect of the grass SLITtablet treatment, a number of clinical phenotypes with increasingly stringent asthma criteria were identified and analysed post hoc in the 2-year post-treatment follow-up period: 1: The proportion of subjects experiencing asthma symptoms (any episodes of wheeze, cough for 10 consecutive days, shortness of breath, or chest tightness). 2: The proportion of subjects using asthma medication (beta-2-agonists, systemic corticosteroid, ICS, leukotriene receptor antagonists, LABA, sustained-release theophylline and cromolyn sodium). 3: The proportion of subjects experiencing asthma symptoms and using asthma medication. 4: The proportion of subjects experiencing asthma symptoms, using asthma medication, and with FEV 1 reversibility ≥12% (after administration of a beta-2-agonist) documented at least once in the trial. 5: The proportion of subjects experiencing asthma symptoms, using ICS, and with FEV 1 reversibility ≥12% (after administration of a beta-2-agonist) documented at least once in the trial. Results: For all 5 clinical phenotypes assessed in the 2-year blinded follow-up period off treatment, the proportion of subjects was statistically significantly lower when treated with the grass SLIT-tablet compared to placebo; odds ratio, 95%CI and P-value for phenotype 1: OR=0.55 [0.33;0.90], P=.017; phenotype 2: OR=0.34 [0.71;0.67], P=.002; phenotype 3: OR=0.28 [0.14;0.57], P=.0004; Regardless of the clinical phenotype (asthma symptoms, using asthma medication and experiencing different combinations of asthma symptoms, asthma medications and FEV 1 reversibility≥12% during the follow-up period), the proportion of subjects fulfilling the criteria was statistically significantly lower when treated with the grass SLIT-tablet compared to placebo. These results substantiate the treatment effect of the grass SLIT-tablet on asthma symptoms and use of asthma medication during 2-year blinded follow-up off treatment.

FIGREF103.text: Paediatric Allergy, Guy's & St Thomas' Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, London, United Kingdom; 2 Private Practice, Bretten, Germany; 3 Global Clinical Development, ALK, Hørsholm, Denmark; 4 Department of Lung Disease and Clinical Allergology, University of Turku and Terveystalo Turku, Allergy Clinic, Turku, Finland Introduction: The asthma prevention (GAP) trial was a 5-year, 1:1 randomised, parallel-group, double-blind, placebo-controlled, multinational trial in Europe, investigating the asthma preventive effect of the a grass SLIT-tablet (75 000 SQ-T) in 812 children (5-12 years) with a clinically relevant history of grass pollen allergic rhinoconjunctivitis and no medical history of asthma. Asthma symptom and/or asthma medication use at the end of trial was assessed as a secondary endpoint, and showed a clear treatment effect in favour of the grass SLIT-tablet. The treatment effect was further characterised post hoc during the 2-year follow-up period.Objectives: The proportion of subjects with asthma symptoms and/or asthma medication use were analysed and here the results for the follow-up years are presented.Results:The trial comprised a screening period, a 3-year treatment period with daily treatment, and a 2-year follow-up period. Independently of whether asthma was diagnosed or not, all randomised subjects were to continue in the trial for all 5 years. The asthma medications recorded were: beta-2-agonists, systemic corticosteroid, ICS, leukotriene receptor antagonists, LABA, sustained-release theophylline and cromolyn sodium. The asthma symptoms recorded ABSTRACTS | 273

FIGREF104.text: relative risk reduction, RRR=43.6%) and OR=0.51, P=.013 (RRR=45.3%) for first and second follow-up year. The greatest differences between SQ grass SLIT-tablet and placebo were recorded for wheeze, chest tightness and shortness of breath. For asthma medication use, the results were: OR=0.24, P=.001 (RRR=73.3%) for each follow-up year. The asthma medications used were primarily beta-2agonists. For the proportion of subjects having asthma symptoms and using asthma medication, the results were: OR=0.26, P=.0007 (RRR=73.2) and OR=0.28, P=.0002 (RRR=71.1) for first and second follow-up year, respectively. Conclusions: Grass SLIT-tablet treatment prevented asthma symptoms and asthma medication use 2 years following 3 years continuous treatment with the grass SLIT-tablet in children with no existing signs or symptoms of asthma at randomisation. 0365 | Clinical effect of intra-lymphatic immunotherapy: Three years follow up from a double blind placebo controlled trail Skaarup SH; Schmid J; Skjold T; Hoffmann H Department of Respiratory Medicine and Allergy, Aarhus University Hospital, Aarhus, Denmark Introduction: With intralymphatic immunotherapy, ILIT, AIT is delivered into the lymph nodes. This reduces the sensitivity of immune reactions to allergen. The time consumption of the AIT treatment is reduced from 3-5 years to 2 months, and the number of injection is reduced from 30 to three. Objectives: We have evaluated long term clinical effect of ILIT with a double-blind placebo controlled trail with three year follow up. Results: We included 36 patients with rhino-conjunctivitis in the grass pollen season and a positive skin prick test to grass pollen. Patients were randomized to placebo ILIT (n=12) or active ILIT (N=24) with 1.000 squ Phleum Pratense, Alum absorbed extract. We performed ultrasound guided injection in the spring 2014. Rhino-conjunctivitis symptoms and use of medication were recorded every day during the grass pollen season 2014, 2015 and 2016. We used a combined symptoms and medication score, cSMS, to evaluate the outcome.

FIGREF105.text: Conclusions: With this double-blind placebo controlled trail, we show that ILIT gives a significant and clinically relevant reduction in cSMS in all three years. Treated patients had less rhino-conjunctivitis symptoms and used less medicine during three years follow up after ILIT. Number of days with severe symptoms were reduced and replaced with more days with no or minimal symptoms. This trail confirms ILIT as an effective AIT. The very shot treatment period with only 3 injections makes ILIT a patient friendly and affordable form of AIT.

Serum LCN2 may thus contribute to assess clinical reactivity in allergic patients. 0367 | Treatment-start early in life reduces the number needed to treat (NNT)-Results from an asthma prevention (GAP) trial Respiratory Biomedical Research Unit, University Hospital Southampton NHS Foundation Trust, Southampton, United Kingdom; 2 Human Development in Health & Clinical and Experimental Sciences Academic Units, University of Southampton Faculty of Medicine and David Hide Asthma and Allergy Research Centre, St Mary's Hospital, Isle of Wight, United Kingdom; 3 ALK, Hørsholm, Denmark; 4 Hans Christian Andersen Children's Hospital, Odense University Hospital, Odense, Denmark Introduction: The GAP trial showed that the grass SLIT-tablet (75 000) provided sustained effect after treatment on rhinoconjunctivitis and had the added benefit of preventing development of asthma symptoms and asthma medication use (secondary/post hoc endpoints) in children with grass pollen allergic rhinoconjunctivitis and no medical history of asthma (Valovirta, EAACI 2016).

FIGREF108.text: The GAP trial was a randomised, DBPC trial including 812 children (5-12 years). The trial comprised 3 years treatment and 2 years follow-up off treatment. Asthma symptoms and asthma medication use since last visit were assessed half-yearly, during winter and grass pollen season, and NNT analysed post hoc for the 2-year follow-up period. The NNT was calculated as 1/[difference in predicted probability of having asthma symptoms and asthma medication use] placebo-SQ grass SLIT-tablet using a population based model (generalized estimation equation).

FIGREF109.text: birch pollen extract is similarly effective for younger and older patients with birch pollen induced allergic rhinitis/rhinoconjunctivitis Introduction: Allergic rhinitis/rhinoconjunctivitis (ARC) is an important problem worldwide and may significantly impair quality of life. Previously, a phase III study was conducted to establish the clinical efficacy and safety of pre-and co-seasonal sublingual immunotherapy (SLIT) with a liquid birch pollen extract for the treatment of birch pollen induced ARC. The primary analysis of this study showed a statistically significant and clinical relevant improvement on the primary efficacy endpoint: Combined Symptoms Medication Score (CSMS) during the birch pollen season after SIT compared to placebo (Pfaar et al. Allergy (2016); 71 (suppl.102): 45 (abstract 87)). The objective of this post-hoc analysis was to assess whether clinical efficacy of SLIT is similar for older (45-65 years) and younger (18-45 years) birch pollen allergic patients.Objectives: The study was a randomized, double-blind, placebocontrolled, parallel-group study, with treatment with a liquid birch pollen extract (40 000 AUN/mL) starting at least 12 weeks before the birch pollen season and continuing during the post-hoc analysis, the effect of birch SLIT was assessed in all patients of the Intent-to-Treat group, ie 267 patients in the younger age group (age 18-45 years) and 90 patients in the older age group (age 45-65 years).Clinical efficacy of Birch SLIT 40 000 AUN/mL was assessed by calculation of the difference in the CSMS as assessed during the birch pollen season compared to placebo for both sub-groups separately.Results: A clinically relevant and statistically significant CSMS reduction was reached for both the older and younger age subgroups compared to placebo (P=.0013 and P=.0022, respectively).Moreover, in absolute terms the CSMS improvement was comparable in both subgroups and exceeded the pre-defined clinical relevant CSMS effect of 23% (relative difference of 40% and 28%, respectively).Conclusions:Results of this post-hoc subgroup-analysis support the hypothesis that SLIT using a liquid birch pollen extract is similarly effective in older and younger birch pollen allergic patients, indicating that both age groups can benefit from this therapy to a similar extent. 0369 | The effect of immunotherapy on birch pollen induced allergic rhinitis symptoms in dually sensitized grass and birch allergic patients-A pilot evaluation utilizing controlled allergen challenge Ellis AK 1 ; Tenn MW 1 ; Steacy LM 2 ; Adams DE 2 ; Walker TJ 2 s University, Kingston, Canada; 2 Kingston General Hospital, Kingston, Canada; 3 Merck & Co., Kenilworth, United States Introduction: A sublingual immunotherapy tablet (SLIT-T, 2800 BAU) approved for the treatment of grass pollen induced allergic rhinitis (AR). Many patients with grass allergy are also sensitized to birch pollen and there was interest to determine if any by-stander effect could be seen on birch induced symptoms following treatment.Objectives: This single centre, randomized, double blind, placebo controlled study aimed to determine the impact of SLIT-T treatment on AR symptoms induced by birch pollen exposure in a controlled allergen challenge model (the Environmental Exposure Unit, or EEU) in participants with both grass and birch induced AR.

Large wheal size in pre-SCIT skin prick tests to relevant allergens and histamine proved predictive of local, but not systemic reactions, while levels of specific IgE did not appear to have significant influence. SEs were more common in monosensitized patients (OR=1.7). Contrary to recent studies, local side effects did not appear predictive of future systemic reactions and both types of events had distinct risk factors.Patients who experienced a higher frequency of side effects proved more likely to see notable reduction of symptoms and medication intake (OR=3.6 for patients with more than 1 SE episode).Conclusions: Side effects are an unavoidable part of SCIT, but the data from our study shows that some patients are at an increased risk of experiencing adverse events. FIGREF116.text: In 2001 the Paul-Ehrlich-Institute (PEI) published an analysis of reports with regard to serious adverse drug reactions (ADRs) in the course of treatment with test-& therapy allergens received within the timeframe from 1991 until 2000. Regarding the respective incidences, no information was given for individual companies or preparations. LETI Pharma GmbH took the opportunity to perform a similar analysis of the incidences of serious adverse reactions (SAR).Objectives: Pharmacovigilance (PV) requires the careful collection, detection, assessment, monitoring, and prevention of adverse effects with pharmaceutical products. We used our PV database to analyze the incidence of serious adverse reactions occurring in the course of treatment with a depigmented polymerized allergen preparation of pollen and mites. Spontaneously reported SARs from 01.01.2001 to 31.12.2013 in Germany were analyzed. As for the analysis of the PEI, the number of presumed injections per vial was used as a basis for calculations: From vial 1 of depigmented polymerized allergen extract 2 injections are administered and from vial 2, 5 or 6 injections are administered depending on the conventional or rush dosing schedule.Results: In total 32 spontaneous serious adverse reactions (in 32 patients) were reported. Separated per allergen group 15 SAEs followed injections with depigmented polymerized mite allergen extract, 17 in relation with depigmented polymerized pollen extracts. Taking the different dosing schemes into account the incidences of SAR is 0.00046% (1:216281 injections). This refers to an incidence of 0.00077% in mite treatment and an incidence of 0.00034% in pollen treatment. Conclusions: The calculation based on the number of sold vials and the possible injections of depigmented polymerized pollen & mite allergen extract showed a very low risk of serious ADRs. Even if criteria for serious assessment have changed and increased over the time we observe a lower incidence with depigmented polymerized allergen extracts compared to the incidence published by PEI of 0.01%-0.0005% for polymerized allergen extracts. School of Medicine, Suwon, South Korea Introduction: Surfactant protein D (SP-D) is a member of the collectin family that has an important role against lung infection and asthma. Moreover, SP-D dysfunction is related with several pulmonary diseases as it regulates inflammation. However, the function of SP-D in the pathogenesis of aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) is still unclear. Objectives: To understand the role of SP-D in airway mechanisms of AERD. Results: Serum SP-D levels were significantly lower in patients with AERD compared to those of ATA (P<.001). Moreover, AERD patients carrying the CC genotype at 2538C>T were significantly higher than ATA patients (P=.027) and serum SP-D levels were significantly different according to this genetic polymorphism. Conclusions: These findings suggest that decreased level of SP-D may contribute to promote airway inflammation in the pathogenic mechanism of AERD. 0379 | What happens to basophils and mediators of tryptase, lxa4, and cyslt during aspirin desensitization? School of Medicine Department of Chest Diseases Division of Immunology and Allergy, Ankara, Turkey; 2 Ankara University School of Medicine Department of Pediatrics Division of Immunology and Allergy, Ankara, Turkey; 3 Ankara University School of Medicine Division of Immunology and Allergy, Ankara, Turkey; 4 Ankara University School of Medicine Department of Pharmacology, Ankara, Turkey; 5 Ankara University School of Medicine Department of Pediatrics Division of Immunology and Allergy, Ankara, Turkey Introduction: Aspirin desensitization (AD) has been shown to be effective in relieving respiratory symptoms, reducing medication use, and most importantly in delaying occurrence of nasal polyps in patients with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID)-exacerbated respiratory disease (NERD). However, limited data is available on how aspirin desensitization works.Objectives: We aimed to study the mechanisms underlying aspirin desensitization by examining basophil activation (CD203c expression), mediator-released tryptase, CysLT, LXA 4 , and LTB 4 receptor expression for the first 3 months of AD.The study was conducted in patients with NERD who underwent aspirin desensitization (group 1: n=23), patients with NERD who received no desensitization (group 2: n=22), and healthy volunteers(group 3, n=13). All participants provided blood samples for flow cytometry studies (CD203c and LTB 4 receptor), and mediator releases (CysLT, LXA 4, and tryptase) for the relevant time points determined. Results: All baseline parameters of CD203c and LTB 4 receptor expressions, tryptase, CysLT, and LXA 4 releases were similar in each group (P>.05). In group 1, CD203c started to be upregulated at the time reactions during AD, and continued to be high for 3 months. CD203c expressions were similar at the other time points in group 2 and 3. All other study parameters were comparable with baseline and at the other time points in each group (P>.05). Conclusions: Our results showed that although basophils were active during the first 3 months of AD, no releases of CysLT, tryptase or LXA 4 existed. Therefore, our results suggested that despite active basophils, inhibition of mediators can at least partly explain the good clinical outcomes seen in the first three months of AD. 0380 | Desensitization to acetylsalicylic acids in patients with SAPHO syndrome Candon Morillo R; Burgos Montero AM; Proy Vega B; Gonzalez Sanchez L; Moreno Mata E; Garcia Rodriguez C Hospital General Mancha Centro, Alcazar De San Juan (Ciudad Real), Spain Introduction: A 53 year-old woman with a history of suspected allergy to acetylsalicylic acid (ASA), migraines, colon polyposis, chronic bronchitis, SAPHO syndrome (synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis and osteitis), psoriatic arthritis with serological lupus anticoagulant, vasovagal pre-syncope, epilepsy and restless legs syndrome and supraventricular tachycardia.

FIGREF118.text: Bernardo, Centro Hospitalar de Set ubal E.P.E.; Faculdade de Ciências da Sa ude, Universidade da Beira Interior, Set ubal, Portugal; 2 Hospital de São Bernardo, Centro Hospitalar de Set ubal E.P.E., Set ubal, Portugal Introduction: Delayed-onset maculopapular exanthema (MPE) is frequently observed in children treated with betalactams. Many are labeled ''allergic'' without reliable testing. Drug provocation test (DPT) is the most sensitive test in allergological work-up for drug allergy, and its specificity is close to 100%, particularly in nonimmediate reactions (NIR). However, many questions remain, among them whether a full therapeutic course should be given instead of one total cumulative dose in order to improve the sensitivity of the DPT.Objectives: To evaluate the diagnostic failures of a DPT with only one total dose in a group of patients who developed MPE temporarily associated with administration of penicillins. Results: In this retrospective study we analyzed 111 patients that underwent standard DPT with penicillins, 59 for investigation of MPE. Two of those had immediate and another 2 a delayed positive DPT. The remaining 54 (negative DPT) answered a phone questionnaire. These patients had a mean age of 25.4AE22 years (28 were children or adolescents), 55.4% female. The suspected penicillin was: amoxicillin/clavulanate (25), amoxicillin (16), penicillin G Only 4 of the 111 patients had positive DPT, supporting that the vast majority of reactions developing during an antibiotic course are driven by an infectious process in susceptible individuals. It is therefore imperative an adequate diagnostic investigation. An important percentage of patients refused to take penicillins again in spite of the negative DPT. This highlights the need to improve doctor-patient communication, reassuring the high negative predictive value of DPT. Only 1 patient with negative DPT had a posterior possible reaction to amoxicillin, suggesting that a full course DPT doesn't offer a relevant improvement of sensitivity to diagnostic work-up of delayed allergic reactions to penicillins. 0382 | Do skin tests predict next perioperative allergic reaction after perioperative anaphylaxis? Tunakan Dalgiç C; D€ us€ un€ ur G€ unsen F; Bulut G; Ardeniz F € O; G€ ulbahar O; Mete G€ okmen EN; Sin AZ; Kokuludag A Ege University Medical Faculty, Department of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, Izmir, Turkey Introduction: The main responsible agents are neuromuscular blockers, antibiotics and latex for perioperative anaphylaxis. 60% of these reactions are known to be mediated by IgE dependent mechanisms. Objectives: We aim to determine the importance of skin tests for diagnosing perioperative anaphylaxis with IgE dependent mechanisms in our clinics between January 2014-May 2016. Results: 35 patients (31 female, 4 male) were searched. Mean age was 48 (20-78). 16 of females and 1 of males, totally 17(48%) of them had anaphylactic reactions in their medical history. Other atopic diseases were; 13 had other types of drug allergies, 4 had allergic rhinitis/asthma, 4 had urticaria/angioedema and 2 had cosmetics and chemical products allergy. 12 of them had no other atopic diseases. Skin tests with latex and general anesthetics were positive in 21 patient (60%). Between those patients with positive skin tests, 1) skin tests were positive. There were no positive skin tests with local anesthetics, etomidate, thiopental, suxamethonium and pancuronium. Totally 20 (57%) patients had operation without any complications. It is remarkable that 10 of them had perioperative anaphylactic reaction histories and positive skin tests. They had operation with different drugs from the culprit ones and had no perioperative reactions.Conclusions: In this study, skin tests showed positivity in 82% of patients with perioperative anaphylaxis history. So, skin tests' predictivity of IgE mediated reactions was found remarkably high for next operation (82%). To do skin tests with suspicious drugs should be essential for perioperative anaphylaxis. Totally, 57% of 35 patients were operated. 58% of patients with perioperative anaphylaxis and positive skin tests were operated without any complications. 40% of 35 patients with negative skin tests were thought to be related with non IgE mediated mechanisms. 18 of 35 patients hadn't any perioperative anaphylaxis history but 7 of them had positive skin test, so those positivities were thought to be related to earlier sensitizations with cosmetics and chemical products similar to neuromuscular blockers.

FIGREF122.text: : DRESS is not an infrequent condition, occurring in different settings in a tertiary center. Clinical manifestations are varied involving several organ and systems. Antibiotics were the most frequently involved drugs. The role and outcomes of the allergy eval-Severe cutaneous adverse reactions (SCARs) are rare but potentially fatal, and often associated to drugs. Symptoms appear late during therapeutics, usually with cutaneous and systemic involvement. SCARs include acute generalized exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP), Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), toxic epidermal necrosis (TEN) and DRESS syndrome (drug, rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms). Objectives: To characterize patients admitted to Hospital Beatriẑ Angelo with diagnosis of SCAR, from 2012 to 2015. Methods: retrospective analysis of patients diagnosed with SCAR, during a 4-year period. Only patients fulfilling RegiSCAR criteria were included.

FIGREF123.text: Although rare, SCARs are associated with high morbidity and mortality. Rapid diagnosis, withdrawal of the suspect drug and treatment is essential. In our group of patients, antiepileptic drugs were the most frequently involved, in accordance with other published results. The beginning of symptoms after approximately 1 month since the beginning of the causative drug is also described in previous publications. The clinical and epidemiological assessment of SCARs is extremely important for their better Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is a severe inflammatory disease that appears in children and adolescents with seasonal recurrences. Topical Ciclosporin A (CsA) has been proven to be effective in the long-term treatment of VKC, significantly improving signs and symptoms without significant side effects. CsA cationic emulsion (CsA CE) is a new oil-in-water formulation that can remain longer on the ocular surface, thereby optimizing its therapeutic effects.Objectives: The VEKTIS study, a phase III, multicenter, doublemasked, vehicle-controlled trial, evaluated the efficacy and tolerability of CsA CE 1 mg/mL eye drops for treating severe VKC patients.169 sever VKC patients between 4 and 18 years of age with severe keratitis were randomized to 4-month treatment with one of two active doses of CsA CE 1 mg/mL (high-dose [four times daily] or low-dose [twice daily]) or to the vehicle. This was followed by an 8month safety follow-up period during which patients were re-randomized to one of the two active treatment arms. The primary endpoint (PE) was a mean composite score that reflected corneal fluorescein staining (CFS) as assessed by the modified Oxford scale, need for rescue medication, and occurrence of corneal ulceration during 4 months.Results:The PE of superiority of active treatment over vehicle was met; the difference in the least-squares (LS) mean vs vehicle was statistically significant for both the high-dose group (0.76, P=.007) and the low-dose group (0.67, P=.010). Treatment effect was mainly driven by CFS score. A majority of the patients did not need rescue medication, and while the mean number of rescue medication courses was significantly different between the high-dose and vehicle groups (P=.010), it was only marginally different between the low-dose and vehicle groups (P=.055). The symptoms and quality of life also improved; outcomes remained stable over the 8-month follow-up. Overall, the proportions of patients with ≥1 adverse event were 58.3% and 50.0% in the high-and low-dose groups, respectively. The most frequently reported AEs in the high-dose group were instillation site pain, instillation site pruritus, cough, influenza, and ocular hyperemia.

Results: A total of 188 patients out of 263 were classified as allergic rhinitis (AR) with positive 7SPT/sIgE results. AR group were found to have higher TNSS, and nNO levels than patients with nonallergic rhinitis (NAR:75) (P<.001, P=.005, respectively), while as NAR group had higher OpS and ObS (P=.01, P=.02). In patients with normal OpS (69.64%), nNO, SPT (+), AR/NAR ratio, and pollen positivity were statistically higher. Those with abnormal OpS had lower nNO (P=.02), and higher ObS, as well as asthma frequency, sinusitis, and blood eosinophil levels. Compared to normal ObS, in patients with abnormal ObS (17.1%), lower nNO (P=.001) and AR/NAR ratio, but higher OpS, sinusitis symptoms and blood eosinophil levels were detected. In linear regression analysis, nNO was negatively correlated with ObS (À38.840-4.465, P=.01, and positively with SPT positivity (8.036-160.952, P=.03).

FIGREF126.text: Periostin, a 90-kDa extracellular matrix protein, is well known to play essential roles in the development and persistence of allergic diseases, including allergic rhinitis (AR) and atopic dermatitis. Although histamine H1 receptor antagonists are recommended as the first choice of agent in the treatment of allergic diseases, the influence of histamine H1 receptor antagonists on periostin production is not well understood. The present study was undertaken to examine the influence of histamine H1 receptor antagonists on periostin production from nasal epithelial cells after IL-4 stimulation in vitro. Objectives: Human nasal epithelial cells (HNEpC) at a concentration of 19105 cells/mL were stimulated with 10.0 ng/mL IL-4 in the presence of various concentrations of either desloratadine (DLT), loratadine(LT), levocetirizine (LCT) or cetirizine (CT). After 48 hours, culture supernatants were collected and assayed for periostin levels by ELISA. The influence of the agents on transcription factor activation, STAT6 and periostin mRNA expression were also examined by ELISA and real-time RT-PCR, respectively through the choice of LCT.Results: Addition of histamine H1 receptor antagonists, DLT, LT, LCT and CT, suppressed the ability of HNEpC to produce periostin in response to IL-4 stimulation in dose-dependent manner. The minimum concentration that caused significant suppression is 0.01 lmol L À1 for DLT, 0.05 lmol L À1 for LT, 0.05 lmol L À1 for LCT and 0.1 lmol L À1 for CT. Treatment of HNEpC with LCT at more than 0.05 lmol L À1 also suppressed STAT6 activation and periostin mRNA expression, which are increased by IL-4 stimulation.Conclusions:The present results strongly suggest that histamine H1 receptor antagonists favorably modify the clinical status of allergic diseases, especially AR, through the suppression of periostin production from nasal epithelial cells after IL-4 stimulation. It is also suggested that the suppressive effects of the agents on periostin production may confer the prevention of both development and persistence of allergic diseases.

The clinicians were allowed to choose the treatment.Results: Twenty two patients are included in the study at present.Data from twelve patients were analysed here. An improvement was noted for most of the symptoms and isolated signs of rhinitis but it was nearly significant only for sneezing (6.7AE1.7 vs 4.6AE2.7, P=.05) and for watery eyes (5.1AE3.8 vs 2.3AE2.4, P=.05). The global discomfort felt by patients decreased from D1 to D15 (6.8AE1.2-5.3AE2.5 (P=.09, NS)) and was accompanied by a decrease of the impact of allergic rhinitis on sport activities (3.7AE3.8, P=.05). We found a significant improvement (P=.007) of the rhinitis control score between D1 (15.6AE3.5) and D15 (19.1AE4.1).

FIGREF130.text: A new approach in treatment of allergic rhinitis without the use of corticosteroids and antihistamines-Three years experience with the nasal application of alpha-tocopherol acetate spray Lamprecht J University Duesseldorf, ENT, Duesseldorf, Germany Introduction: Our first presentation in 2014 (48 patients) showed the efficacy of alpha-tocopherol acetate (vitamin E acetate) as nasal spray (Hulka, Italy) in allergic rhinitis. This encouraging result led usto several studies to confirm its efficacy against the nasal symptoms of hayfever. The aim of this report is to update our experience and to share it with scientists in Finland, the country with the highest prevalence of allergic birch pollen rhinitis.Objectives: The institute of medical statistics, informatics and epidemiology at the university of Cologne performed with us a study on alpha-tocopherol acetate (vitamin E acetate) nasal spray as an alternative treatment option in patients with pollen-induced allergic rhinitis in comparison to standard therapies (A). Meanwhile we offered that spray to more than 400 patients with allergic rhinitis instead of antihistamines or corticosteroids during season (B) and after nasal provocation test (C) and monitored the outcome.Results: The outcome of this new treatment shows the efficacy on the allergy induced nasal symptoms, very prompt (within 4-5 minutes) in birch pollen allergy and remarkable effects (within 4-5 days) in other allergens (B). Alpha-tocopherol acetate in the prospective study (A) even matched with conventional therapy. In addition this approach is highly accepted in women with nasal allergy during pregnancy. And we found a remarkable effect on recovery after nasal provocation test (C).Conclusions: Alpha-tocopherol acetate as a topical treatment works in allergic rhinitis. Compared to standard therapies alpha-tocopherol acetate represents a viable treatment option for sensitive , Regional University Hospital of Malaga, Malaga, Spain, Malaga, Spain; 2 Allergy Unit, IBIMA, Regional University Hospital of Malaga, UMA, Malaga, Spain, Malaga, Spain; 3 Research Laboratory, IBIMA, Regional University Hospital of Malaga, Malaga, SpainIntroduction: There are few data available regarding natural history of local allergic rhinitis (LAR). We previously reported the results of the first 5-years of follow-up observing a similar rate of development of systemic allergic rhinitis (AR) in both LAR patients and healthy controls. Objectives: To explore the natural history of a population with LAR and the development of AR and comorbidities over a 10 year period. A cohort of 194 patients with LAR of recent onset (<18 months) and 130 age-and sex-matched healthy controls were prospectively evaluated in a 10-year follow-up study (2005-2016). All participants provided informed consent and ethic committee of the hospital approved the study. Clinical-demographic questionnaire, spirometry, SPT and specific IgE (sIgE) to aeroallergens were evaluated yearly. Nasal allergen provocation tests (NAPT) with D. pteronyssinus (DP), Alternaria, Olea europaea, and grass pollen were performed at baseline, and after 5 and 10 years.Results: A total of 151 patients (78%) and 90 controls (69%) completed the study. At baseline, most patients had moderate-to-severe persistent-perennial rhinitis. Conjunctivitis (52%) and asthma(19%)    were the main comorbidities, and DP the most frequent sensitizing aeroallergen (51.1%). During the 10 years of evaluation 21 new cases of asthma (12.5%, P=.007) and 17 new cases of conjunctivitis (10%, P=.067) were diagnosed. After 10 years of evolution a similar rate of development of AR was detected in patients and healthy controls (11.3% vs 10%, P=.761). In 5 patients, conversion to systemic atopy occurred in the last year of evaluation (3%).Conclusions: LAR is a well-differentiated clinical entity with a low rate of development of systemic atopy.
