The aim of the study was to assess the influence of PMBL on clinical course of asthma in children. Objectives: Randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled, multicentre, parallel-group study was done (EudraCT number: 2013-000737-12 and NCT02541331, EOLIA Study). Total number of 152 children aged 6-16 years with asthma was randomized. 75 children were treated with Polyvalent Mechanical Bacterial Lysate (PMBL; Ismigen ® tablets) once daily per 10 days in each 3 consecutive months as add-on treatment to routine asthma therapy and 77 children with placebo. The protocol included a total of 5 visits: screening/randomization visit (V1), end-of-treatment period visit (12 weeks; V3), follow-up visits (24 weeks; V4 and 36 weeks; V5). Main inclusion criteria were: allergic asthma diagnosis with at least one perennial allergen sensitization, partly controlled or uncontrolled asthma according to the GINA 2012 guidelines prior to V1, already treated with SABA PRN and ICS or ICS+LABA during the previous 3 months and at least 2 exacerbations of asthma within the 12months period before study. Results: The mean number of infections and the % of patients with at least one infection was not significantly different between groups, whatever the study time point. The number of patients with at least one infection leading to exacerbation was significantly lower in the PMBL group at 12 weeks (10 vs 21, P=.002) and over the total study period (22 vs 38, P=.003) in the PMBL and Placebo groups respectively. The percentage of patients without asthma exacerbation was significantly higher at 12 weeks in the PMBL group as compared to the Placebo group (75% vs 57.9%, P=.028). The mean number of asthma exacerbations was significantly lower in the PMBL group as compared to the Placebo group at 12 weeks (0.3AE0.6 vs 0.8AE1.1, P=.009) and over the total study period (1.1AE1.3 vs 1.9AE2.0, P=.011). The time to onset of first asthma exacerbation (event-free time) was not significantly different between groups although. The times to onset of second and third asthma exacerbations were significantly longer for the PMBL group (P=.0024 and P=.0004 respectively). Conclusions: The EOLIA study for the first time clearly demonstrates the efficacy of PMBL in reducing the number of exacerbations in children with allergic asthma. 0403 | Higher parental education reduced the risk of uncontrolled asthma Goksör E; Str€ omberg Celind F; Alm B; Vasileiadou S; M€ ollborg P; Pettersson R; Erdes L; Åberg N; Wennergren G Department of pediatrics, Institution of Clinical Sciences, University of Gothenburg, Queen Silvia Children's hospital, Gothenburg, SwedenIntroduction: Treatment with inhaled corticosteroids has resulted in better-controlled asthma disease and substantially reduced need of hospitalisation. The aim of this study was to examine the prevalence of and risk factors for uncontrolled asthma and hospitalisation due to asthma at the age of 12 years.Objectives: Data were obtained from a longitudinal cohort study of children born in the region of western Sweden in 2003. Parents answered postal questionnaires when the children were six months and one, four, eight and 12 years old. We also obtained data from the Swedish Medical Birth Register. The response rate at the age of 12 was 76% of those to whom the questionnaire was distributed (3637/4777), 64% of the 5654 included at admission in 2003.Asthma control at the age of 12 was examined with ACT TM , Asthma Control Test.

The proportion of childrensensitized (≥0.35 kUA/L) to Dermatophagoides farinae and Dermatophagoides pteronyssinus was higher in the fall group (29/31, 93.5%) than in the other season group (14/24, 58.3%). Sensitization to HDM was associated with asthma exacerbation in the fall after adjusting for total IgE (OR, 7.68; 95%CI, 1.41-41.81; Table 1). More than half of the children presented with eosinophilia with higher ECP levels that exceeded the reference value in both groups.Conclusions: Children with high HDM-sIgE levels can be regarded as a high-risk group for acute asthma exacerbation in the fall, and measurement of HDM-sIgE levels can be useful for applying individual therapy to prevent acute asthma exacerbation. 0407 | Human rhinovirus is the major cause of asthma exacerbation and acute lower respiratory tract infections among hospitalized children in Hong Kong Leung TF; Song YP; Wang HC; Leung AS; Tao KP; Tang MF; Chan RW Department of Paediatrics, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR Introduction: Human rhinovirus (HRV) is the major pathogen for a range of acute respiratory infections and wheezing illnesses in children. Among the genogroups A, B and C, HRV-A and HRV-C were more prevalent and clinically important than HRV-B. Our published results suggested that HRV-C was associated with childhood asthma exacerbation. However, the clinical manifestations and associations with asthma and different lower respiratory tract infection for different HRV species remain unclear.Objectives: This study aimed to investigate the epidemiology and disease spectrum of HRV detected in Hong Kong children between 2014 autumn to 2015 spring.

FIGREF135.text: and asthma exacerbations, HRV-C was more commonly found than HRV-A (75% vs 25%; OR 2.50, 95% CI 0.66-9.47). Similar proportions of HRV-A and HRV-C were found in patients with upper respiratory tract infection. We observed a trend towards changes in HRV from HRV-C in 2014 autumn to HRV-A in 2015 spring (HRV-A: 20.9% vs 34.0%). The predominant HRV serotypes in these two periods changed from HRV-C-8713-MY-10 to HRV-A30/ HRV-C15. Conclusions: HRV is a strong risk factor for asthma exacerbations and wheezing illnesses in Hong Kong children. Although these disease associations were mainly accounted for by HRV-C, the predominant HRV species isolated from our hospitalised children changed from HRV-C in 2014 autumn to HRV-A in 2015 spring. Prospective studies with larger sample size are needed to confirm our observations. Conclusions: Early anti-inflammatory therapy and maintenance of long-term total control of asthma not only may prevent progression of disease severity and improve quality of life, but also may allow normal development of pulmonary function and outgrowth of asthma in young children. 0410 | Values of fractional exhaled nitric oxide in diagnosis and treatment of children with chronic cough Jiang W; Zhou J; Hao C Children's Hospital of Soochow University, Suzhou, China Introduction: Cough is a common complaint in pediatrics, and often develops into chronic cough in Chinese children, mainly include cough variant asthma, upper airway cough syndrome, postinfectious cough, and gastroesophageal reflux cough. It was widely recognized that airway inflammation was the foundation of all kinds of causes for chronic cough, and the airway inflammatory markers were of great importance for the detection of chronic cough. Based on this characteristic, noninvasive therapies such as fraction of exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) has been developed to detect eosinophilic airway inflammation. Clinical evidences demonstrate that FeNO level could monitor airway inflammation with high specificity and sensitivity, and reflect the level of induced sputum eosinophilia granulocyte, and inflammatory markers in alveolar lavage fluid. In 2005,

FIGREF138.text: Totally, 66 cases were enrolled and divided into 4 groups, including cough variant asthma (CVA, n=13), CVA combined with upper airway cough syndrome (UACS, n=17), UACS (n=26), and another causes group (n=10). Twenty-five healthy subjects were included in the control group. To diagnose CVA from chronic cough, the optimal FeNO cutoff value was 25 ppb, with sensitivity being 84.0%, specificity being 97.1%, positive predictive value being 97.5%, and negative predictive value being 81.4%. FeNO levels were shown to have significant correlations with sputum eosinophils, cough symptom scores (P<.05), and cough scores. Moreover, the decline level of FeNO was significantly related to the degree of the decrease of sputum eosinophils. Conclusions: The study suggests that FeNO measurement might be a better method for diagnosing CVA from chronic cough in children with high sensitivity and specificity. The level of FeNO decreased after anti-inflammatory treatment, which might be a potential marker for sputum eosinophils in children with chronic cough. 0411 | Real-time biofeedback and target minute ventilation in eucapnic voluntary hyperventilation test in children aged 10Pediatrics University Hospital of Kuopio, Kuopio, Finland; 4 Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Turku, Turku, Finland Introduction: Exercise is a common trigger of breathing difficulty in asthma, and dysfunctional breathing disorders may cause exerciseinduced dyspnea (EID) mimicking asthma. Traditional diagnostic methods of asthma have limited diagnostic accuracy in children. For dysfunctional breathing disorders there are currently no efficient non-invasive diagnostic methods available in children. Therefore, new diagnostic methods are required for the differential diagnostics of exercise-induced respiratory symptoms in children. The 6-minute EVH test has mainly been used in the diagnostics of elite athletes' exercise-induced dyspnea but has traditionally been considered to be too hard for children. The aim of this study was to evaluate the use of real time biofeedback in achieving the target minute ventilation in the EVH test in children. . Patients were able to follow their levels of ventilation in real time through the research equipment which is new in relation to traditional research equipment. Results: A total of 91.8% of the patients of the control group and 83.5% of the research patients reached the targeted 80% level of minute ventilation; there was no statistically significant difference between the groups (P=.157). A total of 80.3% of the healthy controls and 71.3% of the symptomatic patients reached at least 90% level in minute ventilation (P=.222) Conclusions: The use of real-time biofeedback is feasible and may improve achieving appropriate target minute ventilation in EVH testing in children aged 10-16 years. Using the real-time biofeedback method, the majority of both controls and symptomatic patients came very close to the target minute ventilation. The difference of our study and most previous studies was our possibility of following minute ventilation in real time by the visual graph. Without this possibility the proportion of participants having reached minute ventilation would likely have been significantly smaller 0412 | Evaluation of reversibility with classical spirometry and impulse oscillometry in children with atopic asthma Toprak Kanik E; Yilmaz O; Simsek Y; Yuksel H Celal Bayar University Medical Faculty, Dept. of Pediatric Allergy and Pulmonology, Manisa, TurkeyIntroduction: Evaluation of respiratory mechanisms in pediatric asthma is essential both clinically and to understand the pathophysiological background of the disease. However classical spirometry is difficult to perform in children, thus new methods are required.

FIGREF140.text: Patients with allergic rhinitis (AR) in the acute period often experience cough and shortness of breath, which may indicate the involvement of the lower respiratory tract. Quantification of lung sounds with the new method of computer bronchophonography (CBPhG) may be an additional not invasive lung function test. CBPhG is a method of registration of respiratory sounds, that is recorded by high sensitivity transducer in wide range of frequencies during quiet breathing: low 0.2-1.2, middle >1.2-5.0 and high frequency >5.0 kHz. We evaluated the acoustic component of the work of breathing (AC) in mJ Objectives: Rate the degree of airway obstruction and the effectiveness of children's therapy with AR during an exacerbation. Results: We selected 72 patients (age 3-16 years) with an exacerbation of moderate AR. All the children had rhinorrhea, sneezing and itchy nose. Patients were divided into 2 groups. 1 group (34 children) administrated antihistamines, intranasal corticosteroids, decongestants as needed. Group 2 (38 children)-in addition to this therapy leukotriene receptor antagonists (ALR) montelukast in age dosage was added. We evaluated AC before and after 2 weeks of therapy. AC was increased in the low frequency range in all the children, which correlates with the obstruction of the upper respiratory tract. Symptoms of nasal obstruction in children's therapy decreased in both groups, but more significant in group 2. Initially AC in the low frequency range was 254.8AE48.3 mcJ, in the middle frequency range-8.2AE4.2 mcJ, in the high frequency range-0.15AE0.05 mcJ. In group 1 in the low frequency range AC decreased to 160.6AE10.5 mcJ (P<.05), in group 2 during therapy with montelukast AC decreased to 105.3+15.2 mcJ (P<.05). AC in the middle frequency range and in the high frequency range not changed.Conclusions: CBPhG is a high sensitive not invasive method which may be used for assessment of the respiratory function and Impulse Oscillometry (IOS) is a no effort dependent validated technique that measures expiratory resistance (R) and reactance (x) at different oscillation frequencies. In this study we compare IOS and spirometry to assess methacholine challenge test (MCT) in children.

ROC curve analysis for these IOS parameters revealed an area under the curve (AUC) ranging from 0.86 to 0.89. The highest AUC was observed for Z5 and R5 (0.89). The cut-off point for the percentage of variation in the Z5, R5, X5 and AX was 31; 22; 41 and 82% respectively, all of these cut-off point show a sensibility and specificity >0.8.The median of PC20-FEV1 was 1 mg methacholine (0.41-4.22), 8.51 mg for PC40-R5, 4.24 for PC40-X5 and 2.18 for PC40-AX.However, cut-offs concentration required to give as positive test were lower than obtained by PC 20-FEV1, median PC22-R5, PC41-X5 and PC82-AX were 0.22, 0.14 and 0.24 respectively, This suggests that IOS could detect the bronchial obstruction before that spirometry.Conclusions:A good correlation between FEV1 and the IOS parameters were observed. IOS can provide a reliable, and patientfriendly technique for the diagnosis of asthma in children. Immunological Research, University of Cartagena, Cartagena, Colombia; 2 Group of Clinical and Experimental Allergy, IPS Universitaria, University of Antioquia, Medell ın, Colombia Introduction: There are few birth cohorts analyzing IgE sensitization in the Tropics Objectives: We aimed to describe the frequency of sensitization, risk factors and evolution of specific IgE responses to house dust mite allergens and Ascaris in the FRAAT cohort during the first 6 years of life. Specific IgE to several allergens were measured by ImmunoCap in 230 children at 6 years-old. The relationships of sensitization to Blomia tropicalis, Dermatophagoides pteronyssinus and Ascaris spp. with different socio-demographic factors and maternal data (sensitization and allergic phenotypes) were evaluated by logistic regression. Also, in a sub-sample of children (n=159) with available specific IgE data at 2-3 years, 4 years and 6 years, the evolution of sensitization was analyzed Results: Blomia tropicalis and Ascaris were the most important sensitizers at 6 years (40.9% and 38.9%, respectively) followed by American cockroach (20.4%) and D. pteronyssinus (16.1%). Sensitization to cat, dog, milk and egg were below 5%. Male gender and maternal Ascaris sensitization were significantly associated to a positive IgE response against this nematode at 6 years. Several poverty/ unhygienic indicators were found as risk factors for Ascaris sensitization; but in regard to B. tropicalis this only occurs at 2-3 years-old. Maternal high total IgE and B. tropicalis sensitization were found as novel risk factors for B. tropicalis sensitization at 6 years; especially if only new sensitizations were considered in the analysis. For B. tropicalis and Ascaris, it was found that early sensitization (2-3 years) persisted over time (66.6% and 76.5% at 6 years, respectively). B.tropicalis sensitization tended to increase with age [2-3 years: 30.2%, 4 years: 36.5%, 6 years: 39.6% in the subgroup, P=.08), but this trend was significant for Ascaris [2-3 years: 21.9%, 4 years: 35.4%, 6 years: 36.7%; P=.005]. In contrast, D. pteronyssinus sensitization kept constant over time (2-3 years: 13.1%, 4 years: 11.9% and 6 years: 13.1%, P=1.00) Conclusions: IgE responses to B. tropicalis and D. pteronyssinus are different during infancy, being Blomia tropicalis the most important sensitizer. Risk factors for Ascaris and B. tropicalis sensitization are different at 6 years; poverty/unhygienic conditions increase the risk of nematode sensitization but do not influence sensitization to mite allergens Center-Institute of Immunology, FMBA of Russia, Moscow, Russia; 2 Moscow State Academy for Veterinary Medicine and Biotechnology named after Scriabin K.I., Moscow, Russia Introduction: Epidemiological studies showed that among all viral pathogens respiratory viruses are the most prevalent (more than 90% of all cases of infectious diseases). One of the most common viral pathogen is respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) which affects the lower airways. It is well known that RSV lead to increased attacks in asthma patients. Natural anti-viral peptides are capable activate innate immune system and affect virions directly. Synthetic peptides are more cheaper compared to natural ones, so the purpose of this research-the study of the antiviral properties of synthetic peptides against RSV infection.

FIGREF142.text: AA of the peptides was studied in a model of RSV infection of MA-104 cells. Solutions of the peptides in nontoxic concentrations were incubated with RSV strain A2 (initial titer in 10 5 TCID 50 /mL) for one hour followed by titration on MA-104 cell monolayer. Five days after the infection RSV cytopathic effect was evaluated by light microscopy. MTT-assay showed that 5 of 16 peptides exhibited cytotoxicity on Hela cells in concentration range from 2.5 to 0.005 mg/mL. Calculated IC 50 for peptides NC-783, NC-810, LO-7, NC785 and AS-543 were 0.04, 0.05, 0.94, 1.6 and 1.85 mg/mL, respectively. Nontoxic concentrations of the peptides were testes in RSV infection model in vitro. Antiviral activity evaluation showed that 8 out of 16 peptides exhibited significant AA against RSV. Linear cationic peptides NC-788, LO-7, KO-1, IA-2, AS-543 and NC-737 demonstrated reduction of RSV titer by 10, 10, 25, 11, 11 and 14 times, respectively. Helical cationic peptide NC-785 reduced RSV titer in 13 times. Dendrimeric peptide LTP with strong positive charge exhibited maximal 99-fold reduction of RSV titer. The possible mechanism of AA of studied peptides is the direct destruction of the bilayer membrane of the RSV virions. Conclusions: Seven synthetized linear and helical peptides are capable from 10 to 25 times inhibit RSV infection in vitro in nontoxic concentrations. Dendrimeric cationic peptide LTP which reduced It has been suggested previously that human neutrophils may acquire features of antigen-presenting cells. For example, they upregulate the expression of MHC class II molecules in the presence of GM-CSF and IFN-c. However, their capacity to process antigens and present peptides via HLA class II has been debated. We studied human neutrophils in comparison to monocytes for their ability to internalize, process and present antigens to CD4+ T cells, employing the major birch pollen allergen Bet v 1 as model. Objectives: Neutrophils isolated from the peripheral blood of allergic donors were cultured with GM-CSF, IL-3 and IFN-c and analyzed for their expression of HLA-DR, CD80 and CD86 by flow cytometry. pHrodo-labelled Bet v 1 was employed to determine internalization and intracellular degradation by neutrophils and monocytes. Degradation kinetics of Bet v 1 with endolysosomal proteases from either cell type were measured by capture ELISA. Proteolytic fragments were analyzed using mass spectrometry. Finally, Bet v 1-pulsed neutrophils and monocytes were co-cultured with Bet v 1-specific T-cells and proliferative and cytokine responses of T cells were assessed. Results: In the presence of IL-3, GM-CSF and IFN-c, neutrophils significantly upregulated the expression of HLA-DR. The expression of CD80 was only marginally enhanced and CD86 was not detectable. Neutrophils internalized Bet v 1 as effectively as monocytes. In contrast to monocyte-derived endolysosomal proteases, neutrophilic proteases rapidly degraded Bet v 1 and digested it completely within 3-6 hours. However, the proteolytic fragments contained the most relevant T-cell epitopes. Neutrophils pulsed with Bet v 1 induced proliferation of all Bet v 1-specific T-cell clones specific for various epitopes distributed over the entire amino acid sequence of Bet v 1. The clones produced a similar cytokine profile as cells stimulated by monocytes.Conclusions: Our results provide strong evidence that neutrophils may acquire all features of antigen-presenting cells, including antigen processing and MHC class II-mediated presentation to effector T cells.

FIGREF143.text: Introduction: Recent studies demonstrated that cytokine IL-33 is upregulated in bronchial asthma (BA) patients. Study with experimental rhinovirus infection showed increase of IL-33 protein expression in bronchi of infected asthmatics. Despite that, there are little data available about role of IL-33 in respiratory virus induced asthma exacerbations.

FIGREF144.text: vRNA in nasal swabs was detected by RT-PCR and showed rhinovirus, respiratory syncytial virus and coronavirus infection prevalence: 50%, 46% and 38%, respectively. qPCR analysis showed 5.5fold increase of IL-33 expression in phytohemagglutinin-stimulated PBMCs from BA patients compared to healthy volunteers. At the same time the respiratory virus infection of asthmatics even more upregulated IL-33 expression; 6.8-fold compared to healthy volunteers. But the most potent IL-33 expression was detected in stimulated PBMCs from subject with RVI only.Conclusions:Our results indicate that IL-33 exhibit strong upregulation during respiratory virus infection rather than bronchial asthma, that support our previous data with animal models of virus-induced BA exacerbation. IL-33 may be a promising target for development of novel drugs for the treatment of virus-induced BA exacerbations. Allergy and chronic Respiratory Diseases, Center for Biomedical Sciences, Korea National Institute of Health, Korea Center for Disease Control and prevention, Cheong-Ju, South Korea Introduction: Staphylococcus aureus(SA) is an important infectious agent, it is also a frequent colonizer of the upper respiratory tract. In addition, SA is being discussed as possible triggering agent of allergic disease, including intrinsic asthma.Objectives: The objective of this study was to investigate the possible role of SA as a developmental agent of asthma. To elucidate the effect of SA infection on asthma development, normal primary epithelial cells (NHBEs) and asthmatic patient's primary epithelial cells (DHBEs) were treated with SA (MOI 100, 0, 1, and 4 hours).We first conducted cell viability test and adhesion & invasion assays.After treatment of SA, supernatants from both cells were collected to measure cytokine and chemokine expression. Total RNA was isolated from the cells, and RT-PCR was performed to analyze the changes of gene expression. For further analysis of gene expression, RNA-sequencing was performed using the illumina Hiseq 2500.Results: To confirm whether SA was infected into the primary lung epithelial cells, we tested expression of virulence factors. Lipoteichoic acid, peptidoglycan, and hyaluronidase activity were time-dependently increased on NHBEs and DHBEs cells by SA infection. The hyaluronidase activity was significantly increased on DHBEs cells compared to normal cells. SA infection increased various kinds of mRNA expression and protein production related with inflammatory cytokine and chemokine on primary lung epithelial cells. We found that MIP-2, TNF-a, and PDGF-BB were evaluated on SA treated primary epithelial cells.Especially, the IL-6 and IL-8 (P<.01) were significantly increased on SA infected asthmatic primary epithelial cells compared to normal cells.According to the results by RNA-seq analysis, over 3000 genes exhibited up-regulated or down-regulated on SA infected epithelial cells.For example, CCL2, CXCL5, IL-23, TGF-b, and MMP13 (fold change>2, P<.05), those related cells proliferation, migration, immuneregulation and inflammatory processes, were elevated. IPA analysis showed that TGF-b, TNF, and HGF (P<10 À6 ) were activated on asthmatic primary epithelial cells, which are related to the inflammatory responses, organismal injury and abnormalities. Conclusions: In this study, we showed that SA infection increased TGF-b, IL-23, PDGF-BB, CXCL5, and TNF expression on asthmatic primary lung epithelial cells. SA infection may accelerate cell proliferation, migration, and inflammation on asthmatic lung primary epithelial, thereby developing asthma. Fungal spores are one of the major types of microorganisms, can be present in all hospital environments, may be transmitted through air, patients and air conditions. It appears that adequate information on the nosocomial fungal allergy in hospital environment of West Bengal are largely lacking though 10% of the patients' infections are suspected to be hospital-acquired. Objectives: This study aimed to identify the novel IgE reactive proteins of nosocomial fungal allergens found in different wards of Barasat District Hospital, WB and investigate the in-vitro cross-reactivity among these allergens by in-vitro immunoenzymatic biochemical methods. Results: Andersen two stage sampler and Burkard sampler trapped a total of 22 fungal genera belonging to 34 species from different wards of the hospital. The most predominant air borne fungi have been identified are Aspergillus group, showed the highest (21.9%) prevalence of sensitization when tested (by SPT) on 128 nosocomial infected atopic patients, followed by Alternaria alternata(AA), Cladosporium cladosporioides(CC), Curvularia lunata(CL), Candida albicans (CA), Penicillium citrinum(PC), Epicoccum nigrum(EN), Tricophyton rubrum(TR), Fusarium oxysporum(FO) specific reactive proteins in western immunoblotting using a panel of sera from immunotherapy free subjects, though these antigens were profiled into numerous distinct bands in 11% SDS PAGE. ELISA inhibition has been used to identify degree of cross-reactivity among fungi whereas immunoblot-inhibition elucidate a componentbased shared allergens. IgE-immunoblot inhibition showed proteins of 26, 38, 45 and 50 kDa of CL were inhibited by AA and EN whereas A. fumigatus(AF) inhibited 26, 45 and 50 kDa proteins. Further 58 kDa glycoprotein of AF showed cross reactivity with 55 kDa antigen of CA and PC showed shared components of 34 kDa from A. fumigatus(AF) and EN. PC, CC and FO also shared multiple antigenic determinants.

FIGREF145.text: At 8 years of age, 21 children were diagnosed with IgEassociated allergic disease (eczema, allergic airway disease and/or food allergy) while 72 remained non-allergic. There was a significant interaction effect (allergic status9time) with decreases in the relative abundance (RA) of Firmicutes and Clostridia in allergic compared to non-allergic children over time (P<.01); within Clostridia, Ruminococcaceae specifically were depleted (P<.01). Both groups followed the same age-dependent pattern with a high RA of Actinobacteria and low RA of Firmicutes at 4 months with the opposite pattern at 8 years of age (P<.01). At 4 months of age LDA revealed that the gut microbiome of children that later developed IgE-associated allergic disease was significantly enriched in Bacteroidetes compared to the non-allergic group; Bacteroidaceae remained significantly higher at 6 months of age. At 8 years of age, the gut microbiome of healthy children was enriched in Lactobacillaceae, Enterococcaceae and Lachnospira whereas the RA of Bifidobacteriaceae was lower compared to that of allergic children. The a-diversity increased with age but there was no difference between the groups.Conclusions: Age-related dynamic changes in gut microbial composition were seen irrespectively of allergy development, however, decreases in the RA of Firmicutes and Clostridia was a feature in allergic children. 0422 | Human umbilical cord derived mesenchymal stem cells decreased T helper 17 immune response in skin draining lymph node of atopic dermatitis-like skin lesions induced by aspergillus fumigatus Introduction: Atopic dermatitis (AD) is a chronic and relapsing inflammatory skin disease. Mesenchymal stem cells (MSC) have been known to have an immunomodulatory effect. There is little information about immune mechanism of therapeutic effect of MSC for AD.Objectives: We investigated immunologic mechanism of therapeutic effect of human umbilical cord derived MSC (UC-MSC) for AD using a murine model.Results:We applied Aspergillus fumigatus (Af) extract (40 lg) to the dorsal skin of BALB/c mice 5 times a week repeatedly with an interval of 2 weeks to induce AD-like skin lesions. UC-MSCs (2x10 7 /mL) were injected subcutaneously at the last day of Af application. The clinical score and transepidermal water loss were decreased after subcutaneous injection of UC-MSCs. Moreover, UC-MSCs inhibited eosinophilic infiltration in skin lesions, and decreased the levels of total IgE. The levels of IFN-c and IL-13 were not decreased, but the level of IL-17 was decreased in skin draining lymph node (LN) of UC-MSC group, compared to those in skin draining LN of AD group.In addition, there is no significant difference in the percent of regulatory T cells of skin draining LN between AD and UC-MSC groups.Conclusions: UC-MSCs alleviated AD-skin lesion and decreased T helper 17 (Th17) immune response in a murine model, which suggest therapeutic potential of UC-MSCs through the modulation of Th17 immune response for human atopic dermatitis. Otolaryngology, Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine, National University of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; 2 Saw Swee Hock School of Public Health; National University of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; 3 Department of Microbiology and Immunology; Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine, National University of Singapore, Singapore, SingaporeIntroduction: Human rhinoviruses (HRVs) are the most common cause of the common cold which results in mild and self-limiting symptoms. While HRV infection causes less cytopathology compared to other respiratory virus infections, it is frequently associated with potentiation and exacerbation of chronic pulmonary diseases such as asthma. Currently, there are limited in vitro models on HRV infection of upper airway epithelial cells compared to lower airway despite nasal epithelium being the first contact site of the virus, and the connectivity of the airways. Objectives: Hence, using the model of HRV infection of in vitro differentiated human nasal epithelial cells (hNECs), we established a system to systematically study the viral replication kinetics, host responses and their association with HRV pathogenesis and disease progression. Results: By infecting in vitro differentiated hNECs from multiple individuals in air-liquid interface culture, we found that individualderived hNECs were susceptible to HRV infection, and that HRV mainly targeted ciliated cells of hNECs. HRV preferentially induced the TLR7/IRF7/IFN-b and IFN-k1 pathways for antiviral responses in hNECs. qPCR analysis of chemokine genes suggested predominant signaling for recruitment of T helper 1 cells (T H 1) and in the progression of innate to adaptive immunity, with CXCL9, IP-10, CXCL11 and RANTES identified as the likely initiator of immune responses in the lower airway following infection. Comparison of the HRV infection with an influenza infection in the same model highlighted key differences that may be explored for HRV specific pathogenesis, and through this comparison, we further identified 11 genes that may be responsible in conferring one of the different feature in pathogenesis between HRV and influenza. Conclusions: Overall, this in vitro hNEC HRV infection model provides a platform for repeated, controlled studies of HRV infection in the nasal epithelium in multiple individuals, revealing novel insights into viral replication dynamics and HRV-induced disease burden in human nasal epithelium. Molecular Biosciences, The Wenner-Gren Institute, Stockholm University, Stockholm, Sweden; 2 Department of Clinical Neuroscience, Centre for Molecular Medicine, Karolinska Institute, Stockholm, Sweden; 3 Department of Clinical and Experimental Medicine, Unit of Autoimmunity and Immune Regulation, Link€ oping University, Link€ oping, Sweden; 4 Department of Clinical Science and Education, S€ odersjukhuset, Karolinska Institute and Sachs' Children's Hospital, Stockholm, Sweden Introduction: Genetic risk factors and parental allergy are strong indicators of childhood allergy. In addition, a skewed T-helper (T H ) profile in early life is implicated as a risk factor in allergic disease. This skewness might indeed be genetic but also caused by environmental cues. A reduced or altered microbial exposure during childhood may inaccurately direct the maturing immune system and promote allergy development. Objectives: To investigate allergy prevalence during the first 10 years of life in a Swedish prospective birth cohort and evaluate the possible influence of heredity, lactobacilli-colonization and plasma cytokine-and chemokine-profiles on allergy development. 281 children participating in a prospective birth cohort were clinically examined at 6 months and 1, 2, 5 and 10 years of age. Skin prick test (SPT), specific IgE-levels and allergic symptoms were evaluated. For a subgroup of children, fecal samples were collected during infancy (≤2 months of age) and the presence of lactobacilli was investigated with RT PCR. The levels of cytokines and chemokines in plasma were quantified by ELISA and Luminex. Results: Among the children that developed allergy, there was a larger proportion of children with double allergic heredity. Increased plasma levels of the T H -related chemokines BCA-1/CXCL13 (T FH ), TARC/CCL17 (T H 2), MDC/CCL22 (T H 2) and MIP-3a/CCL20 (T H 17) in the first year of life associated with becoming allergic later in life. Early-life lactobacilli-colonization was connected to a reduced prevalence of allergy, despite allergic heredity. Notably, lactobacilli-colonized children had lower plasma levels of the chemokines BCA-1/ CXCL13 and MDC/CCL22, and higher levels of IFN-c. Conclusions: Having two allergic parents associated with becoming allergic. Increased levels of T H 2, T H 17 and T FH -related chemokines in the first year of life may predict later development of allergy. Lactobacilli-colonization associated with remaining non-allergic and with an altered cytokine-and chemokine-pattern. Hence, lactobacilli-colonization in infancy could be indicative of a beneficial immunematuration and a reduced risk to develop allergy. The interaction of virus infection and the host elements is one of the determinant factors in influenza A virus (IAV) virulence, which is key in the development of targets for therapeutic intervention that is host dependent and broad-spectrum. CD151 belongs to the super-family of 4-transmembrane glycoproteins called tetraspanins. Tetraspanins have been implicated to contribute to different phases of virus life cycle. However, no studies to date have examined whether CD151 plays a role in IAV infection and none have implicated a functional role for tetraspanins in host immune response against infection. Objectives: To determine the functional role and mechanism(s) of action of CD151 in IAV infection with H1N1 and H3N2 strains in vitro and in vivo. We used clinical donor samples of in vitro-differentiated human nasal epithelial cells (hNECs) cultured at air-liquid interface to determine the functional role of CD151 in IAV infection using biochemical and molecular methods. The role of CD151 in modulating lung pathology and innate immunity was assessed by comparing wild-type and CD151-null mice in an in vivo mouse model of IAV infection. Results: In the in vivo mouse model of IAV infection, compared with wild-type H1N1-infected mice, CD151-null mice showed significant reductions in virus titer accompanied by improved survival,which was associated with delayed but more pronounced host antiviral response. Interestingly, we also observed reduced nuclear export protein abundance and increased nuclear localization of viral proteins. In the in vitro-differentiated hNECs model, we further show that CD151 complexes newly synthesized viral proteins with host nuclear export proteins and stabilizes microtubule complexes;processes necessary for the polarized trafficking of viral progeny to the host plasma membrane for assembly.Conclusions:TargetingCD151 could reduce severity of influenza A virus infection by promoting host antiviral response and lung repair, and interrupting IAV infection at the level of nuclear export, a site not targeted by current therapy, which holds promise for the development of novel alternative/complementary strategies to reduce IAV severity. Otolaryngology, Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine, National University of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; 2 Saw Swee Hock School of Public Health, National University of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; 3 Department of Physiology, Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine, National University of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore; 4 School of Biological Sciences, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore, Singapore; 5 Department of Microbiology and Immunology, Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine, National University of Singapore, Singapore, Singapore Introduction: With the advent of medical research, cell line and animal based in-vitro and in-vivo research were shown to likely be insufficient in elucidating certain biological and physiological phenomena at a human population level, especially so when generating pre-clinical trials data. There is an obvious demand for a model that can further bridge the gap between experimental data and pre-clinical/clinical trials in elucidating the differential responses at a population level towards specific agents. Objectives: To established an in vitro infection model that can capture the transcriptomic changes using smaller sample size that are comparable to clinical data Results: We have previously generated an in-vitro differentiated, air-liquid interface culture of human nasal epithelial cells (hNECs) derived from nasal epithelial stem cells of healthy donors that retained the fully functional multi-layer of the nasal epithelium, the primary target of respiratory viruses. We showed that these cells, retaining the genome of their donors, were capable of capturing the individuals' differential responses towards respiratory viruses like influenza A virus (IAV), rhinovirus (RV), and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). Building onto this, we performed microarray analysis on hNECs model to ascertain the potential of these cells to elucidate population-based response against human IAV under a controlled and reproducible experimental conditions. Indeed, transcriptomic analysis of these hNECs from 5 donors infected 3 independent times were highly comparable towards clinical array data (13 independent influenza transcriptomic array datasets obtained from GEO database), including datasets with high sample sizes (eg Zhai et al., 2015 showed n=133 for microarray analyzed samples from n=1610 patients recruited in 2 years). The analyses of up-regulated genes captured from our model showed >80% identity showing that the hNECs model is capable of elucidating patient level data at a smaller scale when controlled for variables normally present in clinical data.Additionally, our model also allows for the analyses of down regulated genes in the nasal epithelium, which were not feasible in clinical data of blood samples. interfering ribonucleic acids targeted to interleukin-33 decrease airway hyperresponsiveness and lung inflammation in a mouse model of virus induced asthma exacerbationZaretskaia MA; Shilovskiy IP; Nikonova AA; Gaisina AR; Kamyshnikov OY; Khaitov MR; Smirnov VV National Research Center-Institute of Immunology, Moscow, Russia Introduction: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is one of the main cause of bronchial asthma (BA) exacerbations. IL-33 is involved in BA pathogenesis, but there are few data available about its role in virus-induced BA exacerbations (viBA).Objectives: To clarify the role of IL-33 in this pathology we evaluated the effects of IL-33 suppression by short interfering RNA (siRNA) in a mouse model of viBA.

FIGREF146.text: Downregulation of IL-33 expression makes clinical picture of viBA in mice model better. However, local IL-33 suppression resulted in attenuation of allergic rather than viral inflammation that reflected in improvement of lung function and decrease of eosinophil infiltration to the lung; at the same time RSV reproduction in lungs did not change significantly. This work is supported by RSF No 14-15-00894.

FIGREF147.text: Introduction: Atopic dermatitis (AD) is an inflammatory skin disease which may be due to the imbalance between Th1-, Th2 and Treg cell-related immune responses. Evidences suggest that appropriate stimulation with probiotics may correct the skewed immune response in children with AD. The aim was to determine the effects of the yogurt culture lactobacillus delbrueckii subsp. Bulgaricus on the secretion of Th1/Th2/Treg type cytokines by peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) from children with AD. Objectives: L. Bulgaricus was cultivated on MRS broth. The PBMCs from 20 children with AD were separated by Ficoll-Hypaque centrifugation and co-cultured with different concentrations of UV killed bacteria in RPMI-1640 plus 10% FCS for 48/72 hours. The levels of IL-10, IL-4, IL-12 and IFN-c were measured in supernatant of PBMCs by ELISA. RNA extraction and real time RT-PCR were used to measure Foxp3 mRNA expression. Results: L. Bulgaricus significantly up-regulated the secretion of IL-10, IL-12 and IFN-c, whereas decreased the secretion of IL-4 by PBMCs compared to control (P<.05). The secretion level of IL-10 by L. Bulgaricus-stimulated PBMCs at incubation time 72 hours was significantly higher than 48 hours. The expression of Foxp3 mRNA was changed accordingly (P<.001 and P<.01, respectively). Conclusions: These data show that L. Bulgaricus may modulate the secretion of Th1-, Th2-and Treg-related cytokines in AD patients. Therefore, the possible potential therapeutic of L. Bulgaricus for treatment of AD should be consider in further investigation. Epidemiology and Medical Biometry, Ulm University, Ulm, Germany; 2 Department of Dermatology and Allergic Diseases, University Medical Center Ulm, Ulm, Germany; 3 Department of Gynecology and Obstetrics, University Medical Center Ulm, Ulm, Germany Introduction: Several studies have identified association between birthweight and atopic dermatitis (AD). Yet, studies investigating fetal growth using ultrasound-based antenatal measurements have reported conflicting results. In this analysis, we investigated associations of 1st, 2nd, and 3rd trimester fetal anthropometrics and 2nd to 3rd trimester growth with child AD up to age 3 years. Objectives: ?????. Methods: In the Ulm SPATZ Health Study, 934 singleton newborns and their mothers were recruited from the general population during their hospital stay following delivery between 04/2012 and 05/ 2013. Ultrasound-based 1st trimester crown-rump length as well as 2nd and 3rd trimester abdominal circumference, head circumference,

FIGREF148.text: Skin barrier dysregulation contributes to disease severity in subjects with atopic dermatitis (AD). Zonulin is the only physiological protein established to regulate intercellular tight junctions of epithelial cells. To date, there is no data regarding the role of zonulin in the pathogenesis of AD. Objectives: We aimed to determine whether there is a difference in serum zonulin levels between children with AD and controls and clinical risk factors associated with the SCORing Atopic Dermatitis (SCORAD), a clinical tool used to assess the extent and severity of eczema, in children. The study included children aged 5-15 years; 115 AD patients and 140 controls. The study subjects underwent physical examination and the SCORAD index measurement by allergists. Structured questionnaires were completed by their parents and serum zonulin levels (ELISA) along with levels of total IgE and total eosinophil count and skin prick tests to 22 allergens were measured. Results: Children with AD had a significantly higher serum zonulin level compared with controls (11.0 [8.2-16.1] vs 7.8 [4.9-10.9] ng/ mL, P<.001). Children with a high SCORAD index (SCORAD index >20, 16.8 [8.5-22.2] ng/mL) had an increased zonulin level compared with those with a low SCORAD index (r=.28, P<.001). The multivariate logistic regression analysis showed that serum zonulin levels contributed independently to the SCORAD index after adjustment for confounding factors such as age, gender, BMI, family history of allergy, total IgE, total eosinophil count, and atopic sensitization (B=0.458, SE=0.129, P=.005).Conclusions: We provide the first evidence that serum zonulin may play a key role in skin barrier dysregulation in subjects with AD. 0431 | Eosinophil derived neurotoxin as a bio-marker of disease severity in severe atopic dermatitis Pediatrics, Seoul, South Korea; 2 College of Medicine, Seoul, South Korea; 3 The Catholic University of Korea, Seoul, South Korea Introduction: Eosinophils are encountered in many skin diseases but the role of eosinophils in the pathogenesis of atopic dermatitis (AD) remains uncertain.

FIGREF149.text: increased expression of TGF-b, or high proportion of Treg cells. 0433 | The use of the online patient portal for atopic dermatitis patients in daily practice; characteristics of portal users and non-users The prevalence of atopic dermatitis (AD) has increased 2-to 3-fold during the past decades and affects up to a fifth of the population in industrialized countries. The growing burden of chronic diseases on existing healthcare systems had led to an increasing interest for the development of eHealth solutions. The University Medical Centre Utrecht (UMCU) in the Netherlands has developed and implemented an online patient portal for AD patients offering the possibility of follow-up through e-consultations, insightin the medical record, online monitoring and education and self-management training. In a previous study was shown that follow-up through e-consultations is likely to reduce costs while being just as effective as regular face-to-face care.Objectives: The aim of the present study was to investigate the use of the online patient portal in daily practice and to characterize portal users and non-users. A prospective cohort study was con-ducted including adult AD patients who visited the outpatient clinic of the dermatology department for the first time. At baseline, all patients were offered access to the online patient portal and were informed about its functionalities. The follow-up period included 12 months to determine whether patients used the portal by sending an e-consultation and/or request an e-repeat prescription. Data were obtained from medical health records and questionnaires to characterize portal users and non-users. Multivariate logistic regression was performed to determine predictors for the use of the patient portal. Results: Of the 148 included patients, 41 patients (28%) used the patient portal by sending an e-consultation and/or request an erepeat prescription. In multivariate analysis, significant predictors for portal use included higher scores on 'self-monitoring and insight' were found in demographics, disease severity and quality of life; also no differences were found in the number of faceto-face consultations during follow-up between portal users and non-users. Conclusions: Twenty-eight percent of AD patients actively used the online eczema portal with higher use associated with high educational level and higher scores on 'self-monitoring and insight'. Characterization of portal users might help to optimize the use of digital tools in the management of AD. Funding: This work was supported by ZonMw grant number 945062181 0434 | Dietary intervention with a synbiotic mixture of scGOS/lcFOS with bifidobacterium breve M-16V in infants with atopic dermatitis shows beneficial immunological changes in 's Hospital Academic Medical Center, Department of Pediatric Respiratory Medicine and Allergy, Amsterdam, The Netherlands; 2 Utrecht Institute for Pharmaceutical Sciences, Faculty of Science, Utrecht University, Utrecht, The Netherlands; 3 University Medical Center Utrecht, Wilhelmina Children's Hospital, Department of Pediatric Immunology and Infectious Diseases, Utrecht, The Netherlands; 4 University Medical Center Utrecht, Department of Pediatric Immunology, Laboratory of Translational Immunology, Utrecht, The Netherlands; 5 VU University Medical Center, Department of Molecular Cell Biology and Immunology, Amsterdam, The Netherlands; 6 Nutricia Research, Utrecht, The Netherlands; 7 University Medical Centre Groningen, Department of Pediatric Pulmonology and Pediatric Allergology, Groningen, The Netherlands Introduction: Atopic Dermatitis (AD) is the most common chronic inflammatory skin disease in infancy with complex pathology, associated with high levels of Th2 chemokines (CCL17, CCL22).

FIGREF150.text: control) or with scGOS/lcFOS and B. breve M-16V (active) on Atopic Dermatitis in INfanTs (SAINT-study ISRCTN NTR3447), was assessed. Infants with objective-SCORAD (score >20), up to and including 11 months of age, with elevated total-IgE and/or specific-IgE levels were included (n=31) to receive 4 months of dietary ABSTRACTS | 309

FIGREF151.text: After 4 months of dietary intervention the objective-SCORAD decreased within both groups (control; À6.79AE6.40 vs active; À9.13AE9.80 (meanAESD)). Irrespective of dietary intervention, changes in Th2 chemokines (CCL17, CCL20 and CCL22) as well as the Th1 chemokine (CXCL9) were detected. Chemokine CCL17 significantly correlated (r=.4464, P<.001) to objective-SCORAD obtained during the study. The synbiotic intervention resulted in a significantly (P<.01) higher CXCL9 as compared to control diet (control; 1.95 (1.77-2.43) vs active: 2.33 (1.99-2.89) (log10 median (range)) after 4 months of intervention. In addition, the Th2/Th1 chemokine ratio's showed that CCL-17/CXCL9, CCL-22/CXCL9, CCL20/CXCL10 and CCL20/CXCL11 were reduced due to the synbiotic intervention. Conclusions: In conclusion, these data contribute to immune biomarker profiling and the understanding of complexity in pathology of AD in infants early in life. Moreover, although the study is small and exploratory of nature, dietary intervention with scGOS/lcFOS and B. breve M16V in infants with AD suggest improvement of Th2/Th1 balances, skewing away from allergic phenotype.

FIGREF152.text: These results confirm the role of nickel in triggering or maintaining inflammatory reaction for patient suffering from dyshidrosis associated with nickel contact allergy. this study also suggest a potential new approach to address dyshidrosis and possibly related dermatosis with a metal-scavenging protective cream and a non-occlusive emollient 0436 | Optimized growth conditions for malassezia Spp. improves research on its role in atopic dermatitis Leong C; Buttafuoco A; Schmid-Grendelmeier P; Bosshard PP; Glatz M Allergy Unit, Department of Dermatology, University and University Hospital of Zurich, Zurich, Switzerland Introduction: Malassezia spp. is a genus of lipophilic yeasts, comprising 14 species. It is the most common fungal genus of the healthy human skin microbiome but it is also attributed a pathogenic role in skin diseases such as atopic dermatitis (AD). AD is a frequent, recurrent eczematous skin disease that commonly associates with other atopic diseases such as hay fever, asthma and food allergies.To date, 14 immunogenic proteins of Malassezia spp. are characterized, that are predominantly produced by potentially pathogenic species, such as M. sympodialis. These proteins induce an IgE-or T cellmediated immune response in humans that may contribute to skin inflammation in AD. Little is known on the exact pathogenic mechanisms, and if Malassezia species change protein production in the altered environment of human atopic skin. Cultivation of Malassezia spp. is a desirable tool to investigate these disease-contributing mechanisms. However, Malassezia is a fastidious fungus that barely growths on standard agars, what hampers research. Objectives: We aimed to (i) examine the lipid preferences and (ii) to optimize culture conditions of Malassezia species. 28 strains isolated from human skin were used for the analysis. The strains represented five species with a supposed pathogenic role in skin diseases: M. sympodialis, M. restricta, M. globosa, M. slooffiae and M. furfur. Species identity was confirmed by sequencing. Strains were plated on various agar media (Leeming Notman, Sabouraud Dextrose, Tween 60-Esculin, Cremophor EL, mDixon) to determine their media preferences. To assess lipid preferences, commonly used culture media components (eg, tweens, olive oil, oleic acid) and human sebum components (eg squalene, cholesterol) were added in varying concentrations. Results: The mono-unsaturated lipid, oleic acid was the single most effective lipid to improve growth of all investigated Malassezia species. Other additives provided non-essential growth enhancement. Incubation time could be shortened to 2-4 days (vs 2-4 weeks) with only slight differences between species. Conclusions: We optimized cultivation of all relevant Malassezia species with reduced cultivation time on a single agar. This will enable (i) proteomic analyzes of Malassezia species under culture conditions resembling atopic skin, and (ii) the investigation of interaction between Malassezia spp. and human immune cells to elucidate the pathogenic contribution of Malassezia spp. to AD and other atopic diseases. 0437 | Emollient therapy alters barrier function and skin microbes in infants at risk for developing atopic dermatitis , Center for Cancer Research, NCI, NIH, Bethesda, United States; 2 Biometric Research Branch, Division of Cancer Treatment and Diagnostics, NCI, NIH, Bethesda, United States; 3 Department of Dermatology, Oregon Health and Science University, Portland, United States Introduction: Atopic dermatitis (AD) begins in early childhood and is characterized by impaired skin barrier and shifts in the skin microbiome. Skin emollients are commonly used to protect and repair the defective skin barrier in AD.

FIGREF153.text: Long-term emollient therapy is associated with altered skin barrier function and shifts of skin microbiome in infants with a high risk for AD. Additional studies are needed to understand how alterations in streptococci may contribute to the therapeutic effects of emollients in AD.0438 | Preliminary blinded study on the use of emollient products and detergents based on Sacha Inchi oil, in children affected by mild-moderate atopic dermatitis Pharmacology and Therapeutic Research, Italian National Institute of Health, Rome, Italy Introduction: The Atopic Dermatitis (AD) is a multifactorial genetic disorder, with a prevalence of 20% during childhood, characterized by intense skin inflammation with chronic-relapsing evolution and intense itching. The pathogenesis is not yet completely clarified, and no curative therapy exists. The elective therapeutic is to achieve and maintain skin improvement and itch control, basically through daily use of emollients and specific detergents for restoring of the barrier functions.Objectives: To restore the anomalous composition of polyunsaturated fatty acids, typical of the AD, we have conducted a preliminary blinded study on children with AD combined with daily use of emol-lient and detergent products (by SanaMedica Group) composed of Sacha Inchi Oil (polyunsaturated fatty acids: 98%, Omega3: 54%, Omega6: 33.4%, Omega9: 7.2%, Vitamin E with high lipophilicity 5.4%). The enlisted 18 children (average age 4-8 years: SCORAD index till 30, with annual relapses >4) were randomized and allocated in a blinded Group A (active molecule) or Group B (placebo). Each child was evaluated at when inserted (T0), after two months of the application of the products (T1) and after one month from the suspension of the treatments. At time T0 it was explained how to apply daily the products in adequate quantity and delivered a clinical diary to the overall clinical Assessment. Primary objective: For both groups the data related to SCORAD, itching/pruritus and insomnia/ sleep problems were evaluated. Analyzes of SCORAD variable demonstrated a significant improvement of the patients in Group A compared to patients in Group B at the times T1 (P=.0004) and T2 (0.002). At time T0 it was observed no significant difference of the SCORAD between the two Groups, evidence of the substantial homogeneity of the allocated patients in the two Groups. The itchiness improves significantly in Group A at time T2 (P=.004). The insomnia has a significant improvement in Group A at time T1(P=.01), with further increase at time T2 (P=.004). The data were analyzed using the one-way Student's T-Tests for unpaired groups with difference variance. Conclusions: The use of Oil Sacha Inchi has shown significant clinical effectiveness both in the short and long term. The treatment was well tolerated by all with an excellent safety profile. 0439 | Long-term treatment with low-dose medicine in chronic childhood eczema. A doubleblind two-stage randomized control trial Pediatric Allergy, San Pietro Hospital Fatebenefratelli, Rome, Italy; 2 Clinical Research Unit, Guna S.p.A., Italy, Milan, Italy; 3 Clinical Research Unit, Guna S.p.A., Italy, Italy; 4 Department of Pharmacology and Therapeutic Research, Italian National Institute of Health, Milan, Italy; 5 Department of Pediatric Allergy, San Pietro Hospital Fatebenefratelli, Italy; 6 Department of Pharmacology and Therapeutic Research, Italian National Institute of Health, Rome, Italy; 7 San Pietro Fatebenefratelli hospital, Rome, Italy Introduction: Eczema is the most frequent chronic inflammatory condition in childhood; indeed it affects up to 20% of children and starts in the first years of life. Conventional treatment of moderate/ severe eczema may not be sufficient to control the activity of skin lesions, and a small subset of children require more aggressive systemic therapy which is not without side effects. Low-dose medicine (LDM) exerts pharmacomodulatory activity that can restore the homeostatic balance between the various lymphocyte populations, particularly in allergic and inflammatory diseases. The efficacy of low-dose medicine (LDM) in childhood mild/moderate eczema is not known. We conducted a double-blind, two-stage randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trial, lasting 23 months, to address this issue. Objectives: The purpose of our double-blind, two-stage randomized clinical trial was to assess the clinical efficacy and safety of long-term LDM treatment in children affected by mild/moderate chronic eczema. Eighty children with chronic mild/moderate eczema were randomly allocated to Group A (placebo) or Group B (treatment group; Galium-Heel ® , Guna-Interleukin 12 and Guna-The decrease in disease severity was greater in Group B than in Group A already in stage 1 (a decrease of 64% vs 53.2%). Moreover, subjective symptoms (itching and sleep disturbances) initially decreased and then worsened in Group A, whereas itching decreased linearly and sleep disturbances decreased significantly (P=.049) in Group B. Conclusions: This study provides the first evidence that LDM is a valid support to conventional treatment in children affected by chronic mild/moderate eczema. Low-dose medicine had good longterm clinical efficacy (reduction of skin lesions, itching and sleeplessness); its benefit persisted during follow-up; it resulted in a reduced intake of symptomatic therapy, was well tolerated and had a good safety profile. 0440 | The overnight use of a temperaturecontrolled laminar airflow (TLA) device has sustained benefit for children with severe eczema London, London, United Kingdom; 3 Cambridge University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, Cambridge, United Kingdom Introduction: Children with very severe, persistent eczema have limited treatment options, and often require systemic immunosuppression. Effective new treatments are urgently required.

FIGREF154.text: and Investigator Global Assessment (IGA, 0-5 scale) as primary outcome measures; secondary outcomes included child/family dermatology quality of life (CDQLI, FDQLI) and Patient Oriented Eczema Measure (POEM). Changes in outcomes were evaluated using Wilcoxon signed rank test (2-sided significance at <.1) and cluster analysis for longitudinal data.

FIGREF155.text: Conclusions: TLA treatment leads to a significant clinical improvement in children with severe eczema, with accompanying reduction in medication usage. Further work identifying predictors of response, and a randomized controlled trial are urgently required.0441 | Treatment of chronic spontaneous urticaria and angioedema with 5aminosalicylateBarber CM; Kalicinsky CUniversity of Manitoba, Winnipeg, CanadaIntroduction: Treatment of antihistamine refractory chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU) remains challenging, many patients require prolonged courses of glucocorticoids. Therapies that have randomized control evidence are expensive, difficult to access, and have significant side effects. There remains a medication gap between evidence-based first line and second or third line agents. We sought to evaluate the efficacy, and adverse reactions of 5-ASA used as adjunctive therapy for patients with antihistamine refractory CSU.Results:A retrospective chart review was conducted of twenty-five adult patients with 5-ASA treated antihistamine refractory chronic spontaneous urticaria at the Adult Allergy and Clinical Immunology Clinic at the Winnipeg Health Sciences Centre from 2005 to 2016. Three patients were excluded from the final analysis. Consent was obtained via ethics approval granted by the University of Manitoba Research Ethics Board (H2016:076) and the Health Sciences Research Impact Committee (RI2016:026).Seventeen (81%) patients exhibited either a complete or partial response. Eleven (52.4%) attained complete remission; six (28.6%) patients had a partial response. Complete resolution was defined as resolution of urticaria, angioedema and pruritus; partial response was defined as decreased frequency of urticaria, angioedema and pruritus, or the ability to taper glucocorticoids at a dose of 5-ASA equal to or less than 1000 milligrams twice daily. Four (19%) patients failed, as defined by no improvement or discontinuation in favour of alternative therapy following a minimum of 4 weeks of 5-ASA. Five (23.8%) patients were able to entirely taper off of all medications following treatment with 5-ASA. Eleven of twelve (91.7%) of patients utilizing glucocorticoids prior to 5-ASA were able to successfully discontinue their use. Adverse events occurred in six (28.6%) patients, two (9.5%) required discontinuation; one for pancytopenia, the other for arthralgias.Conclusions: 5-ASA appears to be an efficacious, well tolerated, and safe adjunctive therapy for antihistamine refractory CSU. The rate of adverse events in this case series conflicts with data from the literature, where 5-ASA demonstrates a significantly lower incidence of adverse events. The sample size limits conclusions. We showed that extensively hydrolyzed casein formula containing the probiotic L. rhamnosus GG (EHCF+LGG) stimulates tolerance acquisition in children with cow milk allergy (CMA).Objectives: We aimed to investigate tolerogenic immune and nonimmune mechanisms elicited by LGG-derived CpG immunostimulatory DNA sequence (ODN ID35) and by the three most abundant bcasein-derived peptides contained in the formula. Immune mechanisms were investigated in PBMCs from children with challenge-proven IgE-mediated CMA (all Caucasian; mean age 2.4, range 1-5 years) stimulated with beta-lactoglobulin (b-LG; 100 lg/mL) in the presence or absence of ODN ID35 (1 lmol L À1 ) for 24 h. Production and DNA methylation rate of interleukin (IL)-L4, IL-5, IL-10 and IFNc were assessed by ELISA and HRM Real Time PCR, respectively. Non-immune mechanisms were investigated in human enterocytes (Caco-2) stimulated with ODN ID35 (1 lmol L À1 ) and with b-caseinderived peptides (b-CN) 60-69, b-CN 110-113, b-CN 193-209 (500 lg/mL). Cell growth was assessed by colorimetric assay (MTT (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide); mucus production was analyzed by histochemistry after culture. Mucin 2 (MUC2) and tight junction proteins (zonulin and occludin) were analyzed by Real Time PCR using enterocytes RNA. Results: PBMCs stimulation with ODN ID35 resulted in a significant decrease in IL-4 and IL-5 production and in an increase of DNA methylation rate of the two cytokines. Instead, the stimulation with ODN ID35 increased IL-10 and IFN-c production but was unable to modulate DNA methylation rate of these cytokines. ODN ID35 stimulated mucus production and MUC2 expression in human enterocytes. The three b-casein-derived peptides regulated cell growth and MUC2; b-CN 193-209 alone was able to regulate zonulin and occludin expression. Conclusions: Through a direct interaction with human cells, LGG DNA and b-casein-derived peptides regulates immune and nonimmune mechanisms involved in tolerance acquisition. IG, CNG, Evry, France; 2 DBV Technologies, Paris, France; 3 Necker Hospital, Paris, France; 4 DBV Technologies, New York, United States Introduction: Epicutaneous immunotherapy (EPIT) is a safe treatment for food allergy. In animal models, EPIT protection seems to confer sustained unresponsiveness and prevents further sensitization. We have previously shown DNA methylation changes in key transcription factors to be associated with EPIT and sustained unresponsiveness. Objectives: This study investigates the kinetics of miRNA expression patterns underlying the therapeutic effect of EPIT and its persistence. BALB/c mice were orally sensitized to peanut and then treated with EPIT or not treated (sham). Mice (n=112) were sacrificed during treatment at 1, 2, 4, 6 and 8 weeks; and 8 weeks after the end of treatment. MiRNAs were analysed in sorted CD4 + cells from spleen using high-throughput sequencing on a HiSeq4000 to a depth of 200M bases / sample and validated by qPCR. Results: Global miRNA profiles consisting of 800-1000 miRNAs reproducibly detected in the CD4 samples distinguished EPIT-treated mice from controls as early as one week following initiation of treatment. Intra-group variability of miRNA expression profiles was much reduced in the EPIT group at all time points. Between 23 and 190MiRNAs were found to be differentially expressed at p adj <.05 with a large overlap of miRNAs between adjacent time points. Differentially expressed miRNAs include miRNAs controlling T cell stability and plasticity (eg, Tregs, miR-10a) and Th2 cytokine production (eg, miR-92a-3p and miR-423-5p). 34 miRNAs were differentially expressed eight weeks after the end of the treatment, of which 24 (70%)showed similar expression changes at the end of treatment.Conclusions: EPIT leads to homogeneous changes in miRNA expression profiles shortly after the initiation of treatment differentiating EPIT-treated mice from sham-treated control mice and expression changes are maintained following the termination of treatment.Differentially expressed miRNAs include miRNAs in T cell plasticity and postulated targets include genes previously associated with allergy and asthma. Our study provides further evidence for the molecular alterations underlying sustained unresponsiveness in EPIT.

FIGREF163.text: 0463 | Omalizumab treated patients experience good subjective effect on symptoms and quality of life-results from a nurse initiated real-life interview investigation Pedersen LM; Devantier A; Skjold T; Schmid JM Department of Respiratory Medicine and Allergy, Aarhus University Hospital, Aarhus, Denmark Introduction: Omalizumab is an effective treatment option in severe allergic asthma and chronic spontaneous urticaria. Objectives: To investigate patients' experienced treatment effect in a real-life cohort of omalizumab treated patients. Methods: We interviewed 26 consecutive patients (male: 10, female: 16) treated with omalizumab in our outpatient clinic for either severe allergic asthma (n=8), chronic spontaneous urticaria (n=12), severe allergy (n=3), anaphylaxis (n=2) or nasal polyposis (n=1), focusing on their subjective experience regarding changes in symptoms and quality of life from before starting omalizumab treatment and after a minimum of 4 months of treatment. We used a 5point visual analogue scale from 0 to 4 points (0: very severely impaired; 1: severely impaired, 2: moderately impaired; 3: slightly impaired; 4: not impaired) to ask patients for the impact of symptoms and the impact of their disease on quality of life. Patients reported an improvement of their quality of life by a median of 3 points (IQR 2; 3), again, patients treated for urticaria reported a greater improvement of their quality of life (Median 3, IQR 3; 3.5) than patients treated for other conditions (Median 3, 2; 3, P=.13). Conclusions: Patients treated with omalizumab experienced a significant improvement of their symptoms and in their quality of life. Patients treated for urticaria had a slightly better subjective effect as compared to patients treated for other conditions. 0464 | Distance to treatment centre has an impact on number of patients treated with omalizumab-results from a nurse initiated real-life cohort study Devantier A; Pedersen LM; Skjold T; Schmid JM Department of Respiratory Medicine and Allergy, Aarhus University Hospital, Aarhus, Denmark Introduction: Omalizumab is an effective treatment option in severe allergic asthma and chronic spontaneous urticaria. In the Central Region of Denmark, omalizumab treatment is given at the highly specialized centre for allergy and asthma at Aarhus University Hospital Objectives: To investigate, if distance to the treatment centre influences on the number of patients treated with omalizumab.

FIGREF164.text: Omalizumab administration in asthmatic individuals has been shown to reduce viral induced exacerbation. We sought to determine if omalizumab administration in refractory to H1 antihistamines chronic urticaria (CU) patients prevents respiratory illnesses, independently of their atopic status. Objectives: In this longitudinal cohort study, all respiratory illnesses from all CU patients under regular omalizumab administration (300 mg Q4-weeks) from at least November 2015 until October 2016 were prospectively recorded. Patients with history of known respiratory conditions, like asthma, allergic rhinitis, chronic rhinitis/ rhinosinusitis, or any type of immunodeficiency were excluded. All patients were followed up every 4 weeks at each omalizumab administration. The closest in age, healthy household member (spouse, partner, relative, roommate etc), when available, was used as a control individual. Results: Thirty three patients (21 women) 45.1AE16.6 years old and 30 age-matched control subjects (9 women, 46.6AE9.6 years old) were enrolled. The CU-patients reported significantly less respiratory illnesses as compared with the control subjects (median: 0 vs 1, inter-quartile range 0-1 vs 1-1, min-max: 0-3 vs 0-4, respectively, P-value=.0095). The vaccination rate for influenza viruses was similar between patients and controls. Conclusions: Omalizumab administration prevents common respiratory illnesses in CU patients even in the absence of any respiratory disorder or allergic sensitization. This finding suggests indirectly a role of IgE in the clinical expression of a respiratory infection independently of the patient's atopic status and implies the potential prophylactic role anti-IgE may have in this direction. Subcutaneous allergen immunotherapy (SCIT) is a well-documented treatment for allergic disease which involves injections of native allergen or modified (allergoid) extracts. The use of allergoid vaccines is a growing sector of the allergy immunotherapy market, associated with shorter-course therapy. The aim of this study was the structural and immunological characterisation of group 1 (Lol p 1) IgG binding epitopes within a complex grass allergoid formulation containing rye grass.Objectives: HP-SEC was used to resolve grass allergoids of high molecular weight into several distinct fractions with defined molecular weight and elution profiles. Allergen verification of the modified preparations was confirmed by mass spectrometry analysis. IgE and IgG immunoreactivity of the allergoid preparations was explored and Lol p 1-specific IgG epitopes mapped by SPOT synthesis technology (PepSpot TM ) with structural analysis based on a Lol p 1 homology model.

FIGREF165.text: , Moscow, Russia; 2 Institute of Immunophysiology, Moscow, Russia Introduction: Development of personified dendritic cell antitumor vaccines(PDAV) against bladder cancer (BC) is a relevant problem, Operative material from 54 patients with muscular invasive and non-invasive forms of BC, out of which only 10 were consistently transferred for creation of cellular tumorous cultures, was used in the work. UCC cultures were researched at early (before 10) and later (over 30) passages. Preparations were analyzed with consideration for international classification of chromosomes (Ch). As a clone, 2-3 cells with identical damages were reviewed, and in case of monosomy (absence of the same Ch), there must be not less than 3 of these cells. Number of analyzed cells depended on the quantity of identified clones and lied within the range from 20 to 100. CTA expression was evaluated by flow cytometry method. Mathematical processing was performed with the use of SPSS 23.0 Results: It was established, that all researched tumor cultures had cytogenetic changes peculiar to BC. Mostly, the following changes were identified: deletion of 9 Ch (66.7%), absence of Y Ch (50%) and monosomy of 13 Ch (33.3%). In rare cases changes in 1, 3, 7 Ch, monosomy of 17 Ch, trisomy of 7 Ch were detected. Comparative studies showed that in case of prolonged passaging in a part of cultures, significant increase of the number of genetic changes in a form of division of previously homogeneous population into subclones differing in ploidy (up to 56 Ch) and quantity of changed Ch is observed. After comparison of the results with data, obtained by flow cytometry method, certain correlation of these changes to decrease of CTA expression (GAGE, BAGE, MAGE и NY-ESO-1) (P<.05) was established. Particular cultures in the course of multiple transits preserved cytogenetic profile and consistent CTA expression, which makes them promising for preparation of antitumor vaccines in case of BC. Conclusions: In case of creation of PDAV against BC, it is necessary to use autologous tumor cells at early passages of their cultivation, or allogenic cell cultures, marked by cytogenetic consistency and stable expression of tumor-associated antigens. 0474 | M1 and M2 macrophage gene methylation profiles in patients with kawasaki disease Guo MM; Hsieh K; Lo M; Huang Y; Chang L; Kuo H Kaohsiung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, Kaohsiung, Taiwan

The objective of our research was to evaluate the significance of ADRb2 gene polymorphism in the 16th amino acid position in the efficiency of broncholytic therapy by b2-agonists among children with bronchial asthma. Objectives: We examined 208 children 5-17 years of age with atopic bronchial asthma (BA), moderate and severe, who resided in the European part of Russia and were Russian by nationality. All patients received b2-agonists short-acting in the period of exacerbation of BA. 171 patients received anti-inflammatory therapy with inhaled corticosteroids (IGCs) in average and high daily dose. The patients were divided into two groups depending on the efficiency of the treatment with b2-agonists short-acting in the period of exacerbation of BA: group 1-with a positive effect, the group 2-therapy a little or ineffective. All patients underwent genotyping DNA using PCR Real Team.

The 5 weeks program intervention consist in 10 educational animated videos regarding several lecture topics as definitions, signs and symptoms of food allergy, allergens information, prevention, diagnose and treatment, label-reading, cross-contact, psychological impact, anaphylaxis and procedures in case of an emergency adapted from the Food Allergy education manuals for Schools and Restaurants published by Portuguese Directorate-General of Health, in partnership with Faculty of Nutrition and Faculty of Medicine of University of Porto. FIGREF171.text: Dietary avoidance is the only approved treatment for children with egg allergy, and especially for young children. We evaluated low dose ingestion of egg without elevation of dosing for treatment of children with egg allergy. Objectives: To compare the efficacies of low dose ingestion of egg on alternate days (low dose group) and complete elimination therapy (elimination group) in children with egg allergy. Methods: In this randomized controlled study, children with egg allergy aged 8 to <36 months received low dose ingestion of egg (1/ 32nd of a heated whole egg) on alternate days or complete elimination therapy. Egg allergy was confirmed based on clear positive objective symptoms in an oral food challenge test with 1/8th of a whole egg, ingestion of the same amount of egg by mistake, or the titer of ovomucoid-specific IgE antibody at a >95% positive predictive value on the probability curve. At randomization, all participants passed the oral food challenge with 1/32nd of a whole egg. At 24 weeks, the children underwent an oral food challenge with 1/8th of a whole egg.

This paper documents the protocol underway, lessons learned regarding the importance of involving stakeholders in an integrated knowledge translation process, the facilitators and barriers to process and practice change, and the transferrable learnings to other jurisdictions.
