FIGREF175.text: A total of 264 subjects with asthma (age 10-35 years) from the MIDAS cohort with IgE sensitisation to cat dander extract (≥0.1 kU A /L), were analysed for IgE to the cat allergen components secretoglobin (Fel d 1), serum albumin (Fel d 2), and lipocalins (Fel d 4, Fel d 7). We performed multiple linear regression analyses on logarithmic values in order to study the independent associations between IgE-antibody concentrations and the outcome measures fraction of exhaled nitric oxide (FeNO) and blood eosinophil (B-Eos) count. IgE specificities with a moderate-strong correlation to one another (r>.5) were excluded from the same model. Of the 264 catsensitised asthmatics, 230 were sensitised (≥0.1 kU A /L) to Fel d 1, 50 to Fel d 2, 135 to Fel d 4 and 123 to Fel d 7. Further, 28% were mono-sensitised to Fel d 1 whereas mono-sensitisation to the other cat components was less than 5%. In univariate analyses, IgE antibodies against cat dander extract and all cat allergen components were significantly related to the three outcome variables. In multivariate analyses, correcting for gender, age, height, smoking and controller medications, Fel d 2 IgE-antibody concentration remained significantly related to higher FeNO (P=.012) and Fel d 4 IgE antibodies to higher Β-Eos count (P=.009). Cat lipocalins (sum of Fel d 4 and Fel d 7) as independent variable was positively associated with FeNO (P=.045). Neither Fel d 1 nor IgE to cat dander extract were independently related to B-Eos or FeNO (P=.23-0.51).

TABREF9.text: 0539 | Identification, purification and quantification of 20.2 kd IgE binding major allergen of aspergillus fumigatus for quality control Vermani M 1 ; Vijayan VK 2 ; Agarwal MK 2 Amity University Uttar Pradesh, Noida, India; 2 VP Chest Institute, Delhi, India Introduction: Airborne Aspergillus fumigatus is an important source of inhalant allergens. Current allergy diagnostic and therapeutic modalities employ crude non-standardized allergen extracts. Standardization of allergen extracts is crucial for improving their quality, key issue in diagnosis and therapy. We report a study on identification, purification and quantification of a 20.2 kd major allergen of A fumigatus to serve as a reference reagent for the standardization of crude extracts.Objectives: Major allergens of A fumigatus were identified by performing immunoblots using sensitized patients' sera. Purification of one major allergenic protein of crude extract was undertaken by subjecting it to salt precipitation, anion exchange column chromatography and fast protein liquid chromatography (FPLC).Results: In immunoblots, 12 IgE binding proteins were detected, four being major allergens of A fumigatus-90, 83, 34, 20.2 kd. The 20.2 kd component detected with maximum number of positive patients' sera was purified to apparent homogeneity. The precipitate recovered on 80% ammonium sulfate precipitation of crude extract was subjected to anion exchange chromatography (DEAE-Sephacel) which yielded three fractions. The 20.2 kd component was detected in Afu-Fr1 with standard methods. Further, Afu-Fr1 was subjected to FPLC using a pre-packed mono-Q column. The eluates were pooled into five fractions. The 20.2 kd band was observed in Afu-F1a. Rechromatography of Afu-Fr1a again resulted in a single peak. At each step, allergenic activity was evaluated by EAST inhibition and immunoblots. For quantification of the purified allergen in crude extract, EAST inhibition assays with the sera pool of A fumigatus allergic patients were standardized. A dose-related inhibition was obtained in Afu-Fr1a EAST with Afu-Fr1a (purified protein) as well as the crude extract. Dose of purified protein and the crude extract required for 50% inhibition worked out to be 23.7 and 1599 ng, respectively. Thus, the concentration of purified protein (20.2 kd) in crude lyophilized A fumigatus extract worked out to be 14.8 lg/mg.Conclusions: Thus, the 20.2 kd major allergen of A fumigatus has been purified to apparent homogeneity. The inhibition assays to quantify this purified allergen in crude extracts have been standardized. To ensure appropriate biopotency of crude A fumigatus extract, 20.2 kd protein may be used as a reference reagent for quality control.0540 | Comparison of cat and dog allergen concentrations on electrostatic dust collectors in offices and homesSander I 1 ; Sauke-Gensow U 2 ; Czibor C 1 ; Zahradnik E 1 ; Flagge A 1 ; F€ orster M 2 ; Husert D 2 ; Dreyer J 2 ; Fritsch N 2 ; Schmidt W 2 ; Petersen J 2 ; Br€ uning T 1 ; Raulf M 1 Institut f€ ur Pr€ avention und Arbeitsmedizin der DGUV, Institut der Ruhr-Universit€ at Bochum, IPA, Bochum, Germany;Introduction: Pet allergens are not exclusively present in pet owners' homes but are transferred to workplaces and dwellings without pets.Objectives: Aim of the study was to compare pet allergen concentrations in airborne settled dust from offices and office workers' homes.Methods:Electrostatic dust collectors (EDCs) which are developed for passive sampling of airborne particles and are useful in large population studies were placed for 14 days four times a year in five office buildings in Hamburg and Berlin (67 rooms, 436 EDCs), and in parallel in the office workers' homes (145 rooms, 404 EDCs). The samples were extracted and analysed with fluorescence enzymeimmunoassays based on monoclonal antibodies (Indoor Biotechnologies, Charlottesville, US) to Fel d 1 (major cat allergen) and Can f 1 (major dog allergen). Pet allergen thresholds that discriminate samples from homes with cat or dog from the ones without these pets were calculated using receiver-operator characteristics and Youden indices. Samples were grouped according to presence of pets in homes and presence of pet owners in offices and compared by Kruskal-Wallis test.Results: In homes with cats or dogs, 99% or 100% of samples con-tained Fel d 1 (median 1270 ng/m²) or Can f 1 (median 842 ng/m²), respectively. In homes without cats 33% of samples had Fel d 1 (max. 175 ng/m²), and in homes without dogs only 23% were positive for Can f 1 (max. 287 ng/m²). In offices with cat owners, 71% of samples were positive for Fel d 1 (median 16.5, max. 561 ng/m²). In offices with dog owners, 43% of samples were positive for Can f 1 (max. 167 ng/m²). In offices without cat owners, 21% of samples were positive for Fel d 1 (max. 97 ng/m²), and in offices without dog owners, 12% contained Can f 1 (max. 55 ng/m²). The threshold level for presence of dogs in homes was 100 ng/m² Can f 1 (100% sensitivity, 99.2% specificity) and for presence of cats in homes was 59 ng/m² Fel d 1 (96.1% sensitivity, 98.8% specificity). In offices only 3 out of 436 EDCs samples had Can f 1 loads above 100 ng/ m², but 33 samples had Fel d 1 loads above 59 ng/m².Conclusions:Cat and dog allergens seem to be transferred from pet owners to their offices. Offices with pet owners had significantly higher allergen concentrations than homes without the respective pet or offices without pet owners. However, exposure to dog and cat allergens in offices rarely reached levels of households with pets.0541 | Comparison of quality of life and local inflammatory/atopy markers in smoking vs non smoking patients with allergic rhinitisGomez RM 1 ; Muiño JC 2 ; Zernotti ME 3 ; Croce VH 4 Fundaci on Ayre, Salta, Argentina; 2 Faculty of Medicine UNC, C ordoba, Argentina; 3 Faculty of Medicine UCC, C ordoba, Argentina; 4 Instituto Modelo Cardiolog ıa, C ordoba, Argentina Introduction: Exposure to tobacco smoke was reported to provoke increased parameters of Atopy and Allergic Rhinitis (AR) symptoms; on the other hand, non significant differences in nasal symptoms and quality of life (QoL) was described as well in AR patients who smoke. Objectives: Given this duality, we aimed to evaluate QoL and local IgE, IL17 and IL33 levels as representative parameters among active smokers (Smk) and nonsmokers (NonSmk) having AR. and Methods: Cross-sectional study in adult volunteers comparing Smk and NonSmk AR patients. Status of smoking was confirmed by salivary cotinine measurements. QoL was compared using Mini-RQLQ questionnaire. IgE, IL33 and IL 17 were measured in nasal lavage by ELISA. Statistical analysis included T test and Mann Whitney U (Anova 2way). Values of P<.05 were considered significant.Results: Twenty two patients per group, mean age 37.3 years (Smk) and 30.4 (NonSmk) were studied, with no significant differ-ence in age, sex or allergen sensitization. Statistically significant differences in salivary cotinine levels (P<.0001) were found. Local IgE obtained in Smk: 3.41 kU/L (AE6.20 SD) and in NonSmk: 4.68 kU/L (AE7.34 SD); IL 17 in Smk: 16.46 pg/ml (AE24.18) and in NonSmk: 24.65 pg/ml (AE71.49); and IL33 in Smk: 57.50 pg/ml (AE99.47) and in NonSmk: 144.55 pg/ml (AE169.62). MiniRQLQ QoL mean scores were in Smk: 3.39 AE1.01 and in NonSmk: 3.70 AE0.74. P values for all comparisons were non-significant. Conclusions: Active smokers AR patients do not show a worsening in both their QoL and local atopic inflammatory parameters, compared to non-smokers. Even not resulting statistically significant, there is a clear trend of reduced IL33 levels on smokers. 0542 | Anti-allergic effect of intranasal vitamin D treatment by inhibiting dendritic cell activation in the allergic rhinitis mouse model Cho S; Zhang Y; Rhee C; Kim D Seoul National University College of Medicine, Seoul, South Korea

TABREF10.text: Th2 mediated inflammation. 0543 | Appropriate treatment can reduce vitamin D deficiency in children with vernal keratoconjunctivitis Bruschi G 1 ; Ghiglioni DG 2 ; Benatti E 1 ; Osnaghi SG 2 ; Marchisio PG 1 Universit a degli Studi di Milano Fondazione IRCCS Ca' Granda Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico, Milan, Italy; 2 Fondazione IRCCS Ca' Granda Ospedale Maggiore Policlinico, Milan, ItalyIntroduction: Children with Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) show symptoms like other ocular allergopathy, but amplified: photophobia, itching eyes, mucoid secretion, conjuntival hyperemia, frequently with watering eyes, foreign body sensation, palpebral pseudoptosis and pain. Symptoms are controlled by local cortisonic. Anthistaminic, antiflammatory therapy and mastocyte stabilizers are useful only in mild forms. For the last 20 years, in order to avoid excessive and extended use of local cortisonic eyedrops, galenic eyedrops of cyclosporine at 1-2% concentration and tacrolimus at 0.1% of concentration were introduced as treatment in the severe and ABSTRACTS | 177unresponsive forms. Due to the main symptoms of VKC occur most frequently during spring and tend to get worse during summer months, affected children tend to avoid sun exposition, potentially compromising cutaneous productions of vitamin D.

TABREF11.text: : In 2016, in our Paediatric Allergology Clinic of Pediatric Highly Intensive Care University Study of Milan and Oculistic surgery (Fondazione IRCCS Policlinico of Milan), we treated 59 children with cyclosporine eyedrops (first group) and 11 children with tacrolimus eyedrops 0.1% (second group); vitamin D levels were measured in spring and autumn. Before the summer period, the average vitamin level was 23.97 AE 13.82 ng/ml (2 ds) in the first group, and 23.56 AE 10.42 ng/ml (2 ds) in the second group. At the end of summer period, instead, the average levels were, respectively, 33.47 AE 17.89 ng/ml and 35.42 AE 20.55 ng/ml. While, in spring, 44.06% of cyclosporine-treated children revealed a mild vitamin D deficiency, and 33.9% severe deficiency (< a 20 ng/ml), at the end of the summer season these percentages decreased to, respectively, 35.6% and 5.08%. In the second group, vitamin D levels evolved as follows: before summer, 54.4% of children revealed mild deficiency and 27.2% severe deficiency. After summer, mild and severe deficiency rates were 27.3% and 0%.Conclusions: Both cyclosporine and tacrolimus treatments appear to allow a solar exposition sufficient to increase vitamin D levels in blood in children with VKC. If the VKC is controlled with the pharmacologic therapy, solar exposure allows to correct the lack of vitamin D.ASTHMA IMMUNOPATHOLOGY/INFLAMMATION/MECHANISM0544 | The significance of selected smad proteins in the mediation of inflammation in asthma in response to a specific and non-specific triggers Introduction: Asthma is a chronic disease of the respiratory tract, in which various cytokines, including TGF-ß, are responsible for inflammation and remodeling. SMAD protein family plays a crucial role in the TGF-ß signalling pathway, as they are necessary for intracellular signal transduction. SMAD2 and SMAD3 are responsible for signal transduction from TGF-ß receptors (TGF-ßRI/RII).SMAD 1, 5, 8 transduct the signal from Bone Morphogenetic Protein Receptors (BMPRs).

Recently, eosinophil extracellular DNA traps (EET) were detected in asthmatic airways; however, their roles in SA have not been investigated.Objectives: We used confocal microscopy to evaluate the levels of autophagy and EET from PBEs of SA in comparison to non-severe asthma (NSA) patients. TABREF18.text: ).Serum morning cortisol concentrations; Total IgE [normal values <100 IU/ml] and specific IgE anti D.farinae, P.americana and Ascaris [sensitization>0.35 KUA/l] were measured. The ethic committee of the University of North approved this study. Cortisol ratio and the total IgE were analyzed by multiple linear regression models (MRL). All analyzes was done by SPSS v21 statistical software (P<.05). 88%(n=44) of the cases reported normal concentrations of cortisol[3-21 lg/dL].This finding was similar to controls(94%; n=47; P=.21).For the IgE immune response, we found that 72% of the cases and 54% of the controls presented high levels of total IgE(P=.098).In relations to the specific IgE, 74% of cases and 42% of controls were sensitized to D.f(P=.002); 44% of the cases and 16% of the controls were sensitized to P.americana(P=.065) and 58% of the cases and 26% of the controls were sensitized to Ascaris (P=.002). Serum levels of Cortisol and IgE anti D.f and anti Ascaris were observed to respond in 37% of the total IgE variance in asthmatic individuals (R 2 =0.37; b=120.8; P=.015). Anti-P americana and anti-Ascaris IgE controls respond to 32% of total IgE variance (R 2 =0.32; b=103.0; P=.000).Conclusions: This study shown that cortisol levels in cases were similar than those of healthy children, indicating that the endogenous cortisol production in this samples subjects was normal. This finding may be due to the chronic stress. Increased total IgE and atopy could be explained by the subjects genetic load with high percentage of African ancestry and continuous exposure to intestinal parasitic. Further studies are needed to reproduces our results.FOOD ALLERGY DI AGNOSIS 0554 | BP14, an allergen from cupressus sempervirens pollen related to the family of snakin/gibberellin-regulated proteins APHP Trousseau, Paris, France; 2 UCT, Prague, Czech Republic; Eurofins-Biomnis, Lyon, France; 4 Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Japan; Marseille North Hospital, Marseille, France; 6 Institut Pasteur, Paris, France Introduction: The cypress pollinosis affects nearly 40% of Mediterranean allergic people. Several species of cypress are responsible and especially the Italian cypress, Cupressus sempervirens (Cups).Four groups of allergens are described and listed in the IUIS allergen databank. The group 1 is a major allergen and corresponds to a pectate lyase, the group 2 is a polygalacturonase, group 3, a thaumatinlike protein and group 4 a calcium binding protein. Other allergens were reported and specially in Cups pollen where a basic 14 kDa unidentified allergen (BP14) is recognized by 25 to 40% of cypress pollen allergic patients depending on the studied population.

TABREF20.text: 0556 | Is testing for different allergen components useful in diagnosing IgE-mediated allergy to freshwater and seawater fishes? Leung NY; Leung AS; Wong GW; Leung T Department of Paediatrics, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Prince of Wales Hospital, Shatin, Hong Kong SAR Introduction: There has been limited data on clinical usefulness of component-resolved diagnosis for fish allergy.Objectives: This study investigated: (i) the diagnostic utility of recombinant fish allergens from commercially important species in southern Chinese, the freshwater fish Ctenopharyngodon idella and seawater fish Larimichthys crocea, for IgE-mediated fish allergy; and (ii) cross-reactivity of the major allergen parvalbumin from these two species with cod.

TABREF21.text: : Parvalbumin is the best indicator of IgE-mediated fish allergy. This study highlights the importance of including locally important fish species to avoid false negative results obtained using extracts of fishes that are not commonly consumed in the population. The usefulness of heat-labile allergen components such as enolase and aldolase in fish allergy diagnosis needs to be further evaluated. [This work is supported by a grant from the Hong Kong Institute of Allergy Research Grant 2016.]0557 | Immunoprofile of a-gal-and B-antigenspecific responses reveals differences between red meat allergic patients and healthy individualsApostolovic D 1 ; Da Silva Rodrigeus R 2 ; Thomas P 1 ; Bigdeli N 1 ; Starkhammar M 3 ; Hamsten C 1 ; Van Hage M 1 Karolinska Institutet and University Hospital, Stockholm, Sweden;

TABREF22.text: : Red meat allergic patients with a tick bite induced a-Gal response are characterized by elevated IgE, IgG1 and IgG4 antia-Gal levels reflecting a Th2 response. Their antibody response to the B-antigen mirrors the a-Gal response. The healthy B-group on the other hand, is characterized by a nearly non-existing IgE and overall low IgG responses to a-Gal, where a natural IgG2 response dominates, most likely induced by gut microbiota. Dubiela P 1 ; Kabasser S 1 ; Geiselhart S 1 ; Bublin M 1 ; Mazzucchelli G 2 ; Hoffmann-Sommergruber K 1 Medical University of Vienna, Vienna, Austria; 2 Mass spectrometry laboratory, Institute of Chemistry, University of Liege, Liege, Belgium Introduction: Walnuts are potent inducers of food allergic symptoms. So far, five allergens were identified, among those, Jug r 2 belonging to the vicilin family. Based on the identification of an IgEreactive clone from a cDNA library in 1999 (Teuber et al.), the sequence fragment of Jug r 2 was determined. However, only limited data is known about the natural form of the protein. Therefore, this study aimed to purify and characterize the natural Jug r 2.Objectives: Walnuts were ground and defatted twice (1:5 w/v) by n-hexane. Proteins were extracted from walnut flour by 7 volumes of buffer (20 mM Tris/HCl, 0.5 M NaCl, 5% PVPP, 10 mM DTT, pH=8) for 4 hours at 4°C. Subsequently, purification was performed starting with ConA affinity followed by anion exchange and size exclusion. The entire mass of purified protein was identified by MALDI-TOF and ESI-QTOF mass spectrometry. Optimized multienzymatic digestion was applied for extensive protein characterization including post-translational modifications analysis and de novo sequencing. IgE binding activity of vicilin was tested in ELISA and Western Blot using sera from 70 walnut allergic patients. Level of cross-reactivity between detected allergen and selected homologues was assessed by inhibition ELISA.Results: The purified vicilin migrates in SDS-PAGE as a single band at around 50 kDa. MALDI-TOF and electrospray mass spectrometry provided 47 kDa, which is in disagreement with the previously identified Jug r 2 with a mass of 48.4 kDa (No.: Q9SEW4). LC-MS/MS data searched against recently published walnut transcriptome resulting in 89% of sequence coverage at 1%FDR peptide of a yet unknown protein. This novel protein contains two cupin domains and displays high sequence identity to other vicilins such as from hazelnut, Cor a 11 (72%), sesame, Ses i 3 (60%) and pistachio, Pis v 3 (54%). In contrast, sequence identity to Jug r 2 was only 44%. The immunological characterization of this novel vicilin confirmed its IgE binding activity and a high level of cross-reactivity with hazelnut, pistachio and sesame.Conclusions: In contrast to the previous Jug r 2 encoding sequence, obtained by cDNA cloning we report the characterization of another vicilin, purified from walnuts. The obtained sequence displays both, higher sequence identity to vicilins from related species and IgE cross reactivity as compared to Jug r 2. Therefore, it may represent an abundant and relevant vicilin-like allergen in walnuts that should be included in the allergen specific diagnosis.0559 | FABER IgE diagnostic test: the most comprehensive view on IgE sensitization to milks and meats Alessandri C 1 ; Tuppo L 2 ; Zennaro D 1 ; Rafaiani C 1 ; Ciancamerla M 1 ; Giangrieco I 2 ; Ferrara R 1 ; Bernardi ML 1 ; Tamburrini M 2 ; Ciardiello MA 2 ; Mari A 1 CAAM -Centri Associati di Allergologia Molecolare, Rome, Italy; Istituto di Bioscienze e Biorisorse-IBBR-CNR, Naples, Italy Introduction: Cow's milk (CM) allergy is the most common food allergy in infancy. The overall allergic reactions to CM as well as the specific sensitization pattern to each CM protein are variable from patient to patient. Specific IgE detection can help to determine whether all foods containing milk should be eliminated from the patient's diet or some milks, sharing proteins homologues but not identical to CM, might be used for feeding. Objectives: To investigate the milk and meat IgE sensitization profiles in a population of 1751 allergic patients by means of FABER, a new nanobead-based IVD test for specific IgE detection using 122 molecular allergens and 122 allergenic extracts, all coupled to chemically activated nano-particles. Results: The tested allergenic preparations, all spotted on the FABER chip, were 7 milk extracts from different species used in humans, 4 CM proteins, 4 meat extracts, 3 meat proteins and 5 serum albumins shared between milk and meat. Out of the 1751 patients 105 (5.99%), the majority of them in the first decade of life, turned out to be sensitized to at least one of the 11 Faber allergenic preparations available for routine testing. The sensitization prevalence was as follows: for milk extracts cow 73%, buffalo 70%, sheep 69%, jenny 69%, goat 67%, mare 47%, camel 43%, whilst for CM proteins Bos d 4 41%, Bos d 5 20%, Bos d 8 35%, Bos d Lactoferrin 52%. 75 patients are sensitized to at least one of the 7 Faber allergenic preparations made by meat extracts and proteins. The sensitization prevalence was: for meat extracts lamb 68%, cow 59%, rabbit 31%, pork 29%, whilst for meat proteins Bos d CA 35%, Bos d Gelatin 9%, Equ c Myoglobin 1%. Serum albumin sensitization prevalence appears very similar between milk and meat sensitized groups, having Bos d 6 the highest IgE binding prevalence and Equ c 3 the least one.Conclusions: The study results confirm differences in sensitization towards the tested milk and meat allergenic sources. Filtering the sensitization results with the patient's history and oral food challenges, when needed, could improve the allergic patient's diet. For the first time FABER allows to simultaneously test the patients to a broad panel of animal milk, meat extracts and CM proteins, providing at the same time data on sensitizations to the largest number of other inhalant, food, latex, animal and insect allergens, thus providing data for alternative feeding.0560 | Eosinophil cationic protein and eosinophil derived neurotoxin levels in children with food allergy Sentsova T; Muhortnyh V; Vorozhko I; Chernyak O Federal Research Centre of Nutrition and Biotechnology, Moscow, Russia Introduction: eosinophilic inflammation is one of the key mechanisms for the development of food allergy in children. Serum eosinophil cationic protein (ECP) and eosinophil derived neurotoxin (EDN) in feces are markers of eosinophil degranulation. Aim: To study the levels of serum ECP and fecal EDN in children with different clinical manifestations of food allergy. months old. Isolated gastrointestinal manifestations of food allergy were found in 24 children, isolated skin manifestations -28 children, mixed manifestations in 30 children. The control group consisted of 32 healthy children of the same age. The contents of serum ECP and fecal EDN were measured by immunochemiluminescence and immunoassay methods respectively.Results: All children with food allergy showed an increase serum ECP compared control group. In the group with isolated gastrointestinal symptoms-61.2 AE 9.2 ng/mL vs 7.5 AE 1.7 ng/mL (P<.05), isolated skin manifestations 101.0 AE 11.1 ng/mL vs 7.5 AE 1.7 ng/mL (P<.05), in the group with mixed manifestations of 83.6 AE 7.4 ng/mL vs 7.5 AE 1.7 ng/mL (P<.05). Statistically significant differences in fecal EDN levels in children with food allergy and control group were not found.Conclusions:The most informative marker of eosinophilic inflammation in children with food allergy is the level of eosinophil cationic protein in serum. The maximum value of this eosinophil degranulation marker were obtained in children with isolated skin manifestations of food allergy.0561 | Is mealworm food allergy indicative for food allergy to other insects?Broekman HC 1 ; Knulst AC 1 ; Gaspari M 2 ; Den Hartog Jager CF 1 ; De Jong G 3 ; Houben GF 3 ; Verhoeckx KC 3 UMCU, Utrecht, The Netherlands; 2 Magna Graecia University of Catanzaro, Catanzaro, Italy; 3 TNO, Zeist, The Netherlands Introduction: The growing world population motivates the exploration of new and more sustainable protein sources to ensure food security. Mealworm and other insects are promising candidates, with active ongoing marketing efforts within America and Europe. In previous studies we found that patients allergic to shrimp are at risk for mealworm allergy, and mealworm can also induce a primary allergy.Objectives: Investigate the allergic potential of other edible insect candidates, suggested for human consumption by WHO/FAO and EFSA, in both the mealworm and shrimp allergic population. The following insects were investigated: Tenebrio molitor; mealworm (larvae), Acheta domesticus; house cricket (bug), Zophobas morio; superworm (larvae), Alphitobius diaperinus; lesser mealworm (larvae), Locusta migratoria; African grasshopper (bug), Galleria mellonella; large waxmoth (larvae) and Hermetia illucens; black soldier fly (larvae).Results: Fifteen shrimp allergic patients and four primary mealworm allergic subjects from our previous studies were included. In 13/15 of the shrimp allergic patients and in 2/4 of the mealworm allergic patients food allergy to mealworm was confirmed by double blind placebo controlled challenge. All shrimp allergic patients were sensitized to multiple insects, on immunoblot. The``activation test (BAT) showed reaction with similar responses within each individual patient to the different species. Primary mealworm allergic patients reacted with serum binding to some insects on immunoblot, in contrary to the shrimp allergic patients. Positive basophil activation to all insects was seen.Conclusions: All shrimp allergic patients showed sensitization, to all tested edible insects, with protein recognition similar to their mealworm sensitization. Food allergy to other insects due to crossreactivity seems very likely, but a challenge should be performed to confirm this clinically.The primary mealworm allergic subjects showed sensitization to known and unknown arthropod allergens, different from the shrimp allergic patients, but only show clinical reaction to mealworm. 0562 | Fx5: Is it really worth asking for?Alves C 1 ; Romeira AM 1 ; Matos V 2 ; Leiria Pinto P 1 Immunoallergology Department, Hospital D. Estefânia, CHLC, Lisbon, Portugal; 2 Clinical Pathology Department, Hospital São Jos e, CHLC, Lisbon, Portugal

TABREF23.text: : Seven different pomegranate types were selected for this study: 2 cultivars, Dente di Cavallo and Zanna Bianca; 3 accessions, CREA-FRC4, CREA-PR1 and CREA-PR2; 1 commercial sample imported from Israel. Protein extracts, prepared from the mesocarp, juice and seeds, were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and RP-HPLC. Some protein components were purified, identified by protein sequencing and their IgE binding capacity was investigated by dot blotting, immunoblotting and FABER ® test. A variable amount of proteins was measured in the juice of the different cultivars/accessions, whereas the mesocarp was devoid of detectable amounts of them.SDS-PAGE and RP-HPLC separations highlighted a different protein profile for each cultivar. Four proteins were purified from pomegranate juice, namely chitinase, punein (homologous to Bra r 2), pommaclein (homologous to Pru p 7) and the 9k-LTP Pun g 1. All the 4 isolated proteins displayed positive signals in IgE dot blotting and immunoblotting. Specific IgE towards chitinase, pommaclein and Pun g 1 were recorded in 5 (0.31%), 6 (0.37%) and 44 (2.74%) patients out of 1606, using the FABER nanotech test. In addition, 20 patients (1.25%) were positive to the seed extract.Conclusions: Three new IgE binding proteins were identified in pomegranate juice. It was observed that seed proteins provide a significant contribution to the pomegranate allergenicity, whereas the mesocarp could represent a rich and safe source of nutraceuticals also for allergic subjects.0564 | Eosinophilic esophagitis: diagnostic work-up and follow-up -a single center experienceBenito-Garcia F 1 ; Mota I 1 ; Piedade S 1 ; GasparÂ 1 ; Morgado S 2 ; Pires S 2 ; Ratilal P 2 ; Gorjão R 2 ; Santos F 3 ; Morais-Almeida M 1 Immunoallergy Department, CUF Descobertas Hospital, Lisboa, Portugal; 2 Gastroenterology Unit, CUF Descobertas Hospital, Lisboa, Portugal; 3 Pediatrics Department, CUF Descobertas Hospital, Lisboa, Portugal Introduction: Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) an inflammatory immune-mediated condition with an increasing incidence in both pediatric and adult patients, represents a challenge in clinical practice. Objectives: Describe the clinical and histologic features, management and follow-up of patients with EoE. Methods: Retrospective characterization of 57 patients with EoE, followed at our Immunoallergy Department. All patients underwent clinical, endoscopic and allergic sensitization (food and aeroallergens) evaluation work-up. Results: The median age at first appointment was 17 [1.4;70] years old, being 19% children's (<10 years), 39% adolescents (≥10 and <19 years) and 42% adults; 63% were male. The median age of EoE symptoms onset was 12 [0.25;60] years. The most commonly

TABREF24.text: The management of EoE requires a multi-disciplinary approach with regular clinical and endoscopic surveillance to prevent complications. Dietary elimination and/or pharmacological approach are important to minimize symptoms and preserve quality of life. Histologic resolution was achieved in most patients with few relapsing cases. TABREF37.text: Cabral-Miranda G 1 ; Heath MD 2 ; El-Turabi A 1 ; Salman AM 1 ; Gomes AC 1 ; Montoya-Diaz E 1 ; Atcheson E 1 ; Skinner MA 2 ; Kramer MF 3 ; Reyes-Sandoval A 1 ; Bachmann MF 1 The Jenner Institute, University of Oxford, Oxford, United Kingdom;Introduction: Microcrystalline Tyrosine (MCT) is a depot adjuvant used in allergen specific immunotherapy. In the current study we assessed the potential of MCT to serve as an adjuvant in the development of an infectious disease vaccine (malaria). As a consequence, the study reinforced the adjuvant properties of MCT that make this an attractive biodegradable adjuvant to enhance the immunogenicity of antigen targets. Objectives: Circumsporozoite protein (CSP) of Plasmodium (P.) vivax was formulated within MCT and the induced immune responses compared to CSP formulated in PBS or Alum. Four mice per group, agematched 6 week-old females inbred C57BL/6 strain were vaccinated intramuscularly with 50 lL dose of each vaccine. The humoral immune response was analysed by ELISA for IgG1, IgG2a, IgG2b, IgG3. Results: MCT and Alum strongly increased immunogenicity of CSP compared to PBS in both C57BL/6 and BALB/c mice. Challenge studies in mice using a chimeric P. berghei expressing CSP of P. vivax demonstrated clinically improved symptoms of malaria with CSP formulated in both MCT and Alum; protection was, however, more pronounced if CSP was formulated in MCT.Conclusions: MCT is one of the very few depot adjuvants formulated in licensed vaccines for use in humans with a recognised safety profile. Here we demonstrate that MCT is able to produce high and sustained IgG responses that are specific and protective against the sporozoite of P. vivax. MCT may be an attractive biodegradable alternative adjuvant useful for the development of novel vaccines.

TABREF40.text: The average age was 36.52 AE 13.09 years with the majority (53.97%) being male. The conditions being treated with AIT were allergic rhinitis (81.76% of participants), asthma (35.14%) and Hymenoptera venom allergy (15.24%). 52.03% of participants suffered with the condition for over 5 years prior to receiving AIT. 83.86% were treated by the subcutaneous route and the rest sublingually. The main allergens treated included grass pollens, house dust mite, Parietaria and Hymenoptera venoms. Preliminary analysis of the three year follow up data, showed good adherence to AIT with 88% of participants not missing any doses per 4-monthly period. Commonest reasons for missing doses were acute illness and forgetfulness. 19.9% (n=266) of participants that initially started AIT, discontinued treatment. The discontinuation rate for those receiving sublingual immunotherapy was 15.98% compared to 20.68% for the subcutaneous route. Reasons for discontinuation included financial cost and time/work commitments.Conclusions: Compared to reported adherence rates for pharmacological treatments of other chronic medical conditions, adherence to AIT in real life practice is very good. Discontinuation rates in daily practice are comparable to those previously reported from clinical trials. Targeting the reasons for non-adherence and discontinuation will improve AIT practice.Department of Otorhinolaryngology Head and Neck Surgery, Hangzhou First People's Hospital, Nanjing Medical University, Hangzhou, China

TABREF41.text: Introduction: Recent studies demonstrated that chronic cough have significant negative-impact on health-related quality of life.Although many patients are suffering from chronic cough, there is only limited evidence and insufficient clinical data, so far. Postnasal drip is well-known and one of the common causes of chronic cough, but it have been recognized by only patient's subjective symptom.This nationwide, population-based, and cross-sectional study was undertaken using resources from The Korean National Health And Objectives: In this study, we aimed to evaluate various clinical factors associated with chronic cough. Particularly, we focused on nasal Results: Among the 17 471 subjects over all ages, a total of 7990 subjects who were 40 years old or older and who took both cough questionnaire and nasal examination were analyzed.Mean age of the enrolled population was 58.4 years and male/female ratio was 44.0%/56.0%. The prevalence of chronic cough in this study cohort was 2.10% (n=168). Chronic cough had a tendency of increasing with aging (odds ratio (OR) 1.03, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.01-1.04). Male gender had significantly higher odds ratio (OR 1.72, 95% CI 1.26-2.34) than female. Multivariate analysis showed several significant factors associated with chronic cough, those are the history of pulmonary tuberculosis (OR 1.67, 95% CI 1.05-2.66), bronchialConclusions: Overall prevalence of chronic cough in this study population was 2.10%. Prevalence of chronic cough was higher in the subjects with the history of pulmonary tuberculosis, bronchial asthma, and COPD, and in current smokers and CRS patients. Evaluation and proper management for CRS should be considered for the patients with chronic cough, especially in who has no lower airway risk factors.

For a proper diagnosis, food challenge remains the gold standard, but an accurate diagnosis cannot exclude the performance of specific in vitro tests as well. 0275 | Cockroach is the major cross-reactive allergen in shrimp-sensitized rural children in south China Yang Z 1 ; Zhao J 1 ; Wei N 1 ; Xian M 1 ; Feng M 1 ; Wong GW 2 ; Li J 1 Department of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, State Key Laboratory of Respiratory Disease, The First Affiliated Hospital of Guangzhou Medical University, Guangzhou, China; 2 Department of Paediatrics, Prince of Wales Hospital, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China Introduction: The prevalence of allergic asthma is lower in rural children in south China when compared to its urban counterpart. Little is known about food allergy (FA).Objectives: To investigate the prevalence of FA and its disparity between urban and rural areas in south China.Results: Europrevall questionnaires were harvested from 5542 school-age children in urban Guangzhou (response rate 94.3%) and 5319 in rural Shaoguan (RR 91.8%). Case-control study enrolled 189 children with food allergy as cases, and 213 controls in Guangzhou, 124 cases and 225 controls in Shaoguan. They undergo skin prick test (SPT) to 18 food-and 5 environmental allergens and serum IgE measurements against 27 food-and 7 environmental allergens. Allergen extracts from shrimp, Dermatophagoides pteronyssinus and Blattella germanica were prepared and IgE cross-relativities were compared in 23 Guangzhou and 20 Shaoguan shrimp-sensitized subjects. Shrimp allergy is the most dominant in urban (4.5%) and rural (3.7%) subjects in case-control study. The percent of adverse reaction to shrimp in Guangzhou is higher than Shaoguan (3.5% vs 1.4%, P<.001), however, SPT and IgE to shrimp [SPT: 3.7% vs 11.2%, P=.015; IgE: 12.6% vs 36.2%, P<.001] and cockroach [SPT: 5.3% vs 33.5%; IgE: 2.6% vs 27.6%, P<.001] is lower in Guangzhou. There was a significant linear correlation among IgE to shrimp and housedust-mite/cockroach in Shaoguan. The proportions of positive IgE to tropomyosin (Pen a 1, Der p 10) are lower than 7.4% in both areas.For inhibition test, cockroach has a significant higher inhibition rate of binding to IgE to house-dust-mite allergies in Shaoguan sera.Conclusions: Shrimp is the common allergic food in south China.Cockroach sensitization could explain the higher proportion of shrimp sensitization in rural subjects. Tropomyosin is not the primary sensitizer in our study. 0276 | Molecular recognition profiles and clinical patterns of PR-10 sensitization in a birch free Mediterranean area Scala E 1 ; Abeni D 1 ; Cecchi L 2 ; Giani M 1 ; Asero R 3 IDI IRCCS, Rome, Italy; 2 UOSD Allergy and Immunology, Prato, Italy;Ambulatorio di Allergologia, Clinica San Carlo, Paderno Dugnano, Milan, Italy

TABREF62.text: Energy and nutrient intake was assessed in 36 adult patients with active EoE (27 males, 9 females) using 3-day food diaries. The results were compared with Dutch Recommended Dietary Allowances (RDA) for energy, macro-and micronutrients, as well as to intake levels of adults from the Dutch National Food Consumption Survey 2007-2010 by sex. Statistical analysis was performed with SPSS version 19.0 using t tests. Skewed data were log-transformed prior to analyses and presented as the mean [95%CI] on the original (back-transformed) scale. Mann-Whitney U tests were used if data were not normal even after transformation. Results: Average percentage of energy (en%) from protein, carbohydrates and total fat in EoE patients was in line with dietary guidelines. Saturated fat intake in EoE patients was higher than the RDA (max 10 en%) in both males (13.5 [95%CI: 12.4; 14.6] en%) and females (13.0 [95%CI: 10.2; 15.9] en%), whereas dietary fibre intake was lower than the RDA (30 g/d); i.e 20.9 [95%CI: 18.3; 23.4] g/d in males and 19.8 [95%CI: 13.3; 26.2] g/d in females. In males, the majority of micronutrient intake levels were above the RDA with the exception of selenium (45.4 [95%CI: 40.5; 50.9] vs 60 lg/d), vitamin A (418 [95%CI: 309; 564] vs 900 lg RE/d) and vitamin D (2.1 [95% CI: 1.7; 2.7] vs 10 lg/d), whereas females did not meet the RDA of a larger number of nutrients (i.e calcium, iron, selenium, vitamins B1, C and D). Compared to the general Dutch population, male EoE patients had a significantly higher intake of total fat (as en%) and significantly lower intakes of potassium, magnesium, zinc, iodine and vitamins A, B2, B6, B12 and D. In contrast, females with EoE only had significantly lower vitamin C intake. Conclusions: Adult EoE patients' intake of dietary fibre and some micronutrients was below recommended values. Compared to the Dutch general population, male EoE patients had lower intakes of a large number of nutrients. These results support our hypothesis that diet may be associated with the predisposition of allergy development in EoE.

However, in mothers of AD children, a stress-related obsessive-compulsive symptoms brought on by the disease may also have occurred. In this regard, there is need for new studies with larger patient group.Conclusions: The diagnosis of paediatric eczema was accurately made in Primary Care; however, the quality of eczema management was less than adequate. We hypothesize that B cells may have a central role in tolerance induction, leading to switch of IgE to IgG4, as well as by the production of regulatory cytokines. In the future, we aim to study the circulating B cell compartment, including regulatory B cells and correlate it to the levels of IgE and IgG4 before and after OIT.

TABREF101.text: : Levels of total IgE, ECP and EDN were significantly higher in the severe recalcitrant AD group in comparison with mild/moderate AD group. Total IgE, ECP, EDN and number of eosinophils showed significant positive correlation with SCORAD. After stratification by severity, only EDN showed significant correlation with SCORAD in the severe recalcitrant group. EDN showed significant correlation with SCORAD after treatment with cyclosporine A. Conclusions: EDN correlated with disease severity in both mild/ moderate and severe recalcitrant AD. Serum level of EDN could be considered as a candidate molecule as a clinical biomarker for evaluating AD disease activity. TABREF105.text: : Harsh conditions of heat and pressure (138°C, 2.56 atm for 30 minutes), was the most efficient treatment to decrease the IgE-binding properties of cashew and pistachio allergen and to diminish IgE cross-linking capacity, specially in pistachio. The use of treated cashew and pistachio with reduced allergenic capabilities could be of value for the development of respective forms of allergen-specific immunotherapy.0450 | Evaluation of gut microbiota and fecal butyrate concentration in children affected by non-IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy Nocerino R 1 ; Berni Canani R 1 ; Paparo L 1 ; Calignano A 1 ; De Caro C 1 ; Nagler C 2 ; Laiola M 1 ; De Filippis F 1 ; Ercolini D 1 University of Naples Federico II, Naples, Italy; 2 University of Chicago, Chicago, United States Introduction: Gut microbiota of subjects with IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy(CMA) exhibits significant differences if compared with healthy controls(HC). Objectives: We aimed to evaluate gut microbiota composition and butyrate production in children with non-IgE-mediated CMA and in HC.We evaluated 20 HC, and 46 non-IgE-mediated CMA children:patients with recent evidence of non-IgE-mediated CMA at diagnosis; patients with diagnosis of non-IgE-mediated CMA treated with extensively hydrolysed casein formula EHCF; patients with diagnosis of non-IgE-mediated CMA treated with EHCF+Lactobacillus rhamnosus GG (LGG);patients with a previous diagnosis of non IgE-mediated CMA, but with evidence of oral tolerance acquisition, treated with EHCF+LGG. Microbiota composition was studied by 16S rRNA gene amplicon sequencing(V3-V4 region)on Illumina MiSeq platform. Fecal butyrate concentration was evaluated by gas chromatography interfaced to a mass spectrometer. Results: Non-IgE-mediated CMA subjects exhibited significant changes in gut microbiota composition if compared with HC, while microbial diversity was not affected by the health status. Hierarchical clustering based on fecal microbiota composition highlighted a separation of CMA subjects, while treated (EHCF and EHCF+LGG) clustered together with HC. Only Bacteroidetes was significantly increased in CMA. Genus-level analysis revealed that Streptococcus was decreased, while Bacteroides, Alistipes and Haemophilus were increased in CMA compared to HC (P<.05). Their abundance decreased following both the treatments (P<.05), in fact EHCF+LGG ABSTRACTS | 317 treated children showed a lower level of Bacteroides compared to EHCF(P<.05). On the contrary, higher abundance of Lactobacillus was found in EHCF+LGG (P<.05). Health status (HC vs CMA subjects) was the largest contributor to Bacteroides differential abundance suggesting that CMA was the most important variable explaining the levels of Bacteroides in gut microbiota. The treatment with EHCF+LGG appeared to restore the Bacteroides sub-genus pattern, bringing such diversity much similar to that shown by the HC. Fecal concentration of butyrate was significantly higher in non-IgEmediated CMA infants treated with EHCF+LGG when compared with those treated with EHCF alone. Conclusions: Non-IgE-mediated CMA is associated to gut microbiota dysbiosis. Sub-genus Bacteroides diversity differentiates HC and CMA infants and it is restored in EHCF+LGG treated subjects. This dietary strategy is also able to increase butyrate production. 0451 | Non-digestible oligosaccharides can influence IgE-mediated basophil degranulation in whole blood of peanut allergic patients Hayen SM 1 ; Den Hartog Jager CF 1 ; Knulst AC 1 ; Knol EF 1 ; Garssen J 2 ; Willemsen LE 2 ; Otten HG 1 UMC Utrecht, Utrecht, The Netherlands; 2 Universiteit Utrecht, Utrecht, The Netherlands

JACI 2016: Sep 30. pii: S0091-6749(16)31049-1. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jaci.2016.0461 | Hyperamylasemia among patients treated with omalizumabKarabiber E 1 ; Aktas OO 1 ; Ozdemir E 1 ; Celebioglu E 1 ; Sahiner UM 2 ; Karakaya G 1 ; Kalyoncu AF 1 Hacettepe University School of Medicine, Department of Chest Disease, Division of Allergy and Clinical Immunology, Ankara, Turkey; Hacettepe University School of Medicine, Department of Pediatric Allergy, Ankara, Turkey Introduction: Postmarketing experience with omalizumab treatment showed anaphylaxis, hair loss, thrombocytopenia, fever, arthralgia and rash as side effects. One patient with chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU),and under omalizumab treatment for 10 months developed hyperamylasemia, and autoimmune pancreatitis, and later she was diagnosed to have IgG4 related disease. Based on this patient, we aimed to analyse if serum amylase levels of patients who are under omalizumab treatment were high. Objectives: A total of 78 patients under omalizumab treatment for severe asthma and CSU were evaluated for serum amylase levels, and if high those patients were further evaluated for possible etiology Results: MeanAEstandard deviation age of the patients were 44.0AE1.5 and 54 (69.2%) were female. Of the 78 patients 61 had CSU and 17 had asthma. The meanAEstandard deviation duration of omalizumab treatment was 20.6AE1.7 months. Mean cumulative omalizumab dose was 5542AE580 mg. In 19 patients there was at least one measurement of high amylase level. Of these 19; 13 patients showed a transient hyperamylasemia and their subsequent measurements were within normal levels, remaining 6 patients' serum amylase levels were persistently high. The index case had both high pancreatic and serum amylase levels, and she later was diagnosed as IgG4 related disease. Remaining five patients with persistently high amylase levels were evaluated for gastroenterologic diseases. All six patients had normal abdominal computed tomography scans. To investigate if these five patients had macroamylasemia, amylase/creatine clearance ratios were calculated and in all five patients found to be less than lower limit of normal. Patients with transient hyperamylasemia were compared to patients with normal amylase levels, and it was shown not to be associated with age, cumulative dosage, body mass index, duration of treatment, and duration of disease.Patients with persistent high amylase levels were older, compared to the ones with normal amylase levels (P=.015).Conclusions: Not having pretreatment serum amylase levels, and a control group are limitations of the study. However, high serum amylase level detected in six cases on omalizumab of treatment is remarkable. The drug may conjugate with serum amylase to form macroamylase, this may be the explanation of probable macroamylasemia in remaining five patients. This is the first study that investigates suspicious association between omalizumab treatment and hyperamylasemia. Further prospective studies are needed to elucidate the problem.0462 | Omalizumab, lights and shadows of our experienceLopez Couso V; Gonzalez Lopez P; Rodriguez Cabreros MI; Torres Perez B; Barrios Albajar M; Rodr ıguez Mosquera M; Iglesias Cadarso A Hospital Univesitario Puerta de Hierro, Madrid, Spain Introduction: Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody that is prescribed in a stepwise addition regimen for severe asthma treatment and others disease in which you find an overexpression of immunoglobulin E, in response to external factors that in a normal situation shouldn't produce an immunological response. Since it release its trigger was severe asthma but practitioners expand it uses to other allergic diseases offering great results. Omalizumab has demonstrated in asthma and chronic urticaria to: Decrease recruitment of eosinophils and basophils; Decrease use of corticosteroids; Decrease exacerbations; Decrease number of hospitalizations; Increase of quality of life. Objectives: Our objective its to show our experience with Omalizumab since 2011. Results: We have 127 patients using Omalizumab 71 of them are actively treated and 56 have already finished.Severe asthma: We have 39 patients that are actively receiving treatment. 38% dosage of 150 mg/4 weeks, 25% 300 mg/4 weeks; 12% 300 mg/2 weeks; having a good quality of life. 25% active patients started in 2011, 41% active patients were included between 2015-16. Patients who have finished the treatment 46% are free of symptoms, 11% didn't answer to the treatment, 23% left the treatment and one died. Chronic Urticaria: We have 27 patients that are actively receiving Omalizumab. 48% of the patients are using a dosage of 300 mg each 4 weeks. 37% dosage of 150 mg each 4 weeks. Only one patient need 225 mg each 2 weeks. Patients who had finished treatment; 63% had improved with no relapse: 19% didn't answer to the treatment and 19% left the treatment. Patients with angioedema still have angioedema despite the treatment but not as often as before Omalizumab. 10 patients were treated with Omalizumab for atopicdermatitis with no answer at all. 50% were treated with 300 mg each 4 weeks, the rest used 600 mg/2 weeks for 6 months, 300 mg/2 weeks and 150 mg/4 weeks for 3 months. Patients actively treated off-label for other pathologies. 2 polyposis, 2 oral immunotherapy with egg with good response(450 mg and 300 mg each 6 weeks respectively) and 1 hymenoptera 150 mg/4 weeks in a patient with mastocytosis.Conclusions:We have seen that Omalizumab it's very effective in severe asthma and chronic urticaria. We had no answer in patients with atopic dermatitis. A review of different studies have shown its effectiveness in patients with atopic dermatitis in 300 mg dose for 4 weeks.Recent studies have demonstrated that Omalizumab it's also useful in severe asthma diseases and COPD.

TABREF113.text: 0465 | Phenotypic characterization of severe atopic asthma patients treated with mepolizumab Prazma CM 1 ; Idzko M 2 ; Bourdin A 3 ; Douglass JA 4 ; Price RG 5 ; Albers F 1 ; Yancey SW 1 GlaxoSmithKline, Research Triangle Park, United States; 2 University of Freiburg, Freiburg, Germany; 3 University Hospital Center of Montpellier, Montpellier, France; 4 The Royal Melbourne Hospital and University of Melbourne, Melbourne, Australia; 5 GlaxoSmithKline, Uxbridge, United Kingdom Introduction: Biological therapies are indicated for severe asthma according to phenotype. Clinical characteristics such as atopic status, and a variety of biological markers (eg IgE and eosinophil levels) are used to phenotype, however heterogeneity and overlap exists across phenotypes. With the increasing availability of targeted therapies, further understanding of treatment responses across phenotypes are needed, particularly in cases where there is overlap in patient eligibil-ity for these therapies. The MENSA study was a 32 week study (N=576) of mepolizumab in severe asthma. A post-hoc analysis was conducted to observe the outcomes in atopic and non-atopic asthma phenotypes from this study.

TABREF115.text: Vultaggio A 1 ; Nencini F 2 ; Pratesi S 2 ; Carraresi A 1 ; Venemalm L 3 ; Eriksson C 3 ; Mov erare R 3 ; Orsi Battaglini C 1 ; Carli G 1 ; Matucci A 1 ; Maggi E 2 Immunoallergology Unit, Department of Biomedicine, Careggi Hospital, Florence, Italy; 2 Centre for Research, Transfer and High Education DENOTHE and Department of Experimental and Clinical Medicine, University of Florence, Florence, Italy; 3 Thermo Fisher Scientific, Uppsala, Sweden Introduction: The use of infliximab (IFX) carries potential risk of immunogenicity with the production of anti-IFX antibodies (ATI), leading to loss of response or acute infusion reactions. ATI may belong to different isotypes and are usually measured by ELISA bridging assay. This test is not designed to detect IgG4 antibodies.Objectives: The objective of this study was to analyse the production of IgG4 ATI in a cohort of IFX-treated patients and to evaluate their relationship with non-IgG4 ATI and clinical outcomes. For this purpose, non-IgG4 ATI were detected by using a standardized bridging ELISA (Promonitor) in the serum of a cohort of 172 treated patients with different diseases. The same samples were further analyzed for IgG4 ATI using ImmunoCAP Specific IgG4 (Phadia) and a modified research test in which IFX had been conjugated using click chemistry to human serum albumin coupled to ImmunoCAP. A longitudinal evaluation with both assays was also performed in 38 IFXtreated patients to define the temporal evolution of IgG4 ATI.Results: Non IgG4 ATI developed in 56 out of 172 (32.5%) IFXtreated patients. Detectable levels of IgG4 ATI were shown in 38 out of 172 (22%) treated-patients. 36 out of 56 (64.3%) ATI+ patients developed detectable levels of IgG4 antibodies. Two IgG4positive but ATI-negative patients were identified. Serum levels of IgG4 positively correlated with the serum levels of non IgG4 ATI (P<.0001). Both reactive and non responder patients showed higher percentage of IgG4-positivity than tolerant and responder patients. In fact, among ATI+ IgG4+ subset of patients, 47.6% experienced adverse drug reactions, 22.2% were non-responder, 3.4% were tolerant. No significant differences were observed in patients suffering from different immune-mediated diseases. The longitudinal analysis of anti-IFX IgG4 showed that the majority of patients tested positive for IgG4 after few infusions. Conclusions: This study indicates that anti-IFX IgG4 antibodies frequently developed in treated patients and that a large part of ATI producing patients produce IgG4 against infliximab. A stronger IgG4 response toward IFX is detectable in patients with a previous hypersensitivity reaction to the drug or with a loss of response to the treatment.0468 | Omalizumab retreatment of patients with chronic idiopathic urticaria / chronic spontaneous urticaria following return of symptoms: primary results of the optima study Sussman G 1 ; Hebert J 2 ; Gulliver W 3 ; Lynde CW 4 ; Yang WH 5 ; Chambenoit O 6 ; Vieria A 7 ; Detakacsy F 7 ; Rihakova L 7 Department of Medicine, University of Toronto, Toronto, Canada; Department of Medicine, Centre Hospitalier de l'Universit e Laval, Quebec, Canada; 3 Faculty of Medicine, Memorial University of Newfoundland, St. John'S, Canada; 4 Lynde Institute for Dermatology, Markham, Canada; 5 Ottawa Allergy Research Corporation, University of Ottawa Medical School, Ottawa, Canada; 6 Novartis Pharmaceuticals Corporation, East Hanover, United States; 7 Novartis Pharmaceuticals Canada, Inc., Dorval, CanadaIntroduction: Since approval of Omalizumab for CSU/CIU (chronic spontaneous urticaria/ chronic idiopathic urticaria) a number of data gaps regarding management of patients with anti-IgE treatment surfaced. The OPTIMA study (NCT02161562) was conducted to answer some key questions on how to optimize omalizumab treatment of patients with CIU/CSU. The primary objective and topic of this abstract is the efficacy of omalizumab retreatment.Objectives: OPTIMA is a Phase 3b, international, multicenter, randomized, open-label, non-comparator study. Patients with CIU/CSU who were symptomatic despite H 1 -antagonists were randomized 4:3 to omalizumab 150 or 300 mg for 24 weeks (1st dosing period).Based on UAS7 scores, patients entered one of the following phases: treatment withdrawal (if UAS7≤6), step-up to 300 mg (if 150 mg initially and UAS7>6 at week ≥8-24), or continued treatment for 12 more weeks (if 300 mg initially and UAS7>6 at week 24). Patients in the withdrawal group who relapsed (UAS7≥16) were retreated with their initial dose. The primary endpoint of the study was the proportion of patients clinically well controlled (UAS7≤6) upon retreatment in those who were initially well-controlled but relapsed after withdrawal.Results: A total of 314 patients (73% female, 79% white, mean age 46 years, mean baseline UAS7 score 29.8) were randomized to either 150 mg (n=178) or 300 mg(n=136)omalizumab. The overall percentage of well-controlled patients after 24 weeks of treatment with omalizumab 150 mg or 300 mg was 15.2% and 64.7%, respectively. After treatment withdrawal, 44% of patients on 150 mg and 50% on 300 mg relapsed (USA7≥16) within 8 weeks. Mean time to relapse was 4.8 (150 mg) and 4.7 (300 mg) weeks. Upon retreatment, the majority of patients achieved UAS7≤6 (150 mg: 83.3% [95% CI, 62.2%À100%]; 300 mg: 89.2% [95% CI, 79.2%À99.2%]).

Additionally, the work paves the way to help further develop methods for standardising allergoid platforms. 0471 | Liposomes modified by carbohydrates for targeted siRNA delivery into the liver cells Koloskova O 1 ; Shilovskiy I 2 ; Budanova U 3 ; Nosova A 3 ; Shchelik I 3 ; Sebyakin Y 3 ; Khaitov M 2 NRC Institute of Immunology FMBA and Moscow Technological University (campus MITHT), Moscow, Russia; 2 NRC Institute of Immunology FMBA, Moscow, Russia; 3 Moscow Technological University (campus MITHT), Moscow, RussiaIntroduction: Selective drug delivery directly to the target organ can significantly reduce the side effects on the other cells and maximize the therapeutic effect of the drug. It is known that the liver cells have higher expression of lectins which can bind to the terminal D-galactose residues. Therefore, liposomal surface modification by carbohydrate derivatives produces the nucleic acid delivery system targeted to liver cells.

TABREF117.text: ; Caillot N 1 ; Bouley J 1 ; Jain K 1 ; Mariano S 1 ; Luce S 1 ; Horiot S 1 ; Airouche S 1 ; Beauvallet C 2 ; Devillier P 3 ; Chollet-Martin S 4 ; Mascarell L 1 ; Chabre H 1 ; Batard T 1 ; Nony E 1 ; Lombardi V 1 ; Moingeon P 1 Stallergenes Greer, Antony, France; 2 INRA, Jouy-En-Josas, France; Foch Hospital, Suresnes, France; 4 INSERM, UMR 996, Paris-Sud University, Châtenay-Malabry, FranceIntroduction: IgE reactivity to a specific allergen by skin prick or in vitro testing is currently used to screen patients eligible to allergen immunotherapy (AIT). Patient selection would greatly benefit from the identification of biomarkers predicting the likelihood of clinical improvement during AIT.

TABREF118.text: : Both M1 and M2 related genes were found to be hypomethylated in the KD1 group (KD1 vs HC, 20 M1 related genes with 63 CpG sites were hypomethylated, all sites P<.05; 18 M2 related genes with 64 CpG sites were hypomethylated, all sites P<.05), suggesting that both M1 and M2 related genes are overexpressed in acute KD. In the KD2 group, M2 related genes were mostly hypermethylated (KD2 vs KD1, 13 M2 related genes and 37 CpG sites, all sites P<.05), while M1 related genes showed no significant trend towards hyper or hypomethylation, suggesting that IVIG therapy results in decreased expression of M2 related genes with minimal effect on M1 related genes. Conclusions: Acute KD is associated with hypomethylation of both M1 and M2 related genes. IVIG therapy resulted in hypermethylation of M2 related genes but had no significant effect on M1 related genes. Our results suggest that both M1 and M2 related gene expression is increased in the acute phase of KD, but only M2 related gene expression are ameliorated after IVIG therapy. 0475 | Genome-wide identification of allergic rhinitis-related gene networks using blood transcriptomics in a tropical urban environment Andiappan A 1 ; Lee B 1 ; Poidinger M 1 ; Wang D 2 ; Zolezzi F 1 ; Rotzschke O 1Singapore Immunology Network (SIgN), Agency for Science, Technology and Research, Singapore, Singapore; 2 National University of Singapore, NUHS, Singapore, Singapore Introduction: Allergic rhinitis (AR) is a chronic allergic disease influenced both by genetic and environmental risk factors. These factors result in biological processes which influence gene expression and ultimately disease risk. In a previous study we established that a rather unique allergen environment characterises tropical urban areas: the massive and perennial presence of a single dominant allergen, house dust mites. We thus hypothesise that in places like Singapore the massive & perennial exposure to house dust mites should reveal key AR candidates when analysed in cohort-based correlative transcriptome studies.

TABREF119.text: : The cohort consists of ethnic Chinese individuals from Singapore with median age of 21 with a total of 112 allergic rhinitis patients and 113 non-symptomatic controls. Total RNA isolated from those individuals using whole blood samples and were processed using Illumina Human HT-12 gene chips. The differential gene expression analysis revealed a total of 297 unique probes with P values <.01. A total of 23 of these probes were still significant after correction for multiple testing (FDR<.05) targeting mostly genes representing immune regulatory and/or signaling molecules. Further analysis using Ingenuity Pathway Analysis revealed key immune functions such as recruitment, infiltration and response of eosinophils, tolerisation of mast cells and activation of basophils & eosinophils. Additionally inflammatory response characterized by activation of Th2 cells and myeloid cells, chemotaxis of granulocytes and leukocyte migration. Examples of the candidate genes identified are IL5RA, CLC, SIGLEC8, CCL23, which all had been previously reported to be associated to AR and other allergic phenotypes.Conclusions: Using a whole transcriptome approach, we have identified known and novel AR candidates and relevant immune pathways which can be potentially targeted for disease treatment and/or diagnosis & management. A validation of these significant AR candidates and gene networks with expression data of populations

TABREF124.text: Romain T 1 ; Carsin A 2 ; Gomez C 3 ; Cl each I 1 ; Dubus J 2 ; Reynaud Gaubert M 3 ; Mege J 4 ; Ranque S 5 ; Vitte J 4 Assistance Publique Hôpitaux de Marseille, Hôpital de La Conception, Laboratoire d'Immunologie, Marseille, France; 2 Aix-Marseille Universit e, Facult e de M edecine de Marseille -Assistance Publique Hôpitaux de Marseille, Hôpital Timone, Service de Pneumologie P ediatrique et Centre de Ressources et de Comp etence en Mucoviscidose (p ediatrique), Marseille, France; 3 Aix-Marseille Universit e, Facult e de M edecine de Marseille, Assistance Publique Hôpitaux de Marseille, Hôpital Nord, Centre de Ressources et de Comp etence et Mucoviscidose (adultes), Marseille, France; 4 Assistance Publique Hôpitaux de Marseille, Hôpital de La Conception, Laboratoire d'Immunologie -Aix-Marseille Universit e, Facult e de M edecine de Marseille, Marseille, France; 5 Aix-Marseille Universit e, Facult e de M edecine de MarseilleLaboratoire de Parasitologie & Mycologie, Hôpital Timone, Marseille, France Introduction: Detection of specific IgE responses is a cornerstone of allergy diagnosis, while specific IgG responses are usually considered as irrelevant. Aspergillus fumigatus (Af) is an ubiquitous airborne mold that causes allergic broncho-pulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) in asthmatic and cystic fibrosis (CF) patients. Specific IgG and IgE are both presumed relevant for ABPA diagnosis. Specific IgE, but not IgG4, responses to Af molecular allergens were reported to display distinct profiles between ABPA patients and CF patients carrying « benign » fungal sensitization. Objectives: 1. To describe specific IgG responses to Af extract and molecular allergens in CF and ABPA patients. 2. To compare specific IgG, IgE, and IgG4 responses in CF and ABPA patients. 3. To compare three commercial methods for the determination of specific IgG to Af. Results: Specific IgG, IgE and IgG4 to Af extract and molecular allergens Asp f 1, Asp f 2, Asp f 3, Asp f 4 and Asp f 6 were measured with a fluorescent immuno Assay (FEIA) method in 50 patients comprising 40 CF patients (16 children; 24 adults) and 10 ABPA patients (2 children; 3 CF). IgG to Af were measured with an ELISA kit and immunoelectrophoresis (IEP) in 44 of these patients. Mycological culture was performed in 38 patients. Concomitant IgG and IgE production against Af extract and Asp f 1 was most frequent (90%-100% of both groups). Dissociated IgG and IgE responses were found for other allergens; isolated IgE was more frequent than isolated IgG (29 vs 12) production, especially in the ABPA patients. IgG to Asp f 3 and Asp f 4 were more prevalent among ABPA patients (50% vs 21% and 70% vs 33%, P=.03 and 0.02). Except for Asp f 2, IgG levels to Af extract and allergens were significantly higher in ABPA patients (P ≤ 0.05). IgG and IgG4 levels to Af extract and allergens were correlated, except for Asp f 3 et 4 in the ABPA group and Asp f 6 in patients without ABPA. FEIA and ELISA or IEP IgG determinations were concordant in about 50%. Ten out of 14 positive Aspergillus spp cultures were associated with detection of IgG to Af extract with the three methods. Conclusions: Specific IgG and IgE to Af extract and molecular allergens may help distinguish between ABPA and fungal sensitization. Af molecular allergens display distinct IgG and IgE responses, suggesting different immunogenic behavior and biomarker potential. 0512 | Personalized and rapid food allergy test using natural allergenic extracts Frossard M 1 ; Gasilova N 1 ; Arlettaz L 2 ; Dayer E 2 ; Girault HH 1 Laboratoire d' Electrochimie Physique et Analytique, EPFL Valais Wallis, Ecole Polytechnique F ed erale de Lausanne, Sion, Switzerland; 2 Service d'Immuno-Allergologie, Institut Central des Hôpitaux, Sion, Switzerland

TABREF125.text: 0515 | Basophil activation test (BAT) as a measure of passive sensitization following plasma transfusionApelseth TO; Kvalheim V; Berg RS; Lund KB; Mikkelsen KE; Kristoffersen EK Haukeland University Hospital, Bergen, Norway Introduction: Passive transfer of IgE may occur in patients receiving blood components from allergic blood donors. In solvent detergent treated (SD) pooled plasma, specific IgE against common airborne allergens, peanuts, wheat, and latex have been detected. During complex surgery, patients may receive high volumes of plasma and other blood components. Basophil activation test (BAT) measures basophil response to allergens crosslinking membrane bound IgE. Basophil sensitivity may be used to monitor effects of immunotherapy and levels of circulating IgE as seen in anti-IgE treatment. Objectives: A pilot study was performed to investigate whether passive transferred IgE are able to crosslink allergens and thereby activate host basophils in patients receiving plasma transfusion during complex cardiothoracic surgeryResults: Following surgery, 15 patients were transfused with a range of 400-14200 mL SD treated pooled plasma. The day after surgery, BAT and basophil sensitivity (maximal reactivity, CDsens and Area Under the Curve (AUC)) were measured after stimulation with house dust mite and timothy in 6 concentrations (100 000-0.1 squ/mL). Basophils were identified by use of CD193, and CD63 served as activation marker. Results were reported as (mean; median; range). Significant increase in specific IgE (ImmunoCap, Thermo Fisher) against mum levels within the first day after surgery. 4 out of 15 (27%) patients had a positive BAT result against house dust mite and timothy the day after transfusion. Significant positive correlations (Spearman test) were observed between maximum levels of IgE within day 1 against house dust mite (1.61; 0.70; 0.16-7.54 kU/L) and basophil maximal reactivity (14.1; 6.7; 2.1-81.1%) and AUC (106; 40; 10-730910 3 ). Similar, positive correlations were observed between maximum IgE against timothy (0.82; 0.61; 0.15-1.88) and the basophil maximal reactivity (10.8; 6.9; 2.0%-41.1%) and AUC (75; 43; 13-320910 3 ). CDsens could be calculated for 3 positive samples only and showed no correlation to IgE level, maximal reactivity or AUC.Conclusions: We conclude that passive sensitization of basophils may follow plasma transfusion in patients undergoing cardiothoracic surgery. Results must be interpreted with caution due to low number, and further studies are recommended to determine the clinical implication of these observations. 0516 | Evaluation and validation of a salivary interleukin-3 immunosorbent assay for the evaluation of chronic urticaria exacerbated by a salicylate rich diet Gumunyu E 1 ; Venter C 2 ; Dzobo W 1 ; Eren E 1 University Hospital Southampton, Southampton, United Kingdom;Division of Allergy and Immunology, Cincinnati Children's Hospital Medical Center, Cincinnati, United States

TABREF126.text: Results: Results showed there was a significantly increased IL-3 in the saliva of chronic urticaria sufferers compared to controls (mean 54.7AE76.2 vs 20.7AE32.0: P<.05). Upon excluding some patients on IL-3 lowering medication such as steroids and ranitidine (n=7), increased IL-3 was especially noted in a group of chronic urticaria patients on a high salicylate diet compared with low salicylate diet (mean 131.4 vs 42.3). Man Whitney U test showed statistical significance (median 126.3 vs 8.6 n 1 =6, n 2 =6; P=.03). IL-3 in serum was below detectable limits.Conclusions: This is the first study demonstrating raised IL-3 in the saliva of patients with chronic urticaria and proposes a novel mechanism where natural salicylates worsen symptoms of urticaria via increasing levels of IL-3. Measuring salivary IL-3 by ELISA is superior in terms of sensitivity and convenience to serum. Salivary IL-3 levels may provide a simple test to predict which patients may benefit from a low salicylate diet. 0517 | Allergorithm: allergy algorithm to increase pre-test probability of allergic disease Kos S; Neele M; Phaff R; Schenk R; Wulkan R Maasstad Hospital, Rotterdam, The Netherlands
